column10:
This is a great game! For all the WW2 RTS games out there this has to be one of the best. I don't play much online against real people, they tend to either stomp me with the quickness or leave once I destroy their first armor unit. So I play custom matches against AI, which is pretty tough and offers a good challenge.

It has community made maps and stuff in the workshop, some maps are pretty cool. Sometimes I get some lag when epic battles are taking place in choke points and lots of artillery and fragmentation bombs are dropping everywhere. Sometimes there are moments when I just sit back and laugh because there is so much chaos unfolding before me.

Very enjoyable, not a steep learning curve, epic moments, decent enough graphics, workshop content, and flammenwerfers!

Here is my personal and completely honest review, of Company of Heroes 2

The game itself is not bad at all, actually. It's a pretty good strategy game, that involves careful micro-managing of every SINGULAR one of your personal units within the game, however, this is also where it's main flaw lies, at least for me. For most strategy players out there (including myself) it's usually found to be EXTREMELY annoying, whenever you have to micro-manage EVERY LITTLE soldier on the battlefield, kind of like you do in this game, as sometimes it causes a lot of problems with in-game coordination and usually leads to you ending up in extremely nasty and unsavoury situations half of the time because of this, because it's just so easy to mess up if you aren't a master at micro-managing. Also, the fact that some rounds can drag out for over an hour or even more, especially if you are playing in the Annihilation game mode, can get VERY irritating, if the round itself lasts too long, because one player can't get an upper hand over their opponent. Also, not to mention the fact that you need to PAY to unlock the rest of the in-game's playable factions, I mean... need I say more about that?


However, it's not all grim and despair with this game, as I personally found enjoyment with the game's campaign, it's historical accuracy, as well as the fact that even when it seems like you have completely lost a round, you can still turn it around in your favour, no matter how desperate it may seem like your situation is in that specific round. However, I still won't recommend you getting this game, for one simple reason; if you aren't prepared for a HARDCORE in-depth strategy experience, where you have to:
- Micro-manage EVERY SINGLE LITTLE soldier on your team with LASER like precision, unless you wanna risk losing a whole round, just because you didn't bring over a single soldier to a very specific position
- Potentially play a whole hour or even longer during a SINGULAR round (especially if you are playing in Annihilation mode), because you or your opponent can't get the upper hand over each other
- Be willing to pay an extra 52 bucks (at least if you decide to buy the standard base game with the USSR and the Wehrmacht factions, that is), to access the 3 other playable in-game factions

Then this game simply isn't for you

Want to have a 1-2 hour long WW2 simulation where the AI alternates from being dumb as rocks to a hivemind capable of executing war plans faster than the computer from that movie War Games? 
Want to suffer eternally while mortars, crossfire from a million different emplacements, assorted artillery, Fallschirmj√§ger and airstrikes rain down like hellfire all around and on you? 
Want to know how well your friends are able to coordinate blobs of infantry and tanks without utterly messing up the flow of battle, getting your hard-earned, veteran squads and heavy tanks blown to smithereens?
Play this game, and experience the pain of disconnecting an hour into the game when you finally reach the enemy's base with your tanks, unable to rejoin, as your friends mourn your sudden disconnection.

To make money off Chinese people without valuing them, Chinese mods cannot be installed, and Chinese patches are unusable. I can understand your foreign language, but I'm giving a negative review for the sake of the Chinese market! During WWII, the Soviet Union sacrificed an entire generation to resist German fascism. In your case, this sacrifice is insulted, full of your damn foreign nonsense! This is a negative review on behalf of the soldiers who sacrificed their lives on the Soviet-German front!

The sacrifices made on the Chinese front during WWII are comparable to those on the Soviet-German front; otherwise, Japan and Germany would have successfully joined forces. Players don't demand you to add the Chinese faction, but could you at least make a Chinese version? Wanting to make money without putting in the actual work, what kind of game are you making? This is another reason for a negative review from us players!

I will advise all surrounding players to change their reviews to negative. Not because the game is bad, but because you people are terrible!

Additionally, your country, Poland, despite being a sworn enemy of the Soviet Union, unequivocally supported Japan's militaristic full-scale invasion of China and believed it was justified! The capitalist countries you adore did not land in France until 1944, conducting what they call a "just war," while the Soviet and Chinese people did not take a single step back from the beginning to the end! They fought back with the resolve to survive against all odds! "Company of Heroes," this game, should have celebrated those inspiring and tearful soldiers, but you turned it into rotten pork on the chopping board!

2024 Review: 

I have now played 1,000.1 hours. At my first review, it was 275,7 hours. Here in 2024, CoH2 is still being played and I still think it's a FANTASTIC game! I've nearly completed all DLC missions on the highest difficulty and generally would recommend all DLC. 

I mostly just play against bots, with other people. I think that's much more fun than versus actual players, so this is an option for you too. CoH3 doesn't seem like it was a great success and I haven't bought it. Meanwhile, CoH2 can still be enjoyed with friends. The worst thing about it, is the occassional "sync error" which disconnects a game in progress. The other thing, is how slow it is earning enough gold to buy new commanders and the fact that there's no new commanders coming in. I also think the game suffers from Achievement Spam, since there's many I think are pointless, like building X amount of something to kill Y amount of something else, but then, some people like it. 

I recently discovered there's Art of Defence mods in the Workshop as well, so you can play with others against waves of enemies. It's cool. It's reminiscent of the C&C Zero Hour days, somewhat. Currently, CoH2 is still my preferred RTS game. The graphics are still lovely, the gameplay is fun and there's good map and faction variety to keep people playing.


2017 review underneath:
----------------

A fantastic game. 

- Excellent graphics.

- Very realistic units. So satisfying when you recognise them in movies!

- Great campaign. 

Just very very good allround, as an RTS. It really feels like watching a warzone every battle. Here's a review for the British Forces DLC because I can't post it over there: 

I can recommend this expansion, as indeed I can with every one of CoH2. If you like CoH2, you shouldn't miss out on the British forces. The drawback with these, is that there's no singleplayer campaign and so you do need to play multiplayer. However I find it fine just playing against the CPU in that regard, instead of real players. You can also create custom matches of course, if you just want to be alone against a CPU opponent, rather than being bothered by other players on your team.The units are very useful in terms of defence, which is how I play. Early on for example, you have access to an MG unit immediately, which is super useful for locking down areas, since enemy infantry then can't advance, but will get pinned down. There aren't a lot of British commanders as of writing sadly (August 2017). So in addition to the 3-4 Commanders you start with, there's an additional 3 you can earn or buy. These 3 are super useful, but that also means in my view, that the default ones are pretty garbage. The marketing text says there's different nationalities represented in the units and that may be so, but I certainly haven't noticed it, because it's not that distinct. Still, it's nice to hear British voices. British tanks are alright, although in my experience other tanks from other factions are all vastly better. The most interesting British ones can only be unlocked by using a Commander; such as the Crocodile or AVRE Churchil tanks. It's also a pretty annoying thing, that British units can't build tank traps or such like. However British infantry units are quite strong when in cover and when using Royal Engineers to build a Forward Base, you can heal your units and really dig in. If you add some Bofors emplacements 
(basically an Anti-Air gun which can destroy most units) and some AT guns, then you can really turtle like a boss. Likewise, British Royal Engineers can build static mortar placements. These have a pretty huge range and fire pretty quickly. However in general, artillery isn't the British strong suit, as a great artillery unit is generally lacking. British units instead make their base fire artillery and this means that an infantry unit for example, can be upgraded so that while fighting, you can call in artillery fire. This is in addition to any grenades or such that they have. I don't think it's so accurate though, until you buy an expensive defensive upgrade later on.

I experienced every human emotion in one game of company of heroes 2. 10/10

My friends, it has often been said that I like war.

My friends, I like war...

No, friends, I love war!

I love holocausts.

I love blitzkriegs.

I love defensive lines.

I love sieges, charges, I love mop-up operations, and retreats.

Wars across prairies, in streets, in trenches, in grasslands, in frozen tundras, through deserts, on the sea, in the air, I love every act of war that can occur upon this earth.

I love blasting the enemy to smithereens with artillery salvos that thunder across the lines of battle.

My heart leaps with joy whenever a soldier is tossed high into the air and cut to pieces by well placed sniper rounds. And there is nothing like a tank operator using a Tiger acht acht (88) to destroy enemy tanks. And the feeling that comes when a soldier runs screaming from his blazing tank, only to be mowed down by heavy machine gun fire, is such an exquisite feeling. Like when ranks of infantry brandish their bayonets rushing into the enemy line. It moves me deep within my heart to watch a fresh recruit stabbing over and over into the bloated chest of a long-dead enemy.

The sight of deserters being strung up from a street lamp is an irresistible pleasure. And there is nothing more arousing than the sounds made by prisoners of war dropping like flies, screaming in agony as they're mowed down by ear piercing schmeissers!

When a band of pitiful resistance fighters makes their final stand with nothing but small arms, only to have their city smashed to atoms block by block by 4.8 ton bombshells, (tone suddenly softens) I'm in ecstasy.

I love it when my forces are ravaged by a Russian armored division. It's so sad to see towns and villages that were supposed to be defended at all costs, being laid to waste, their women and children being raped and killed.

I love to be squashed under the heel of the British and American war machines. The humiliation as my men crawl around like vermin, ducking the jagdbombers flying overhead.

Gentlemen... All I ask for is war, war so grand as to make Hell itself tremble. Gentlemen, I ask you as fellow brothers in arms what is it that you really want? Do you wish for further war as I do? (Voice begins to raise) Do you wish for a merciless, bloody war? A war whose fury is built with iron and lightning and fire? (Dramatically raises voice) Do you ask for war to sweep in like a tempest, leaving not even ravens to scavenge from this Earth!?

(The soldiers begin shouting/chanting "Krieg" meaning "War")
...Very well. Then krieg is what you shall have. We are a clenched fist, ready to strike down all who oppose us with our might.

But... After enduring over half a century wallowing in the darkness, for us, a simple "ordinary" war will no longer be sufficient.

(Raises voice) We need a MASSIVE war! A war beyond any other that man's history has ever known!

We are but a single battalion... The remnants of a defeated army numbering less than a thousand strong. However, I believe that each of you old warriors is equal to a thousand of their sickly soft children! We represent a force that could easily defeat an army of a million and one men!

It is time for them to awake the ones who sent us screaming into oblivion, and who now lie sleeping. Let's drag them out of bed by the hair, and remind them of what we are! We will remind them of what it feels like to live in fear. We will remind them of the sound our jackboots make against their throats.

(Cuts to scene of Alexander Anderson looking up at Millenium's Zeppelin and the blood-red moon, before fading back to The Major)
We will remind them that there are more things between Heaven and Hell than are dreamt of in their philosophy.

(Cuts to soldiers shouting "It's Europe! We see the lights of Europe!" while looking out at scene below, and then meeting of Hellsing and Integra, before cutting back to The Major)
Our Kampfgruppe of one thousand vampires is going to burn this world down to ash.

(Cuts to window scene)
Yes, my friends! Soon, Europe's charred remains will illuminate the night sky!

(Cuts to window with Seras and Pip)
I have brought you all back just as I promised I would. Back to our favorite battlefield. Back to our beloved war!

(The Letzes Battalion hail the Major as their Battalion Commander.)
...At last, the sea lion has crossed the ocean and is heading up the hill. Attention, all soldiers of the Millennium Battalion! This is a message from your commander.

‚Ä¶Friends... let‚Äôs bring them hell.

Better than COH 3 by a mile, after almost 500 hours of gameplay I highly recommend not buying COH 3 because COH 2 is significantly better.

I would not recommend this game to anyone who plays single-player down to the simple fact that Company of Heroes 2 has the single worst 'AI' I have ever experienced in a video game. It cheats more blatantly than any I have ever seen but to any human player with even the slightest grasp of the game it doesn't matter because of how stupid the AI is. It is given vast amounts of cheating even on normal but really hard and extreme are just not enjoyable to play in the least because of the amount of cheating that is on display here. When the enemy AI has seven panthers barely ten minutes in the game I think we have problems, its not a matter of real strategy then as it is a matter of exploiting the AI to defeat it and this stops feeling like a World War 2 strategy game and just becomes a lesson in tedium and frustration - two words you should not want attached to your game ever.  
Even with all the cheating the problem is the AI is 99% of the time too stupid to make it matter in the overall context of the game, I noticed for example they specifically are ENRAGED when ever you build some sort of structure like a forward base or resource cache, in fact they become so obsessed with it this can be used to exploit them for your own benefit. That's how the AI works with very dumb decisions like that, its just bad really really bad AI. Oh yeah and grenade spam, the AI loves to spam grenades so get ready for that - Company of Heroes 2 Microhell Edition whereas using grenades against the AI is virtually useless save on MG crew or in buildings since the exact nanosecond you click the grenade button the AI reacts to it, so they are already on the other side of the map by the time you have clicked the button and your union went through the process of throwing the grenade.
As for the allied AI its the complete opposite, it was clearly designed to do barely anything other than mostly support so its often the case that your ally Ai get pushed all the way back to their base within five minutes effectively meaning you are fight the opponent single-handedly, especially 'fun' on the 8 player map. This shows that this stupid, inconsistant, cheating AI was purposely designed like this - this is what Relic's AI designer wanted for reasons that will always baffle me. Oh and the AI can use their ability in the fog of war. Did you pull your tank back to repair? oh well the AI uses its aircraft anti-tank ability to wipe it out even though not a single unit was around and don't give me any excuses, I have watched countless hours of replays and study them all in extreme detail - the AI cheats, it cheats blatantly to make up for how piss poor the AI actually is.
It just comes down to the fact that Relic and specifically their AI designers are lazy and/or incompetent, and I'm tired of paying for such shoddy work which is why Company of Heroes 2 will probably be the last relic title I buy. I could go on for hours about the cheating and I have in fact spent a great amount of time studying the AI cheating in detail, but another major problem is the Relic fanbase itself is made up of some of the most stubborn fanatical people I've come across and they will argue until they are blue in the face the AI doesn't cheat which renders it a pointless battle to argue with so I prefer to just leave this negative review instead warning people buying this for single-player. Mindless devoted fanbases ruin a game more than anything when they don't want to face criticisms with their beloved game/developer and it hurts the company and games overall so its a self-defeating action. I'm sure this stupidity is being passed over to CoH3 which doesn't seem to have improved anything wrong with the series and in fact has made it worse.
Don't make the mistake though - the AI cheats beyond all reason but that doesn't mean you can't win, even on extreme you can pull off a victory if you think enough but its never an enjoyable victory rather just a frustrating and comedically inane waste of time. [h3] Company of Heroes 2: it's less luck and more strategy [/h3]

Company of Heroes 2 is certainly not for everyone, not least because of DLC that restricts factions in MP. Although there are decent Eastern Front and American DLC campaigns, most of my time has been spent in multiplayer, and I'd recommend it for several reasons. Certainly compared to some games in the RTS genre, the Company of Heroes series relies much more on strategy and tactics to carry the day rather than mindless RNG. Sure, you can lose an engagement because of RNG but I never felt like I lost a game over one. Some of my mates would disagree, of course, as I'm almost unbeatable on any map, with any faction, and sometimes, I don't even need to pick a commander against them. Perhaps they'd argue that the opening fight is much more critical. In my view, a fair strategy game revolves around predictable opening moves and tactics, leading to consistent outcomes. Company of Heroes is, therefore, more of an asymmetric version of Chess than anything else. I‚Äôve lost my fair share of MP games, but it‚Äôs hardly because I felt cheated, I usually felt outplayed.

Nevertheless, some games can be tighter than others, and I've had instances where lucky anti-tank shots and a few tricks have given me an edge to secure needed victory points or strategic resources. In this case, since there are no arbitrary resources (e.g. reinforcement points) that dictate the spawning of units, if the enemy is not capturing the territory points, then you're almost certainly better off than your opponent. This means that winning engagements has a tangible impact on the battle, rather than a simple: rock, papers, scissors match that occurs in games such as Men of War, War Game: Red Dragon, or Steel Division (not that those games are poorly designed, they‚Äôre different). Company of Heroes makes it so that if you're winning, it's a little easier to keep winning. I appreciate the resource system for this reason. Although it still allows for quick comebacks, in no sense are you penalised for playing aggressively because losing a unit doesn't mean that the enemy can make an unequivocal comeback; you'll have more resources! This is important as you need those resources to build armoured vehicles, tanks, and support equipment. This system is not perfect (or even particularly deep), but it enables more strategic differences, as the mid-game can change depending on the resource imbalance between players.

We sadly don't play Company of Heroes 2 anymore. Instead, we play Men of War, which is fun, don't get me wrong, but it always makes losing to RNG much more frequent. Cheeky anti-tank shots or several bounces of anti-tank grenades are never enjoyable when that‚Äôs what decides matches. We make jokes because: ‚ÄòOf course, the tank was angled,‚Äô or ‚ÄòAnti-tank grenades don‚Äôt immobilise it, they weren‚Äôt that strong,‚Äô to make fun at each other when we‚Äôre all cursing, but none of these problems ever existed in Company of Heroes. I wonder if others have noticed similar imbalances regarding games with reinforcement points. In those games, should I be penalised for capturing points closer to the enemy spawn?

Is it worth playing Company of Heroes 2 now - it's up to you. I luckily bought this game and all its DLC for $10, which was a fantastic deal. If you're interested, then you might want to grab it during a sale! For the reasons above, and as many have pointed out, it's difficult to get into the game when you're starting without tangible matchmaking, but you can always try. Because of my hours, I certainly got my money's worth...

Man, did this game not stand the test of time well. I remember this game as very cool, squad-based, objective focused with a great story. After trying it for a bit again, I think you can play many other RTSes that will give you a more fun time. It still does have  a right to exist, in it's class, I still think its one of the best. It might just be a case of "you're now too old" or "git gut", but a game should still invite you to get better without being too frustrating. The barrier to entry might just be a bit too high.

The good:
- Five very distinct armies to play with
- Objective heavy*
- Really feels like a slow, front-line war*
- Enough (re)playability with friends (2v2, 3v3, 4v4)
- Active modding community. I'd recommend playing on modded maps any day!

The bad:
- More difficult AI is mostly of the "just give 'em more resources" variety. All AI will micro very heavily (think, grenades, multi-squad movements), while at the same time happily facetanking flamethrowers and grenades. In principle this would be fine without the AI bonuses, but instead it'll feel more like fighting an unending stream of mooks  with a gazillion HP, instead of a clever mechanical fight. Be prepared to bring your cheese against AI!
- There are clear "better" strategies. Because scouting is relatively hard (scouts are squishy and troops are expensive and slow), rush strategies are generally superior. Not true for very chokepoint-heavy maps, of course. Still, winrates within ~2% of 50/50, so not ugly. Check e.g. https://coh2stats.com/ and look for yourself!

The ugly:
- * If you like to play against AI with a few buddies like me, be prepared to be pushed in very specific strategies. E.g. playing choke-point maps and focusing on artillery only. This is slightly alleviated because of the many options to play with, but be prepared to be wildly underpowered playing certain commanders or armies. Unfortunately I could not find the numbers, but in principle the hard AI cheats with resource multiplier (I think you need to trade about 1 for 2 to be even, just by experience), and the expert even worse with mapcheats and all. See e.g. https://steamcommunity.com/app/231430/discussions/0/135512133550194680/ for a short discussion
- * Fire-based weaponry absolutely _melts_ any infantry line anywhere. For sure the fire-airstrike will mess your armies up because:
- Pathing! Pathing is _horrible_. Do not assume squads will actually move to where you send them, because they get stuck in bushes, on corners of buildings, behind (friendly) tanks, you name it! Be prepared that (again, infantry squads are the worst offenders here) you have to babysit every unit all the time. Tanks and mechanized infantry alleviate this problem a little bit, but they still get stuck in unending chase-circles with engineers, or in slightly-too-narrow streets, for sure if you have a OKW in the team.
- Commanders, for sure good ones, are locked behind either a paywall (regular discounts though, but come on! The game is 11 years old) or a very _very_ long grind. This is not so good for those of us that played before, or just want to jump in for a few games with friends. This is based on the list on https://www.coh2.org/guides/33767/commander-tiers
- Expensive DLC, at time of writing E75,- for all DLC and an old game is on the expensive side for me
- Campaign just simply doesn't work, crashes in loading. The interwebs told me that it might be my GPU, or CPU, possibly that the hardware is just too modern. Fine, it's an old game, but why does skirmish work? And why can't I test that before buying? And why is there still no official solution except "we're working on it for the past 5 years"? I guess a lot of the devs moved to CoH3, but we all know how that went ;)

Again, the game performs very well in its niche, and it might just be _your_ cup of tea. I just don't think this one withstood the test of time.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happineass of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

The first [i]Company of Heroes[/i] managed to scratch my post-[i]Tiberium Wars[/i] RTS itch back when I first played it in 2008. Being set in World War II (the European theater, at least) was also unexpected for an RTS game of the time. [i]CoH[/i] was a great game and an improvement on the game mechanics pioneered by its predecessor, [i]Warhammer 40K: Dawn of War[/i]--already a good game in its own right.

But of course, [i]CoH[/i] still had some limitations with the old engine that necessitated development of a sequel, and with that said:


[b][i][u]Company of Heroes 2 - The Good, Bad and Ugly[/u][/i][/b]

[b]The Good:[/b]
[list]
[*]Improved game engine, game mechanics and physics.
[*]Mainly set on the Eastern Front with the Soviets and Wehrmacht Ostheer, but expansions with the Western Front factions were added later.
[*]Intel Bulletins (mini-buffs for your units) can only be bought with Supply (in-game currency) after the War Spoils 2.0 patch. No "pay-to-win" BS on that front. On that note...
[*]Duplicate items can be converted to Supply post-War Spoils 2.0.
[*]A vibrant and creative modding community that improves the game's replayability.
[/list]

[b]The Bad:[/b]
[list]
[*]Overly simplified User Interface. Gone are the ping buttons for "Defend Here" and "Capture Here" from [i]CoH 1[/i], which would have been more useful for team games without voice chat apps like Discord. It would have been better to have 5 buttons: "Attack Here", "Defend Here", "Capture Here", "Reinforce Here" and "Repair Here". Even the [i]CoH 1[/i] AI would understand those simple commands, but see below...
[*]Standard and Easy ally AI can be...frustratingly stupid, especially when playing vanilla. Not helped with the multiple updates to commanders and gameplay mechanics, but not the skirmish ally AI using said commanders.
[*]Grinding for Supply can be tedious. Mods make it a little bearable, but are subject to a daily limit. Need more? You have to play three more vanilla games (see above).
[*]No visible indicator(s) whether you're connected to Relic's game servers or not. It's downright frustrating when you've won a long match only to see a "You have been disconnected" message on the result screen and no Loot Points are granted. (One of the dark sides of a "live service" game, besides direct server outages.)
[*]Modders (apparently) don't have access to the full suite of modding/developer tools that allow the creation of custom vehicle and infantry models. (So for now, no Jagdpanthers, Wirbelwinds, Hummels, AT half-tracks, Sherman Crocodiles, or even an Imperial Japanese Army/Afrika Korps faction with theater-specific units.)
[/list]

[b]The Ugly:[/b]
[list]
[*]In-game store. While most of the items are cosmetic (vehicle skins, faceplates), the Commanders that aren't available with the base package do have a tinge of "pay-to-win" to them.
[*]Fox Company Rangers (DLC for the [i]Ardennes Assault[/i] expansion), isn't displayed on the store page for the game and you have to manually search for it on Steam.
[/list]

[b][i]The Verdict:[/i][/b]
- [i]Company of Heroes 2[/i] - Still a decent RTS game despite leaning toward the "live service" model. It's still possible to get some in-game store items through daily grinding for Supply, though you'll really work for it especially if you're just doing comp-stomp matches solo*. Single-player campaign (both in the main game and [i]Ardennes Assault[/i]) is also pretty good with a decent enough story and worth a replay once you master the strengths and weaknesses of various units in skirmish. Definitely love the game's modding community as well, from mods that overhaul some of the base game's mechanics/limits, to amusing custom faceplates of military moe anime characters (though only in custom games).

However, this game could have been a damn lot better (and get a better score) if the devs made the CPU teammate AI more responsive, improved the variety of ping buttons in the UI, and gave modders the full set of developer tools to make even better mods. (Hell, Relic might even find the newest dev team member from those modders.)

Sadly, it's been seven years (and counting) since the game's release and all that may be left of the game's dev team are a skeleton crew who are more concerned with game balancing, expanding to the mobile game market and auto-censoring swear words in the in-game chat (despite in-game units openly swearing).

Update: [i]Company of Heroes 3[/i] has been released and yet some of the problems in [i]Company of Heroes 2[/i] still have yet to be fixed, especially the "dumb as bricks" ally AI in vanilla skirmish games and the "minimum viable" mod support (some of those mods being able to improve ally AI behavior even just a bit, if not make the game more fun). Oh, and add that update where you can no longer see a red silhouette of a defensive structure when placed over unsuitable terrain (in order to adjust the facing/orientation as needed).

[b][i]3.5/5 stars.[/i][/b]

[b](*Note: I'm mainly a "play-to-relax"/"play to get away from people" kind of guy and limit my online co-op play to friends I personally know.)[/b]

Often described as [i]Hank Scorpio[/i] or [i]Terrifying[/i].

Alas, it's a great WWII RTS. It's got a lot going for it:
[list]
    [*] good graphics, especially for it's age. 
    [*] It's got mod support (never did manage it personally) and a map builder (I've made a handful).
    [*] Low Requirements (It is from 2013!)
    [*] Not too buggy (I mean, it's got bugs, but they don't completely ruin it)
    [*] Can be hilarious, and can be downright horrifyingly difficult...
    [*] Plenty of vehicles, troops and commander-based bonus units and abilities.
    [*] Seen by many as better than CoH3. I've not played much of the third due to it's pricetag; subject to later update.
[/list]
It does have some downsides, but they're not that bad.
[list]
    [*] You have to buy most of the armies as DLCs.
    [*] There are definitely some bugs.
    [*] Personally I find the AI to be either stupidly easy or stupidly hard.
    [*] There's a troop cap.... smh. (It can be removed by modding) But it does make sense, due it's slightly more microfocused nature.
[/list]

I've played many other RTS games, like Age of Empires 3 and 2, but I really like COH2's emphasis on combat rather than resource gathering.

This game is one of the games of all time. Personally, I really enjoy the game. The nearly 500 hours I have at the time of this review should make that clear. The game may not be extremely realistic with infantry being able to survive 5 shots without dying, or Panzer IVs being able to withstand a 7.6cm F-34 cannon from a T-34 with the front armour, but it does place you in the commander's seat fairly well. You need to either pick a doctrine early to catch your enemy off-guard, or wait for them to pick their doctrine allowing you to counter effectively. You need to manage resources of manpower, munitions and fuel to make sure you can replace losses and build up offensive breakthrough forces or defensive fortified forces. You need to know what your army is capable of and what your enemy can use from their army to counter; such as the Soviets being more infantry focused, while the British are more about "capture and hold" strategy. The Americans are versatile and the OKW are likewise. The Wehrmacht are arguably also versatile, but in my experience, they are more tank orientated. Doctrines are used to give you an edge in specific fields such as ambush tactics, elite infantry, heavy tanks and artillery. The doctrine you pick can either hyper-focus on what your army is already capable of (e.g. Soviets with elite Guards infantry), or it can be used to fill gaps in where your army lacks (e.g. Soviets with IS-2s and T-34/85s). The community has also made some great mods with my personally picks being the Wikinger mod and the Spearhead mod. These mods aim to make the game more immersive and realistic.

Overall, I like this somewhat old RTS. The CoH series is one of my favourite series ever, and this game may just be my favourite of the three current CoH games. Even with all of this said, do keep this in mind:
Experiences in game may and will vary. Form your own opinion by experiencing the gameplay yourself. If you don't like the RTS genre, this game is clearly not for you.

This is a very well-made, relatively balanced WW2 RTS if there ever was one. I would only fault this game for having certain factions/content locked behind a lot of DLC but compared to the garbage cash-grab that is CO3, its practically a blessing Relic only went that low. 

The style of the factions is demonstrated through a great variety of units whose hammy dialogue and diverse weapons define their role in combat. In the base game, you get the Wehrmacht and the Soviets, who play pretty much how you'd expect. While the Germans outclass the soviets in quality, a good player who keeps their veterans alive and knows how to flank can turn the tide and create a completely unstoppable juggernaut, a play style very reminiscent of the actual historical events. 

Overall the campaign is pretty good.  Apparently Russians got really salty when this game came out for depicting a Soviet protagonist who was morally disillusioned because he was... serving under a vicious totalitarian regime? Really my only issue with the campaign is that the Germans seem to be remarkably absent (aside from an offhand mention of Majdanek) from being depicted of doing the whole war crimes thing while the Soviets (accurately) commit plenty. I guess Relic didn't want to offend their German audience or something.

The game is very fun and the community builds are fantastic, but it is plagued with bugs (even with a clean install and no mods) that range from inconvenient to outright experience destroying. The former, for example, including silly pathfinding or absent-minded CPU units. In the latter cases, the save game feature can become disabled and crashes are frequent if you pause the game and get up to do something, with no auto recovery features that are common enough in dinosaur era RTS games. So in summary? Very fun and sometimes very frustrating.

This game was released in 2013. My brother had the previous game and I was anxious about it. Not everything in WW II, if you are lovers of history, was Saving Private Ryan or Enemy at the Gates or Dunkirk. There were a huge variety and diversity of uniforms. In some occasions during the war, the infantry did not carry their bagpacks, sometimes they did. Tanks also used camouflage. Which they did not have in the game but still it was so nice.
                       Order 227 was there for Stalingrad and the scenery was realistic. Some of them did not even get weapons and millions of them died. But only a small part of them were shot during retreat by their commissars. The sniper mission was my favourite. So much better than Call of Duty 2. And the shooting of another people caused much controversy. 
    V The US, British and Soviet and German armies were equally strong. You need to have the right mix, right units, right strategy, right combat cover and right adaptation of environment. Germans had the best tanks such as Pz . III, IV, V, VI and Tigers I and II (Konigstiger) along with destroyers like Jagdpanther and Jagdtiger, but they were matched by the others. In late phase, the Pershing, advanced Shermans  and T-34s, Churchill, KV 1 and 2,  Comet, Cruiser and Matilda along with IS 2 bested the German ones. 
                The variety of infantry - Riflemen, Rangers, Volks, Obers, Conscripts, Engineers, Pioneers, Medics, Grens, Pgrens, Sturmpioneers, 88s were real units in WW 2. The Air Support, Medics, Ambulance, Heal, Camouflage, Different abilities along with maps are also a great work by the developer.Thanks to Relic for staying true to the core of WW 2 without much deviation. Also, it would be nice to include the Italian and Japanese fronts as well.

Company of Heroes 2, developed by Relic Entertainment, is a highly acclaimed real-time strategy (RTS) game that immerses players in the brutal and unforgiving Eastern Front of World War II. Released in 2013, the game builds upon the success of its predecessor, offering a gripping and tactical experience that captures the essence of the war. In this review, we'll explore the key elements that make Company of Heroes 2 a standout title in the RTS genre.

Authentic and Immersive Setting:
Company of Heroes 2 transports players to the Eastern Front, where they take command of Soviet forces and engage in intense battles against the formidable German war machine. The game's attention to historical accuracy, from the detailed environments and authentic unit designs to the immersive audio, creates a realistic and immersive World War II experience.

Deep and Challenging Gameplay:
The gameplay in Company of Heroes 2 is deep, strategic, and highly rewarding. Players must carefully manage resources, deploy and maneuver squads, and utilize cover and terrain to outmaneuver and outwit their opponents. The game's emphasis on tactical decision-making and unit preservation adds depth and complexity to the gameplay, requiring players to think strategically and adapt to changing battlefield conditions.

Dynamic and Destructible Environments:
One of the standout features of Company of Heroes 2 is its dynamic and destructible environments. Buildings can be destroyed, cover can be obliterated, and the weather conditions can impact gameplay, adding a layer of realism and tactical depth. This level of environmental interaction creates a dynamic and ever-changing battlefield that keeps players engaged and on their toes.

Compelling Single-Player Campaign:
The game's single-player campaign offers a captivating narrative that follows the Soviet Red Army's struggle against the German forces. The campaign is well-paced, featuring memorable characters and a series of challenging and diverse missions. The storyline effectively captures the harsh realities of the Eastern Front and provides a sense of immersion and emotional investment.

Competitive Multiplayer:
Company of Heroes 2 offers a robust and competitive multiplayer experience. Players can engage in intense online battles, testing their skills and strategies against opponents from around the world. The multiplayer mode features a progression system, allowing players to unlock new units and abilities as they gain experience. The strategic depth and teamwork required in multiplayer matches make for exhilarating and rewarding gameplay.

Stunning Visuals and Immersive Audio:
Company of Heroes 2 boasts impressive visuals that bring the war-torn Eastern Front to life. The detailed landscapes, realistic unit animations, and visual effects create a visually stunning and immersive experience. The game's audio design, including the powerful sound effects and authentic voice acting, further enhances the immersion, adding to the intensity and realism of the battlefield.

Conclusion:
Company of Heroes 2 stands as a remarkable RTS game that offers a gripping and tactical World War II experience. With its authentic setting, deep gameplay mechanics, compelling single-player campaign, competitive multiplayer, and stunning visuals, the game successfully captures the brutal nature of the Eastern Front. Whether you're a fan of the RTS genre or a history enthusiast, Company of Heroes 2 delivers an immersive and rewarding experience that will keep you engaged for hours on end. Prepare to command your troops, make strategic decisions, and experience the epic battles of World War II in this standout title.

Certain units/features can be overpowered for different factions. Which taints the overall experience. German armor gets spammed to a certain point where it's entirely impossible to break their defense. Certain German tanks such as the KonigsTiger which can really cost an allied victory. None of the Allied heavy tanks can really counter it pragmatically, because it's always supported with something else. German tanks in general are tough nuts to crack, because any of its counter parts on the opposite team just don't come to par Allied/Soviet. Especially the Soviets not really having anything to counter the German Tank spam. 

Most of the Soviet Commander abilities don't mean jack lickity squat. Because due to the flares on the ground, the German players see them, and they simply pull their tanks backwards. And once the Soviet air raid is over, they push them back into the same place. The Soviet Tank destroyers can't really punch a hole against the spam, because they're range, accuracy, damage isn't on par with the German and easily are taken out. So, it gets to the point where almost every game end in a German victory because of the tank spam. This is the main issue with the game, is that German players can exploit this in-game bias and win every match easily. The only time, Germans ever lose is if the players on the German side are simply not as good skillfully as the Allied/Soviet players. But once the German side are aware of the bias and tank spam exploit, they instantly win the game. Which can really taint the experience. 

The Story mode is great, and the Theater of War is fun. For an older game, it's still a lot of fun to play. I've sank over 200+ hours into it. Just be aware before you buy, that the game can get really frustrating really quickly, especially when the opposite side abuses tank spam exploit. Artillery spam exploit can be really difficult to counter too. The game is a great arcade strategy game, but like I said can be really frustrating so make sure to look up some Youtube Soviet/German Builds before going into the multiplayer. And just understand some of the exploits and abuses you will encounter in the games multiplayer.

I'm not a big FPS fan, but I love strategy.  This is the best (and most realistic) strategy war game I have ever played. The graphics are great. The sound is wonderful. The play is smooth and cohesive.  I have spent many hours playing this game and am not tired of it at all. Every game is unique.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This game is such a fun and unique RTS and one that improves upon the original title in most ways. The main focus of the campaign(s) is on the Soviets during WW2 and their own history against the Germans but I find (as most do) that online/skirmish is where it's at. You have 5 playable nations/armies some of which have up to twenty two individual commanders so the amount of combination and replay-ability is vast. However some commanders are DLC that need to be purchased separately and the only way to do that is to type "COH2" into the Steam Search Bar to see all of the commanders as they do not appear as DLC in the store pages "content for this game" which is very odd. 

The main improvements over the first game are as follows:

Proper line of sight - If enemy units are on the other side of a wall/building/tree/bush you can't see them. The POV has to be clear from the perspective of the soliders. I think relic was calling this "True Sight" and as such ambushes are now easier to pull off and makes the game feel more realistic and fun overall. 

Population is no longer tied to how many capture points you control. This gives the player with less territory more of a chance to fight back. 

Soliders no longer have to actively "take" the control point as an action rather they just have to be standing within its territory giving you the ability to fight back. 

Snow/Blizzzards/Ice - Your vehicles can slow and stall, your tanks can fall through the ice, your soldiers can freeze to death, your line of sight is horrendous. All of this is fun, and all of this introduces many new elements of gameplay. You may have to pullback your soliders and wait out a blizzard or reroute your tank pathing on an ambush. And the great thing is you can turn this on/off at any time and it's highly welcomed. 

Graphically it looks very similar to the first other than the terrain being much improved as a whole this time around. 

Those are the biggest things off the top of my head. COH1 and 2 play mostly the same and as such I think both are phenomenal RTS titles that hold up well to this day.

This game HATES YOU! DON'T BUY IT!

It hates you when you are:

A Russian: BECAUSE
1. the campaign displays them as moraly questionable (would be fine if american campaign would be the same but it isn't.)
2. And weak without general winter fighting for them.

B You are a new Player: BECAUSE
- People will constantly remind  you; play bad, you are a noob or easy game for them.

C: You want to play allied armies in multiplayer: BECAUSE 
- If you search for a game you will see 25 - 40 % players searching to play allies and 60 - 75 % of players searching to play Axis. And this at any given moment you try to play.
This tells you all about the balance in this game!

D:PAK43 placements can be placed behind buildings. They shoot through bildings without destroying it and can't be seen or shot directly. By the way PAK43 is the strongest AT Gun in the game. 

E: German tanks bounce shots 1-3 times before they die. They have a health bar of 0 and still manage to get away because of that. This is tested. The German tank has actually 0 health. You need to shoot it beyond 0 to kill it.

F:The discharge smoke ability on german tanks conceals the tank when it retreats but that smoke doesnt bother other german units. They can see right through it. Allies cant see anything and they dont even have the ability to discharge smoke grenades on their tanks 

G: By contrast, the russian t34 tanks can RAM-Attack a tank. The attacked tank suffers a movement penalty for 3-4 seconds and a little bit damage. The T34 can't move or fire after that attack. Its a sitting duck.

Good things:

+ nice grafics
+ nice sound
+ a view new features over COH 1 (infantry can vault over fences, blizzards in winter, some new units) 

VERDICT:
If you ever got married and you divorce your wife that truely loved you but wasn't perfect and you marry again a woman that looks perfect but hates you, then you know how it feels to play company of heroes one for years then moving on to this one. 

If you get the woman that hates you in the first place. I tell you a secret son.

Still one of the best RTS out there. Cinematic and tactical warfare that emphasis field strategy instead of turtling. Which is a problem I have when playing with a few friends in my steam list in this game. 

See here, these things that I play with sometimes have it ingrained in themselves that the only way they can win is if they turtle up all the way, without building one single unit, without ever leaving their base until they unlock tiger tanks or whatever late game tech in the Annihilation game mode while the other dudes in the team soak up all the damage. These kinds of matches last for 2 hours and it's infuriating AF to be a part of.  It's disgusting. It's f***** gross. They killed the fun of this game themselves simply by playing like a disabled grandma in her retirement home. And lola would have been able to grasp the concept that the game gets a whole lot more fun when you're playing the capture points mode instead of being a gaddam gardener in base in annihilation mode camping bridges to prevent the enemy from crossing 2 hours into the game. It's insane I don't know how I put up with it. The worst part is that there is celebration when the match is over after the equivalent of preparing and eating an entire family meal with a cigarette and dessert after. It wasn't fun to play these kinds of matches. But this game is fun if you just stop playing like a lawnmower and actually get to capturing points and getting into the action. wtf. The worst part is that almost every RTS that we play together boils down to this kind of gameplay of waiting on government welfare to bail you out of your shoit teenage year decisions for the next 20 years and then showing up to the friends party where most people have forgotten about your existence, showing up with a bagfull of weed claiming that you "made it".  Matches should last below the 40 minute mark I honestly don't know why this happens with them. It is atrocious how these decisions come to a conclusion. The AI is fine, some of the best and fairest in any RTS. HAY.

That said, I'm looking to play COH2 again with anybody because it's a nicely balanced RTS set during WW2 that has community maps, that has multiple fantastic campaigns, that is more complete than COH3 currently and is nicely balanced between all the available factions and units available.

Furthermore doesn't even have Anti Cheat or any system to detect cheaters for gaming online. Now I know why I haven't played in over 2 years. Joined a game whereby one of our allies asked us in chat that he's going to turn Fog of War off for us on map and we thought he was messing around but said yes to play along with his joke. What happened??? No joke. The whole map could be seen and allowed us to see everything. This is when I knew I'll never play online again with this game.

Company of Heroes 2 is a real-time strategy game set during World War II. Released in 2013, it received positive reviews from both critics and players. The game offers immersive tactical gameplay, an intense single-player campaign, and engaging multiplayer modes. It is praised for its realistic graphics, detailed environments, and strategic depth. However, some criticized its steep learning curve and the controversial portrayal of the Eastern Front. Overall, if you enjoy strategy games and the World War II setting, Company of Heroes 2 is worth considering.

[h1] The Train Simulator of RTS games, but still enjoyable[/h1]

COH2 is really, really good. The gameplay is intense, refined, and immersive. The sound design is absolutely fantastic, artillery sounds like hellfire, panzerwerfers sound heroic(but less intense from coh1 blitzkrieg) and overall balance is alright. Each of the four factions are unique and have their own playstyle, and have unique quirks and gimmicks that can be used against your opponents. Though, the fact that pretty much all unique and cool commanders are locked and you have to fork over either 3$ per each, and then having to pay even more for the 3 non included factions is peak train simulator DLC bargaining. 

Ignoring the scummy DLC policy, the game itself is amazing. If you do wish to buy it, just wait for a major sale so you can obtain pretty much all the commanders for around 20$ rather than 100$ something extra.
It is basically a video game that makes you suffer where you need to stay calm while your tank misses the third shot in a row against the enemy tank.
Best game ever. Fun and great community with a lot of banter. It's quite old, but not dated.

The game is very realistic. VERY AMUSING and VERY FUN TO PLAY.
Hope to play more Company of Heroes Series to developed later.

Thank you so much to Relic Entertainment, SEGA and to the Steam Community for the very wonderful experience they provide for the games. Also thanks to Mr. Quinn Duffy of the Company of Heroes development for the very wonderful game.

Editing this review, old review will be after here, take it as the impressions of a player a little past noob era:

As someone who's fairly decent at this game, (in-game ELO is 13 with soviets)

It's really good, it has a few flaws, but it is THE squad based RTS. Every unit is distinct (looking at you total war), the game's built on extreme hard counters, blobs get punished by any decent player. Sound design and visual design is also top notch, not just from immersion perspective, but also so you always know what's going on. Every unit has a distinct icon, and voice actor for example. Micro is everything here, but it's not just a clickfest. In terms of problems, there's close to none, but the servers aren't great, the community is (mostly) a cesspool, and relic won't bother to fix the few bugs left. Other than that, it's really great. I have a few comments on faction design I could make, but I won't.

Add me if you want to play coh, I need more people, I must collect all the time-zones!

9.7/10, game gud, cheap on sale

old review:

OH GOD THE MUSIC IS SO GOOD

With that out of the way...

Visuals: 9/10

The game is almost a decade old at this point, but still looks great. I feel completely immersed, and the Graphics feel perfectly fine. Explosions, animations, etc, all beautiful. The UI is fairly intuitive, and gets the point across well. Units close up, look worse than any modern total war game, but they still look fine. The cutscenes, however show off how pixelated the uniforms are, and take me out of the immersion.

Campaign:

7/10

Story is barely stringed along with very short cutscenes, doesn't feel like anything special. It's decent when you're stuck without internet, but multiplayer is very much superior.

Multiplayer:

10/10

This game defines RTS for a reason. The factions are well balanced. The skill ceiling is high as hell, and it runs really well. Multiplayer is seamless, and the shining point of the game.

Controls:

10/10

Feels nice and comfortable. You'll grasp the controls after the first hour. Nothing feels janky, all smooth.

Music:

ALLTHEDAMNNUMBERS/10

So good, if you don't buy the game, just listen to it on youtube, so emotional and epic. So perfect for this game.

Microtransactions:

5/10

So much stuff you can buy, but so much grind to get them.
You get a drop every 6000k points
Lose = 1500 pts
Win = 2000 pts
You might get a unit perk, or a skin, or 500 supply
You can buy
Commanders, which will let you spawn special units, or use special abilities
Unit Perks
Unit Skins
And other misc stuff
Everything costs extreme amounts of supply, or small amounts of real cash. Prices are fairly reasonable, but microtransactions are still evil...
Even with just stock items, you can still dominate, and store-bought stuff isn't an improvement, just a slightly different playstyle.

Final score:

9/10

Company of Heroes 2: A Solid WW2 RTS Experience

Company of Heroes 2 is a fantastic World War II real-time strategy game that has provided me with countless hours of fun, whether I'm battling friends or facing off against AI opponents. It captures the essence of WW2-era warfare remarkably well.

One of the minor drawbacks is the substantial amount of paid content, which can be a bit frustrating. However, in the world of gaming, it's not uncommon to encounter such practices.

Graphically, the game could be improved, but I can't complain too much. Most of the vehicles and units look pretty decent, and the overall visual experience gets the job done.

I was fortunate to grab it when it was free, as I wouldn't necessarily recommend paying the full price. My advice is to wait for a special offer and watch some videos to ensure it's the right game for you.

Overall, I'd rate Company of Heroes 2 a 6.5/10. It's a solid WW2 RTS experience that offers plenty of strategic thrills. And there's something oddly satisfying about surrounding the German army with tanks and watching them crumble, time and time again. :3

Company of Heroes 2 is a fantastic real-time strategy game that offers players an immersive and challenging World War II experience. Here's what I think about it:

A Strategic Gem:
Company of Heroes 2 excels in almost every aspect of a real-time strategy game. Its mechanics are finely tuned, and it provides a genuinely immersive World War II atmosphere. The gameplay is engaging and will satisfy even the most demanding strategy enthusiasts.

Room for Improvement:
Despite its many strengths, Company of Heroes 2 does have a few drawbacks. Additional maps and the introduction of new factions, such as Italy or France, would bring fresh diversity to the game. One noticeable issue is the perceived overpowered nature of Soviet Katyushas, which may require some balancing adjustments.

Overall Enjoyment:
Overall, Company of Heroes 2 offers an exceptional gaming experience that shouldn't be missed by fans of the genre. Its compelling mechanics and captivating historical context make it a must-play for strategy enthusiasts.

In conclusion, Company of Heroes 2 stands out as an outstanding real-time strategy game. While it has a couple of areas that could benefit from refinement, it remains a thrilling and challenging journey through the battlefields of World War II. Whether you're a history buff or a strategy aficionado, this game is well worth your time.
Overall: 6/10.

While I didn't get the same charm of COH1, this sequel definitely scratches the itch in terms of the great gameplay you remember. But I didn't get bang for my buck here. I can't help but compare it to Men of War Assault Squad 2 which had a lot more content without reminding you 'Hey, we have an ingame store. Come buy tank skins'. 

Things I Like: 
+ Visual improvement over the last game. 
+ The same great gameplay as the previous, but with some improvements
+ There are some earnable unlockables but they're kinda shit. Stuff like nameplates and stat boosts and tank skins. 
+ The campaign mode is my favourite. Take territories, get bonuses for your company and keep people alive as to not wear your company to death. Some genuinely fun missions too
+ The workshop mods. New maps. New units. New ways to play. New...ugh tank skins. And achievements aren't disabled using them. 
I recommend Infantry Emphasis mods, the All Units mod (which allows you to get previously bugged achievements because the devs removed certain units ffs), General Utility Game Mode to remove the cheating AI and Zombies. 
 
Things I Dislike: 
- Uninstalling the game opens a tab in your browser for a fucking survey
- Only 2 factions without DLC. 
- I bought the USA DLC to play the campaign and it asked me to pick 3 commanders out of 4 choices. One of those choices was ANOTHER DLC. WTF. 
- That mode I said I like? Only playable as Russia and the USA DLC. They'd rather release microtransaction tank skins than increase the bang for your buck with Faction DLC. And also the first mission is the same everytime, it effects your company's health and it's unskippable. 
- Rank up / XP / Loot drops are throttled because you don't get XP based on units defeated or things built like Starcraft, you only get XP for match finished and wins. So if you're going for XP and unlocks, there's no incentive to play longer or harder games. 
- The AI cheats. You could take all the resource points on the map and they'd still churn two tanks out for no apparent reason. An attempt to make matches against AI more interesting done in the cheapest way possible. I don't want to play against Players. And now I don't want to play AI higher than Easy. 
- The grind for unlocks is a little too much for what you actually unlock imo. You need 3 wins to unlock a random lootbox. Easiest way is to play Easy AI on a custom map 3 times but even putting in that little effort is asking too much. 
- Even now the game still has it's glitches. Physics freaking out. Things not unlocking after a long campaign. 
- Only 40% of people have finished the first main campaign mission. They knew we didn't want to play as the Soviets. So they dropped that USA DLC for the extra $$$
- Can't change keybinds and it uses Arrow Keys instead of WASD like a very early 2000's FPS game lol. 
- Rewards for completing campaigns are abysmal. Guess what it is? TANK SKINS AGAIN

I have been a fan of the Company of Heroes series since its release in 2006, and I was excited to try out Company of Heroes 2. Unfortunately, COH2 never lived up to the acclaimed original. Despite this, the game still provides plenty of entertainment for strategy and history fans. The story is deep and engaging, and the tactical combat is still enjoyable. The modding community has also created a wealth of content for the game, which adds to the replayability. All in all, Company of Heroes 2 is still a great game, but it is starting to show its age. If you are a fan of the series, then you will still find plenty to enjoy in Company of Heroes 2. However, if you are looking for a more modern experience, then you may want to look elsewhere.

Something kin to the sick awful feeling you got in your stomach the moment you realized what's inside Mike Pence is exactly what's on his face.

Company of Heroes 2, developed by Relic Entertainment, stands as a compelling and nuanced take on the real-time strategy genre. Set against the brutal backdrop of World War II, the game combines deep strategic gameplay, engaging storytelling, and impressive visuals to create a memorable experience.

The heart of Company of Heroes 2 lies in its tactical gameplay. Every decision, from unit positioning to resource management, plays a significant role in determining victory or defeat. The game encourages you to think strategically, to take advantage of the terrain, weather, and the unique abilities of your units. This tactical depth keeps the gameplay engaging and rewarding, providing a great challenge for strategy enthusiasts.

Company of Heroes 2 stands out for its realistic portrayal of the harsh conditions of World War II. The weather system, for instance, is not just a cosmetic feature. Severe cold can freeze your troops, blizzards can reduce visibility, and bodies of water can become deadly traps when the ice breaks, adding another layer to the game's strategic depth.

The game's campaign is noteworthy as well. Told from the perspective of the Soviet Red Army, it offers a gripping and sometimes harrowing narrative. The voice acting and cutscenes are of high quality, immersing you in the story and the bleak realities of the Eastern Front.

Visually, Company of Heroes 2 impresses with its detailed environments and unit models. The destructible environments add a dynamic element to battles, and watching a well-planned assault unfold is satisfying. The sound design, too, enhances the overall experience, with the sounds of gunfire, explosions, and soldier chatter contributing to the immersive wartime atmosphere.

However, the game does have a few shortcomings. The AI can sometimes feel unbalanced, with difficulty spikes that might frustrate some players. Furthermore, while the campaign's storytelling is engaging, its portrayal of certain historical events has been a topic of controversy.

The multiplayer mode is a strong point of the game, offering competitive and cooperative gameplay that can keep you engaged for hours. It's here, playing against or with friends, where the game's strategic depth truly shines.

In conclusion, Company of Heroes 2 is a robust and engaging real-time strategy game. Despite some minor flaws, it offers a deep and rewarding tactical experience, a captivating campaign, and an enjoyable multiplayer mode. For fans of the genre or those interested in WWII history, Company of Heroes 2 is an adventure well worth undertaking.

Campaigns are not fun at all. The game disables production of units but the enemy is able to swarm and reproduce. Not very well thought out. In turn you're not able to carry out your strategy and its overly frustrating when your unit is KIA and cant be used further in the game.

Honestly at this point they've smoothed a lot of the microtransactions out and made the gameplay fairly solid, but I still refunded it. The reason why? I absolutely could not get through the very first few campaign missions without cringing to death.

Company of Heroes 1 told a fairly grounded story, very Saving Private Ryan at times and dramatic for sure but always grounded in actual World War 2 stories.

In 2 they seemed to have hired a writing staff who mysteriously immigrated from Europe to Argentina in the late 40's because boy is it bad. We open with the classic 'the Soviet army had no guns' myth as a soldier tells his superior officer that he has no rifle to use but is told to keep marching or be shot. This is framed by our narrator, a Soviet veteran looking back on his time in the war, grimly describing the famous 'no step back' order 227. Of course like most western descriptions of it, it ignores that this order mainly was focused on OFFICERS to prevent them from surrendering their entire company without approval and was not in fact the evil commissars eager to shoot any private who takes a step backwards.

We then are treated to a montage of literally endless Soviet troops charging machine guns, ordered forward by their evil officers who don't care for their lives at all and too dumb to do anything but mindlessly run into a hail of bullets. This backdrop literally lasts the entire mission, just an endless line of Soviet soldiers charging established machine gun nests as your squad is the only one who seems to know they can go around the static encampments.

Again we get our narrator, so remorseful about the horrors of Soviet war, grimly saying that they went too far, were too cruel, in this battle that ends with a lone, helpless, surrendering nazi soldier getting coldly exicuted by the same evil Soviet officers. The poor guy, really makes you wonder who the real victims in this war were.

Of course you may have a harder time wondering that when you know that the tutorial battle full of 'meaningless death' and Soviet cruelty to the poor innocent nazis was STALINGRAD and these were, you know, literal invading nazis. So to recap, a Soviet soldier laments how mean he and his men were to the INVADING NAZI FORCES AT STALINGRAD, and that's our introduction!

Then mission two had me use flamethrowers to burn Russian civilians inside their homes and fire bombs to set my own Soviet soldiers on fire just to deny the nazis...something? It's not really clear why the people who could just leave their homes or positions before the invading nazi army arrived had to be burned alive horrifically but the Soviet officer who orders it is sure to laugh like a cartoon villain as he orders it.

It was then I decided to refund this game, before I assume mission three would have a prolonged scene where the poor remorseful Soviet veteran looks at the camera and says 'and you know did the holocaust really even happen? Who's to say' or whatever other outright nazi propaganda Relic managed to get in here.

While this game is fairly replayable, and doesn't feel as personality-less as CoH3 can feel like at times, it doesn't quite recreate the same solid magic the first game did. There are still balance issues after all these years, and the developers suffered from the historical overestimation of the German armed forces that many did, buffing units that don't make sense (looking at you flame halftrack). I don't think I'd accuse them of being Wehraboos, but they definitely saw them much better than the historical record really shows.

I decided to come back to this game after a number of years and I immediately regretted it and remembered why I shelved it.

The game is terrible.  Anyone who thinks this is anywhere close to an accurate or even reasonable representation of combat in World War II has zero understanding of military history or strategy.  This plays more like a bad Starcraft clone with a WWII skin than an actual war game set in the second world war.  For example, you can often just run a squad past an enemy in cover with few or zero losses, flank them and kill them so everything just descends into ridiculous unrealistic running battles.

The models don't really reflect the appearance of troops or equipment from the period either, looking chunky and far too colourful and frankly there are much older WWII strategy games that more accurately capture the feel and aesthetics of the period.

Multiplayer is also terrible, not a good community and ultimately not very enjoyable.  Poorly thought out game mechanics that manage to be unoriginal and yet also somehow poorly implemented make for a dull experience that does not capture the essence of combat or strategy in World War II anymore than the single player experience does.

Dull, Uninspired and profoundly unrealistic to a ridiculous degree.  The creators of this clearly have zero understanding of the period in which it is set.

For the veteran players who just want to know if it‚Äôs still worth it to play coh2 even after the coh3 launch, the answer is yes, the game was almost not affected, it just decreased a little the amount of players but even that still has more players than coh3.

For the people who are new on RTS or coh franchise and want to start now by coh2, I need to warn that this game is very complicate and has annoying features like an aggressive supply system, stability problem and crash, so, you will need to have a lot of patient and love this game to not give up, also you are late for the party so you will suffer a little with the experienced players.

About the supply drop system, to be short you will need to pass over a lot of useless things like skins and bulletins until you start to get coins often and you will have to accumulate a lot of coins to buy commanders that it‚Äôs the only thing interesting and make some difference in gameplay.

About the stability problem, the game might get unstable after one or a few matches and that increases the probability of crashing, to avoid it you can reset the game after every match and I highly recommend that if you are playing on a laptop. Speaking of laptops the game is not more so light for this devices after the 64 bits update, I have an average laptop and during the 32 bits I played 4v4 without problems, but after that update my laptop suffer in 3v3 on late game and 4v4 run in low frames and in the late game tend to crash.

To finish and be fair this game has well-make features like the combat of the units where the weapon, type of cover, angle of each soldier in the squad make difference, the sounds, the voices and lines of the characters, the environment destruction, the high detail in every infantry and vehicle and every battle is unique making the replayable infinite.
