I promised, in the discussions forum for this game, that I would review more properly when I had chalked up 100 hours, well, my initial review was at 104.2 hours and as someone pointed out that could not be properly considered adequate play time to form a complete and informed opinion. I now have over 1017 hours in game, both solo experimentation across the range of teams and strategies but also co-op and vs. with my brother overseas. Accordingly I am reviewing my review...

I've played solo vs. AI, Online vs. Person (my brother in Australia) He and I have played Team vs. AI single team and Team vs. AI Dual team. I've hit the Campaign trail in the Russian Campaign as the Russians. I have played all nations and both German service branches utilising, throughout it all, different Generals with different tactical specialisations and I have played across a wide range of maps both urban, rural and in between.

The first comment I would make about this game is that if you have ever played any of the Command and Conquer games ( I first played that at the beginning of '96 and my favourite was '99's "Tiberian Sun") then you've played this game... and, to be fair, a great many others like this.

Strategically the premise is basic and rather formulaic, no real surprise, you have to survive an initial onslaught ( don't know where they get their stuff so fast) Consolidate your middle game ( just like playing chess) then counter-offensive during the endgame. I have only lost 3 or 4 solo games to the A.I. since figuring that one out and that had as much to do with choice of side as with anything I did, or didn't do during the game.

Game mechanics - 7/10 - The actual "mechanics" of the game can't really be faulted though they do seem to be a little stilted in the early game when your A.I. "opponent" seems to be able to "tech up" and produce the hardware three times faster than you.

Game visuals - 8/10 - This is a very detailed and highly visual game. I read one industry review that described it as being "visceral", that is "Based on deep feeling and emotional reaction rather than reason or thought:" (Cambridge English dictionary) Ummmm... I think someone just wanted to play with big words, I certainly wouldn't call it that. Beautifully rendered, well presented and highly detailed yes, not er.... visceral.

Game Tech levels - 4/10 - This is my big beef and main criticism I would lay out. The "Tech Up" process seems rather clumsy and, in some respects, unnecessary. As with many games of this type the enjoyment factor, overall, is detracted from by having to micromanage funds and resources. Let's face it, field commanders during WW2 didn't have to worry about money, fuel and munitions, that was for the High Command and Supply Corps to worry about (I know all about supply chain, I was in the Army for a while and the key phrase was always "Hurry up and wait") I am definitely NOT a fan of "financial micromanagement" in wargames.

The other criticism, and the main one that I have for the game, is the ridiculously low "Population Cap" that keeps you operating with minimalistic resources throughout the game. This actually frustrates the player more than anything in my opinion. I cut my teeth playing the old SPI tabletop games (pre-computer) and the Camo Workshop/Shrapnel Games "Steel Panthers" series from 1995 ( originally on MS-DOS based systems) and the unit availability/reinforcement was determined pre-game start... you went into the game with your pre-selected army group and that is, repair and re-supply options notwithstanding, what you fought out the game with. in short, much more realistic. My advice now is to go to the modding hub and subscribe to a mod that gives you all units. This gives you the ability to up your pop cap anywhere between 125 and ( from memory) 500. There is also a mod that allows for Infantry only with light battlefield support vehicles and artillery. That gets very interesting if you like the whole idea of village street and urban combat scenarios.

Replayability - 6/10 - Once you've played around 60 hours or so the only thing that changes is the scenery, depending on which map you choose. The saving grace here, and I've given it another point, is the availability of game influencing mods through the modding hub.

Overall impression, if you like a beautifully rendered game, highly detailed with big beautiful explosions and injured men crawling away from a battle rather than the reality of what were very often protracted ground combat actions with both air and artillery support then you'll like this game.

My reaction, after more than one thousand seven hgundred hours, and losing count of the battles (although I do have one game going between the OKW and the British forces that's sitting at 7 hours and 29 minutes duration over several days - yes, you can stall the game...!) is that "It ain't the all, that's all"

Overall average score 7/10

After giving it more of a chance...my opinion, be it ever so humble as always.
Cheers,

I found the single player, scenario, skirmish versus AI, and DLC single player experience fun. Playing against AI with friends and using mods is pretty fun as well. Also, I really like the cover system and the responsiveness of units in this game. The online multiplayer is what I played most with friends and solo. It is why I primarily still play the game, but it is certainly not perfect. The game has gone through patches and improvements over a long period of time to get where it is now. It had a bad start on launch, but it is pretty good now. One of the most common issues people complain about in multiplayer is the balance, but it is in a pretty decent spot right now in my opinion. Compared to CoH3 at the time of writing, I feel like CoH2 is definitely ahead in many aspects such as polish, content, path, and player base. Also, CoH2 currently just look much more "realistic" than CoH3. There are many other things I could mention in comparison to CoH3, but I will stop there. Hopefully CoH3 will get patched and developed enough over time to surpass CoH2 in time.

[h1]My Review[/h1]
[b]When I played the original Company of Heroes, I had a hard time thinking how a WWII RTS game could look or play so much better than it does. Apparently, so has its developer, Relic, because seven years later, Company of Heroes 2 is strikingly similar. There are, of course, subtle visual improvements and numerous unpredictable gameplay tweaks as the series transitions from the western to the eastern front, but this is very much a new spin on the same game.[/b]

[b]Of course, the original CoH has held up remarkably well (if you haven't played it, you should), so I welcome something that looks and plays like it with open arms, even if it's not necessarily a better version.[/b]

[b]Because it's so similar to the original, Company of Heroes 2 is great for the same reasons. More than most RTS games, CoH is all about using clever tactical positioning to take advantage of cover and exploit weak tank armor. And because armies rarely have more than a dozen units at a time, it's relatively slower-paced and more methodical than a traditional RTS, though there's almost always something going on.[/b]

[b]Its territory-based resource system, now revised to allow you to influence which of the three resources generates a sustained point, allows for a playstyle that is almost entirely focused on tactics. I especially appreciate the ability to win a battle by attacking an enemy where they are not, instead of facing them head on.[/b]

Game is very unbalanced and the factions are poorly designed especially when looking at them from a historical role perspective. Some how Russia has the best armor and infantry selection in the game when they were known for high volume low quality. The game should have been balanced with casualty statistics in mind. T-34 was robust tank for sure, but when you look at their k/d they were rarely greater than 1. Also with a few hundred encounters documented between the T-34 vs the Sherman, the Sherman would win by a wide margin having about 2.5 k/d. Yet T-34 swarms all, accompanied by unstoppable conscripts and elite plebs. They could have easily fit the russian aesthetic and kept them viable by making all russian units weaker but also requiring less population space each. So you can still have swarming hoards but resemble the hoards of poorly equipped and poorly trained russian farmers.

this is my third review iv written on this game and I must say my thoughts have changed on certain aspects of the game. although I still do not recommend this game to the casual steam player, this game is really only for the most hardcore of RTG players. company of heroes is fast paced and slow paced at the same time. some moments have you in shock and aw moments of fighting for every inch of territory while making smart and informed decisions on how to command your troops which is rewarding win or lose scenarios. AANNNNDD other times your just getting shit on no matter what you do. I prefer to play the multiplayer because i feel the maps are too large for a one on one's. during my time playing multiplayer getting a good team is kind of like finding a unicorn in the middle of a tornado while balancing a ball on your nose. servers need to be dedicated too continents, too many players mixing together that dont even speak the language is very frustrating. (mostly talking about Japanese players) and when you do get ally's that can communicate most the time they dont know what they are doing. not too say thats their fault due to the lack of a meaningful tutorial and skill based matchmaking in the game. but all that could be overlooked if certain game mechanics were fixed. the biggest one of all being that the Germans are just stacked no matter how you look at. Im not a guy that likes to blame games saying certain things are over powered just so i can justify losing buuuuutttttttttt, the Germans have way to many units that are just way to effective or hard to kill or some of their abilities are straight up too powerful. Like the fragmentation barrage just lasts way to long while also dealing a lot of damage and suppressing infantry, and if you just leave your tanks in the middle it can still do a considerable amount of damage to them. and thats just one ability i dindt even mention the king tiger. iv seen matches where as soon as the Germans got a king tiger there was nothing the allies could do to even keep one point defended. iv seen a king tiger take on 3 american tanks 4 British tanks and a total 3 AT guns and still come out on top. to make a short story both german teams need some reworking in some of their ability and units, not say that playing as german can have its draw backs but most of the time if playing a German team your going to win. other things about the game can make your experience frustrating like constantly waiting for resources to build units or reinforce danged squads just for them to fight for 5 seconds before getting wrecked again even though the have upgraded weaponry and support from mortars and machine guns. which brings in another problem. MORTARS ARE TOO DAMN SLOW!!!!. before a mortar team can even become remotely useful is if they veteran 3 and by that time tanks and and whole hoards of infantry are storming the mortar position because the range on mortars are so close that by the time mortars get rounds down range the target is already on top of them. a complete overhaul of the mortar system is required. in conclusion if you are a hard core RTG player this game is probably for you but it may not but you are new to strategy games to do not play you will be raped.

Had this game pre-War Spoils and it was pretty fun for awhile, not to entertaining solo but with a friend things are more exciting even if you lose. The fact we can make maps and mod maps brings a new realm for the game to experience yet it is kind of weak. The gaming experience is loads different from COH 1 yet the developers are trying to keep this game THEIR game but keeping the community for creating mods and giving players a chance to explore more aspects of the game. I'm on the edge of recommending this game because the NEW War Spoils system limits your game play experience if you are one of those people who don't have hours on top of hours to play this game... Rewards are based on hours committed to playing this game, if you don't have the time to play then don't expect to get anything cool or special... Sooo yes, recommended because of the games potential, and No for those who can't devote their lives to Sega and Relic...


Edit  01/15/2023

This game has it's ups and downs. Without the mod support and community, this game would've died a long time ago.

Nothing really beats COH 1

COH 2 is so-so (okay)

The release of COH 3 I feel is going to be the death of the COH series. I don't think the developers or writers have a clue on how to stick to their roots and instead choose to monetize on vanity items and dlc's for game play.

I don't plan on wasting any money on COH 3 mainly because COH 2 was some what of a let down... I'm certain COH 3 will be a total flop...

I still recommend COH 1 and 2

EDIT 05/31/2023

762 hours later and I'm laughing at the COH 3 Store reviews... To be honest I uninstalled COH 2... Still play COH 1 but thats about it... I still do not plan to ever purchase COH 3 because it's a money grab, no interest in the player community except to get into your wallet...

Gameplay:
Company of Heroes 2 retains the core gameplay mechanics that made the original game a success while introducing new features that enhance the tactical depth. Players lead their forces as either the Soviet Red Army or the German Wehrmacht, engaging in dynamic and challenging battles across historically inspired campaigns and multiplayer modes. The game emphasizes resource management, unit preservation, and strategic decision-making, requiring players to adapt their tactics to the harsh conditions of the Eastern Front.

The game's innovative TrueSight system adds a layer of realism by simulating limited visibility and fog of war. Commanders must utilize cover, line-of-sight, and environmental factors to gain an advantage over their opponents. The inclusion of diverse unit types, such as infantry, tanks, artillery, and specialized squads, allows for a variety of strategic approaches, from overwhelming assaults to careful defensive maneuvers.

Graphics and Sound:
Company of Heroes 2 impresses with its detailed and visually stunning graphics. The environments, ranging from snowy landscapes to war-torn villages, exhibit a high level of authenticity and attention to detail. The game's physics engine produces realistic destruction and environmental effects, immersing players in the chaos of battle. The sound design is equally commendable, with powerful weapon sounds, explosive effects, and a fitting musical score that heightens the tension and atmosphere.

Multiplayer Experience:
The multiplayer component of Company of Heroes 2 provides intense and strategic battles against other players. The competitive multiplayer modes, including ranked matches and tournaments, offer a challenging experience for those seeking to test their strategic skills. Cooperative gameplay is also available, allowing players to team up with friends and face off against AI opponents or engage in epic multiplayer campaigns. The strong multiplayer community ensures a thriving player base and ongoing support for new content.

Campaigns and Narrative:
Company of Heroes 2 offers a rich and engaging single-player campaign that delves into the harsh realities of the Eastern Front. The narrative-driven missions present a compelling story, following the struggles and sacrifices of both the Soviet and German forces. The campaign showcases the human cost of war and provides historical context, immersing players in the gripping narrative of World War II.

Expansion Content:
Company of Heroes 2 features several expansion packs that introduce new campaigns, factions, and gameplay mechanics. These expansions expand the game's content and provide additional depth to the overall experience. Whether battling through the Ardennes in "The Western Front Armies" or taking part in the brutal Siege of Leningrad in "The Case Blue Mission Pack," the expansion content offers exciting new challenges and narratives.

Conclusion:
Company of Heroes 2 stands as a testament to the excellence of the franchise, delivering a gritty and authentic World War II strategy experience. With its engaging gameplay, impressive visuals, and immersive sound design, the game captures the brutality and complexity of the Eastern Front conflict. Whether playing through the captivating campaigns or engaging in intense multiplayer battles, Company of Heroes 2 offers an unforgettable journey through one of history's most significant periods. For strategy enthusiasts and World War II buffs alike, this game is a must-play.

Its a fun strategy game and you can have some fun while playing with friends or win a hard-fought game .But there are a lot of errors that are hard to overlook .

 First the game needs your money .Three of Five functions are locked and almost all of the good commanders are behind a pay wall or if you collect the coins . To collect your coins for the cheapest commander you may play over 150 hours .

There is a great imbalance on function power when Axis has 60 % win rate for all the life spam of the  game . The game may be more balanced if you play 1vs1 or 2vs2.

There are many tactics who are no skill ,no fun . Some are blobs of elite units,mass artillery, mortar spam who they hit you every time,mg spam(not that strong but no fun early game) to name a few. Those are more known on 4vs4 matches .

Some of the functions lacks utility and you must buy commanders that can solve the issues that should never  be existed to begin with .

But all that i can forgive . What i cant forgive is that there is no punishment for the droppers ,but may it is impossible to punish someone when the server just drops you so many times and its much more horrible that you cant reconnect (maybe they dont know how to do this or because of the AI bots). There is a AI backup if a dropper exists ,but the AI is useless and gets many bonuses so it may not be 100% garbage.(may the bonuses are the causes of the no reconnect issue dunno). A bot is no match for a average to bad player .  SO if a player drops or he lost connection or the server kicked him or something like that the game is over . I have rank 14 on many functions (20 are the highest) and 1187 hours total . I may have seen 10 wins with bots vs players (you may see more on super low elo) , i mean its only possible if the players dont have a clue of what they are doing .

Anyway . In conclusion the game it can be fun in the right scenario  ,if you play with friends ,if you play 1vs1 and the enemy may not take a overpowered commander (you can still win but the 60% - 40% says a lot) or maybe a 4vs4 that everyone is on your lvl and they dont drop for some reason.

If you thinking to buy it . Dont . coh3 will come and then we will see if its a burning garbage can or a fair game.
If you want to just try it . Well this game has  vast skill gaps that takes time to learn and the missions are all bad cause the AI is bad and you may not learn a thing for player vs player.

UPDATED

Pros: 
+ Fun and really challenging to play.
+ Soldier units now CAN jump across barricades and have a better cover system. 
+ Great soundtracks (in overall).
+ Well arranging maps and environments.
+ Several custom maps and other mods in the workshop. 

Cons:
- Only 2 main campaigns, they are quite fewer than the game should have.
- Not quite smart and unreliable AIs. (Still, I think it slightly better than AIs in the first COH)
- This is a personal opinion: Some campaign's missions are way beyond ridiculously hard, even when you play it on a normal difficulty. (Notably the Moscow suburban, Mtsensk and Halbe missions)
- Definitely the worst of all, historical inaccuracies of this game are totally unacceptable.

Here are the lists:

1. There are so many anachronistic uniforms and weapons on both Soviet and Axis faction:
1) Only M43 tunic and M43 wool-padded jacket (Gymnasterka and Telogreika, used since 1943) applied for the most of Red army soldiers. As for the 1941 - Pre 43 missions, they MUST be the M35 tunic and M41 Telogreika.
2) As a writer, Lev Isakovich himself still wearing M35 styled tunic during the last years of war, including Sgt. Pozharsky.
3) All German engineer, machinegunner and mortar units wear the M36 styled tunic since 1941 missions until the end of the game.
4) Panzergrenadier unit with Waffen SS lookalike camo pattern (1944) and sniper with M43 field cap can be seen since 1942's Stalingrad missions.
5) MG42 in 1941 missions (should be MG34). And Gewehr 43 with scope, STG-44, Panzerfaust, Panzerschreck in 1942 - Pre 1943 missions. 

2. Anachronistic and out of the place vehicles, such as: 
1) StuG III Ausf.E, StuG III Ausf.G, T-70, T-34-76 with 1942 model in 1941. (StuG III Ausf.E can be used for Stalingrad missions and further on)
2) StuG III Ausf.G and the long-barreled Panzer IV (possibly Ausf.G) in January 1942.
3) StuG III Ausf.G in Stalingrad during Sep-Oct 1942. (It should be allowed during 1943-45 missions)
4) Tiger I in the Stalingrad Aftermatch mission's cutscene.
5) Sd.Kfz. 251/16 Flammpanzerwagen in 1942 missions.
6) From all above, here are vehicles for 1941-42 missions that should be added or replaced the anachronistic ones: Either T-26 or BT-7, T-26 flame tank (optional), KV-1 (from Halbe), Panzer III Ausf.G, StuG III Ausf.B, Panzer IV Ausf.F (short-barrel).

3. Population cap are way beyond ridiculously FEW for the Red army, especially in 1944-1945 missions. It caused too much trouble and really unrealistic yet anti climatic for Halbe and Berlin missions.

4. Lack of variations and wrong appearances among Soviet and Axis soldiers units, notably the Axis units.
1) Every grenadiers (regular soldiers, should be called as infanteries during 1941 - Pre 42 missions) are wearing full Wehrmacht camo uniforms. They should just wear a normal tunic: mainly M40 styles, and optionally M43 for 1944-45 missions.  
They also worn a strange uniform during the winter missions (should be proper greatcoats, same for machinegunner and pioneer).
2) Some of Red army soldiers should worn a greatcoat (could be M41 Shinel), it can be used on some of non-winter missions like the Stalingrad and Halbe-Berlin also.
3) Lack of variations on both uniforms and helmets for the Red army and Axis soldier units, including winter uniforms.
4) Osttruppen troop uniform looks too good, especially during the winter missions. (They should have worn a greatcoat)
5) Here are some of examples of additional troops for German/Axis side: 
5.1) Wehrmacht Panzergrenadier and Stormtrooper dressed with proper Wehrmacht splinter, tan and water patterns for their smocks and helmet covers. Recommend for 1944-45 missions. While in 1942 missions, only helmet covers with camo + regular tunics could be applied.
5.2) Waffen SS units: Grenadier, Machinegunner, Pak 40 crews, Officer, Panzergrenadier and Stormtrooper. All with Dot 44 tunic/trouser variants (full and half-body). Also Oak leaf or Plane tree smock. Better equipment and more dangerous than Wehrmacht units. Highly recommend for Behind Enemy Lines, Halbe, and Berlin.
5.3) Volksstrum unit - could be dressed with great coat and civilian uniform + arm band, recommend for 1945 missions.
5.4) (optional) Fallschirmjager - Appear in a few number in the Battle of Berlin mission.
5.5) (optional) Kriegsmarine (navy) - Appear in a few number in the Konigsplatz and Reichstag section.
5.6) (optional) Hitlerjugend - Teenage Panzerfausters for Halbe and Berlin.  

5. TOO MANY Osttruppen in the campaign, especially the intro mission (Stalingrad, regular German units should be spearhead troops for the attack) and the Berlin mission.

6. The Shock troopers should have the ability to use DP-27 and PPS-43 (the latter one is for 1944-45 based missions).

7. Only American lend-lease vehicles available as a scout car (M3A1) and anti aircraft vehicle (M5/M17). Here is some soviet vehicles I could recommended to fill the gap:
1) BA-20, a light armored vehicle for 1941-42 missions.
2) BA-64, a light armored/scout car since 1944 missions until the end of war.
3) T-27 (optional), a tankette for 1941-42 missions.   
4) ZiS-42 motorized 25 mm (optional), an anti-aircraft gun for 1942-43 missions.

8. Although they put some of the lend-lease vehicles in the game, but for some reason, there is no M4A2 Sherman available in the game at all (1944-45 missions, could be equipped with 76mm gun). 

9. Winter storm resistance of the Red army should be better than the Axis.

10. No other 88mm flak for Axis faction apart from Pak 43, the recommend one is Flak 36/37. 

11. KV-1 appeared only in Halbe mission. It should appear in other missions also (1941-42).

12. Ostwind Flakpanzer is actually a RARE vehicle (41-45 of them ever produced).

13. In the Berlin mission, the Kroll opera house will become a next target after the Ministry of Interior building. But in reality, it was attacked after 150th rifle division rush into the Konigsplatz first, but then got counter-attacked by defenders from both Reichstag and Kroll opera building. Also, judge from real photos and plans, the building is totally unrealistic.

14. From above, a date should be changed from April 29th into 30th after the Red army took the Ministry of Interior building, Pak 43 positions in Konigsplatz should be replaced by 88mm Flak 37 guns, Katyusha need to be usable, and at least 1 or both Tiger I tanks should be replaced by King Tiger.

15. Although the Berlin scenario and environment are great in overall. Still, they missed the BRANDENBURG GATE. It should be located in the far background, South-Eastern side from the Reichstag building. 

16. By all of his actions throughout the war, Sgt. Pozharsky should gained the ranks as Lt. or Capt. in the Behind Enemy Lines mission. And soldiers who guard him should be the NKVD troops (change uniforms).

17. In the latter-half of Stalingrad Aftermath cutscenes, besides from Yuri, there should be other soldiers and engineers appear in the scenes also.

18. Although the Red army are so well known for its (plenty of) "bad reputations", especially in term of cruelty among their own troops, POW, and those who didn't share the same ideology with them. But still, some points in the storyline are inaccurated, over-exaggerated, and seems to be too HOLLYWOOD. For example; Most part of the intro mission (Stalingrad) and how that fanatic Major threats your soldiers in the Stalingrad Aftermath mission.

In conclusion: 6/10

Company of Heroes 2 is an exceptional PC game that delivers an immersive and thrilling World War II experience. From its stunning graphics and realistic sound design to its engaging gameplay and well-crafted campaigns, this game truly shines. The attention to detail in depicting historical battles and the strategic depth of gameplay mechanics make it a must-play for fans of real-time strategy games. The multiplayer mode provides hours of intense competition, and the single-player campaigns offer a gripping storyline that keeps players hooked. The game also boasts a vibrant modding community, adding even more replay value. Overall, Company of Heroes 2 is a masterpiece that delivers a captivating and memorable gaming experience, and is sure to be enjoyed by both history buffs and strategy enthusiasts alike.

Updating this review, since I played about +400h more since I wrote the original one, and [i]Company of Heroes 3[/i] came out recently.

This game is an excellent RTS, specially in the sense that it removes most macro-level management, which I greatly dislike from other RTSs. In CoH there's no grand economy to balance, a dozen different buildings to make, nor workers to send get minerals. You win resources and the game by holding ground, "capture points", pushing all the focus into the firefights, which are amazing in both gameplay and feel.

On top of that, the visuals and audio of the game is incredible, both in the music as well as the SFXs. I didn't really appreciate how [b]good[/b] everything looks and sounds until I played the recently released CoH3, which greatly fails on those departments. Explosions and hits have punch, and that makes them both spectacular and easily noticeable, which is great to be accurately informed of the state of the battlefield in the middle of all that chaos. It is not "realistic", it's better than that.

The campaign doesn't fall short either, with varied missions involving the Red Army and a story that is not breathtaking, but not forgettable either.

All in all, the game has been steadily improving for a decade, and is now in a very commendable state, albeit with some problems, it's not perfect. CoH3 shows promise, but until it gets the level of polish it deserves, I'll enjoy this game for as long as I can.

a little late, but amazing game after many years of updates and balancing

you can pick it up for really cheap on sale, and it remains a top tier rts. 

the graphics, environment, balancing, different units and teams, and the fluidity and variety of the doctrinal system makes for a really great experience. the teams are similar enough to be roughly balanced but different enough to feel like unique experiences, especially with different commanders assigned.

the audio in this game is stellar too, whether it be the orchestral music in the background or the ambient conversations between the grunts on the ground. gunfire and explosions and tank engines are all awesomely loud and immersive as they should be.

game is also very responsive, sadly unlike dawn of war 2. tanks still turn like tanks, but for the most part everything responds and controls well, and the ui is smooth. 

i did have an issue where i had to delete some 30fps movies from my local files to make my multiplayer menu smoother for some technical reason, but a cursory google search shows it doesnt happen to everyone.

all in all, an amazing rts that deserves to be experienced.

Update: Upon returning to the game after many years, and after replaying the original campaign as well as the expansion pack, Steam offered me to revise my review. 

My opinion has not changed.

There are over 80 DLC options available for this game now. Granted you can eventually purchase some of these things, like the commanders and skins, with in-game currency upon completing online battles, but the fact remains that they have opted to monetize this game to a ridiculous extent.

Furthermore, I acquired the Ardennes Assault expansion pack, but I was greeted with the commander selection screen where it asked me to choose three of the four commanders to bring into the campaign. I was astonished to find that one of the commanders (Fox company Rangers) is locked behind a paywall which you can purchase separately for $5.00. When you purchase the expansion pack, it does NOT come with the US army or the Oberkommando army to play in online multiplayer mode or in offline skirmish mode (unlike the Opposing Fronts expansion pack from the first CoH, which came with TWO stand-alone campaigns and two additional armies for the price of $30). You have to purchase those two armies separately.

Even the DLC has DLC.

This game is not bad by any means. There is plenty of constructive criticism regarding balancing, game mechanics and design choices that can be openly debated, but I did actually enjoy playing through the game again. The micro-transactions and DLC in this game is insane and I can't wait to see how it's going to look like inCompany of Heroes 3, especially since they just released the official store for it in the last update...

Sorry THQ, you either die a hero, or live long enough to see yourself become a villain. And you died a hero. Unlike Sega, who insists on squeezing every penny out of their customers.

At the time of writing I still play this game virtually everyday. Strategy games have certainly come a long way from my first experiences with WarCraft 2 through AOE2, C&C Generals and Dawn of War all of which I've loved. 
Of these, Coh2 can be most readily compared to the latter, apart from Coh1 of course, with territories on the map (points) needing to be captured to bring in resources, victory points or in some cases simply to link-up territories to allow hard-won resources to flow back. Cover and line-of-sight mechanics will rule your engagements and, as your army grows, keeping on top of multiple engagements will test even the most hardened veteran. With a limited population cap, what to build when and how much of it to build becomes a very delicate balance. Adding to this dilemma is one's choice of a commander doctrine which will give the player access to various unique abilities or units, all of which vary in usefulness, cost and stage at which it will unlock (represented by command points which increase during the course of the game). 
Almost ten years after release the graphics still hold up wonderfully well with a real level of detail going into the units and animation in particular. It is important to remember however that no matter how cool your units and tanks look they need to be positioned and controlled properly to be genuinely effective, having the biggest tank is not necessarily going to win you the game by itself.
The maps are also nicely varied from sun-soaked pastures to bleak snowy grey bombed-out cities and fairly dynamic in terms of being altered during the course of the conflict as tanks and shells start to become more prevalent.    
I must note that while I did play through the entire single-player campaign I can't really recommend it apart from learning the absolute basic mechanics of the game. While the online/skirmish, which I unreservedly recommend, side of things has seen regular updates and balancing between the factions has been fine-tuned, the original campaign has been left in 2014 where the obsession with cold weather (albeit understandable) makes the experience more than a little frustrating.
I really felt I owed this game a review after it has given me so much joy and consumed so much of my time.
Not sure if this is allowed but also to thank the community - particularly AECOH who organises events like Master League and all who showcase their skills

Based upon the amount of time I have played this game you can tell I really enjoyed the game. I was a young teenager when this game came out and I loved it. I thought the campaign was meh but the multiplayer was great and definitely worth the 60$. I recommend playing this game with friends as you will enjoy the game more that way. I found every unit to be unique in its abilities and strategies. When the announcement came that they were going to add the US faction and the Oberkommando West faction I was hyped. When i got the two new factions I was not disappointed by them as their units were just as unique as the beginning factions' units. The same story goes with the British faction. 

My issues with the game began when I noticed the price tags on everything. At first there was a ranking system that would reward you with a commander or bulletine when you reached a certain rank. But after a while everything was put into either a dlc or an RNG "war spoils" system. I was annoyed by this as I didn't want to pay money into a game I already paid 60$ for, but I did to get some good commanders that I still use today. I was fine with paying for the new factions because they were expansions on the original game, but I could't say the same for the commanders as some of those commanders recycled old abilities from several commanders into one commander and maybe added one or two new abilitiesand then placed a price tag on it (This is more for the USSR and the Wehr than the USA and the OKW). Despite all this I still loved the game as I really enjoyed that the developers tried to balance their game based off of some advice from the community as it showed they really cared about the game. But what I began to notice was that with some of these balances ruined some commanders. A big example of this was the Rifle Company from the US faction, I loved the Rifle Company as you can  risk spending more money and waiting longer to get veteran riflemen, and you can equip those riflemen with a flamethrower, and you could save your fuel to get the Sherman Easy Eight without going for the Major. But after a balance update over a year ago, they took away the veteran riflemen ability, they allowed the flame thrower for the weaker Rear Echelon (I hope I spelled that correctly) troops instead of the Riflemen, and they made the Sherman only accessible by unlocking the Major. This ruined the company for me and this is just one example of this. 

Another issue I had with this game was allowing community made mods within the game. At first I was fine with it, I tend to not use community made mods but I know that others do so I was fine with them. But after a while when you tried to make a game it was much harder as there are many cases of being unable to start a custom made match because, "The game cannot start because <insert name here> within the match has one or two mods that one or more people have not downloaded" (this is not the exact wording but I understand the message as this). With the addition of the community mods I enjoyed some well made maps and unique mods, i.e. infantry only or tank only battles ect. But I also found a lot of animated girls for skins and backgrounds and I found these to break the immersion of a World War II game when there are animated girls with big boobs thrown into the game. Before you say it, yes I understand that this is just my opinion but this is a reason why I prefer Company of Heroes over Company of Heroes 2. This may or may not be relevant but now it takes a long time to make a custom game so it is faster to find an automatch game, I enjoy automatch but I really like the annihilation victory condition and I enjoy a change in gameplay from time to time.

A final issue, as this review is getting long, is that in the developers trying to balance the game, they have constantly changed the abilities of several units and commanders in the process. I have already discussed the change and commanders so I will describe an example of a unit. I want to talk about the OKW's VolksGenedier unit (probably spelled it wrong), when they were first added to the game they were equipped with Kar98s and their abilities were salvage wrecks and to throw a grenade for a certain cost in munitions, they were able to be upgraded with Panzershrecks and cold gear for the winter maps. After a while I noticed that they switched the grenade to an incendiary grenade, added a panzerfaust, and they replaced the Panzershreck with MP44s. I guess they did this because there were complaints of Volks spam with Shrecks and they wanted to fix that, but they gave the Panzershrecks to the Strumpioneers and now I have seen Strumpioneer spamming. So I do not know what that solved. I also didn't like the MP44 upgrade for the Volks as I viewed that they excel at long range. I would often pair them with Sturmpioneers in a combination tactic but with the new upgrade that is not required as the Sturmpioneers are now designed as tank destroyers instead of shock troops while the Volks are now an anti-infantry only squad with a panzerfaust to fight tanks. After this I noticed that the incendiary grenade for the Volks is timed before detonation instead of instant detonation which makes it useless for killing infantry as they can move out of the way before detonation. To compare this to another unit the Conscript squad of the USSR has never had its abilities changed and the upgrades had stayed consistent to today.

Summary: I really love this game and I want to play it but due to what I wrote about and other reasons I cannot say I would recommend it. I thank you for reading this review and I hope it has helped you decide whether to get this game or not. If you buy this game, I wish you luck and I hope you enjoy it as much as I have because it is a great game. 

Edit: I removed my disclaimer as they are doing more and more of what I have talked about. It is no longer my opinion when they change things for the sake of balance, and ruin strategies and units in the process.

March 28th, 2023. For those unaware, Steam has had a glitch occur where it states I made my review with 3K hours and added 2K more hours afterwards. If you read the comments, you will find this is not the case. 

Now that that housekeeping is out of the way. I intend to change my THUMBS DOWN to a THUMBS UP as COH3 is a disaster and the recent update is a store system that is worse than this game had before with the in game credit system. My complaints are still prevalent and the population of this game is down since my review. However, this is a greater (and cheaper) version of COH3 so I would recommend getting this game instead of COH3. I wish there was a choice of a mixed thumbs sideways, but alas there is not.

In conclusion, this game has been fleshed out with 5 factions with all cosmetics, commanders, intelligence bulletins, victory strikes, decals, etc for free with an in game credit system that rewards you for playing. If you have the time, you can get it without spending extra money (except the three add-on factions USA, OKW, and UKF however). I would recommend this game over COH3 any day.

*Apparently I cannot change the recommendation of this game without resetting the community response, so I will have to leave it as a NO, but I want a YES!!!

This game had a really rough release but at this point is one of the best RTS games from its era. Unique mechanics, very diverse rosters of units that give you tons of room for different playstyles. The singleplayer experience is prime. The campaign is solid and engaging, if not a bit short. If you played COH 1 its not as good, but still good. The Ardennes Assault campaign DLC is worth it if you're getting the bundle on sale, but otherwise you can skip it (not amazing, but worth a playthrough). 

AI in the game is good enough, but what really pushed the SP skirmish experience to its peak is the mods. There are mods that tweak AI and add/modify tons of units. There are a plethora of community made maps that are amazing. The replayability is prime.

The multiplayer at this point is probably not worth your time. Its ok, but the MM isnt great, theres no rejoin feature if someone crashes, and the metas are pretty stale. It is still active though, and I have no problem finding matches in NA region.

If you like WW2 games, get his one. It goes on sale for like $5, totally worth it.

From a perspective of someone who focuses on everything RTS except for "serious" competitive play of any sort, I was rather... underwhelmed?

Company of Heroes is a pretty damn successful and influential RTS series, introducing revolutionary new squad and cover systems, and a really cool balance between fun abstractness and that explosive intense realism. CoH1 while rather outdated on technical side, being a 2007 game, still shined with cool campaigns, a still existing modding scene, and feeling dignified. It's successor, Company of Heroes 2, in the meantime, has some issues.

Big focus on monetization in the version the game currently is. Apart from cosmetics (could be nice but limited in historic-ish game), some minor bonuses, there's some allegedly underwhelming mission packs that don't grip in either description nor footage, and a lot of content can be grinded trough some opaque random drops. It's demeaning, though I guess it's impressive how devs managed to pivot trough MULTIPLE monetization schemes with this one. One sad bit of monetization is that commanders, the selected special ability and improvement giving choices here are aplenty but majority are paywalled. Even factions are sold individually, this ain't the expansions of CoH1, everything comes piece by piece.

Another bit? It's somewhat low-energy. It's fun with friends, like three vs three or four vs four, getting intense then, but 1vs1 or in singlepalyer the slower comparing to original pace, and it used to be even moreso with stuff like cold mechanics making your troops sit out storms and cling to safe spots, which can only be spoted in campaign or turned on optionally now. The stories too lack the energy of CoH1, even at the time of writing hated on CoH3 has, from playtest I tried, a more enticing pace, all while maintaining depth.

I can't even name that many mechanics in this one I would a definitive improvement on original formula. A lot of new units and faction-based systems are neat and fun but not that distinct. Not to mention the mechanics and some units got tossed around and discarded, like the Soviet conscript upgrade system, showing this design conservatism where devs would rather retread on old ground than try to maintain a level of novelty. Even features I liked, like the commander selection, are somehow flawed like tied to monetization too hard. There are mods, but you can't add much new content beyond images like icons for units and abilities, so while you can tweak factions and units, they'll still look the same.

I can play and enjoy this with friends, at least a few, but playing by myself I feel bored and disinterested soon enough. It's an "ok" sequel that doesn't ruin series but it doesn't muster excitement either.

This game is awesome, probably my favorite RTS game and WW2 game.
The game is a tactical RTS game based in WW2, there are two playable base factions. The Wehrmact (Germans) and the Soviets (Russians). These two factions have many units, all with tons of unique voice lines and cool mechanics.
The game despite it's age look remarkably well on the medium and higher graphics, as well as running quite nicely. The visuals of the game really immerse you into the setting, it makes you feel like a general commanding soldiers on a battlefield.
I mostly play multiplayer with friends but there is a pretty good single-player Soviet campaign which comes with the game. I have not finished the campaign, nor even got half-way through, but from what I have seen and played it is a fun campaign with a decent story and well animated cut-scenes.
Not everything about this game is perfect though, the monitization is a crime. Aside from the starting two, the other three factions cost roughly $8 each, and there is countless doctrines that cost $4, which for there content is nowhere near worth it. I know they sell campaigns but I can't speak for how much of a scam those are.

Company of Heroes 2 is an exceptional real-time strategy game that takes players back to World War II. The game's attention to detail is impressive, from the graphics and sound design to the gameplay mechanics. 

The game puts a strong emphasis on strategic thinking and resource management, which will keep players engaged for hours. The single-player campaign is well-crafted and immersive, while the multiplayer mode offers endless opportunities for players to test their skills against others. The game also has a strong modding community, which adds even more replayability to an already fantastic game. Overall, Company of Heroes 2 is a must-play for any fan of real-time strategy games.

It's hard to believe that Company of Heroes 2 has already been around for ten years! Despite its age, this game still stands out as a classic in the real-time strategy genre.

Sure, the graphics may not be as cutting-edge as some of the newer games on the market, but they still hold up remarkably well. And the gameplay is just as engaging and challenging as it was a decade ago. The attention to detail in the sound design and historical accuracy of the game's story is still impressive, even by today's standards.

In some ways, the fact that Company of Heroes 2 is ten years old actually adds to its appeal. For fans of classic real-time strategy games, this is a must-play title that stands the test of time. And for younger players who may have missed out on the game's initial release, it's an opportunity to experience a classic game that helped shape the genre.

Overall, if you're a fan of real-time strategy games or World War II history, you owe it to yourself to check out Company of Heroes 2, even if it is already ten years old. It's a true classic that has stood the test of time, and it's just as fun to play now as it was back in 2013.

Since I have over 650 hours on this game and CoH3 just got released last week, I feel like I need to leave a review for this game. 

First of all, the best WW2 RTS I have ever played, maybe even best RTS in general ( this or SC2 imo ). Company of Heroes was one of the reasons why I started to get really into WW2 history as well as have a knack for tanks. Everything about this game, even the bad, make it a near perfect game. I'd recommend this to anyone who has played a RTS or even wants to get into the genre. Every faction is made uniquely to perfection and having such a large modding community makes the game even better. Albeit, you can't really get the full experience from just the base game, modding and owning all factions is a must but they usually go on a cheap sale. The Soviets show strength in numbers yet lack longevity in units, the Wehrmact have a slow yet steady pacing in their defensive army but can pack a punch mid-late game, the US excel in generalized tanks and infantry with a decent early game, the UK ( can ) have the strongest defensive army out of all 5 factions and the Oberkommando West are the best defense with an incredibly scary German offence. This is at least how I have seen and played each faction, all of which have their own play style and with each game sometimes I learn something new while playing. I hope that in CoH3 they really learn where they went well and where they need improvement as many things from this game I felt "this is good but if they had this it'd be perfect." All in all, fantastic game and even as it's definitely aged well ( still has bugs and isn't optimized for multi-core performance ) I will still most likely come back to it every now and then.

Used to recommend but change my mind. For a game that came out in 2013 and with additional charges through its in-game store I realized that it should be a lot more improvements. No hot keys customization in-game, crappy 64 bits transition (Somehow it runs worse after transitioned into 64 bits system rather than the opposite.) Periodic unpreventable bugslpat crashes that occur occasionally, no penalty system for dropping in the first 3 mins without reasons, etc.

Meanwhile Age of Empires changed their gender identity to coh3, let me explain:
-8k hours and nearly a decade in this game and it still puts up against any modern RTS in terms of graphics/sound and effects.
- Perfect controls and camera options
- Lots of stories to listen from idle squads in multiplayer (even after 8k hours). Fighting is brutal and intense both in terms of audio and video.
- Weapon/crew health, footsteps in snow, crawling soldiers, smoke animations.
- Was $40 at launch with tons of maps
- Ability to open and block players in game.
Why was there even a need for coh3 ? I mean they could have followed the total war route that would enhance aesthetics and also merge all games.

One of key to make a game fun is create frustration.

But the way this game create frustration is... kind of cheating:  it made the control of units either lagging or simply not responsive.   Machine gun unit doesn't really attack even when you use "attack move,"  anti-tank gun doesn't fire even though it's facing the tank,  and worse of all,  armor units, instead of attack, often just moving toward the unit you are targeting instead of firing upon it.

This lack of responsiveness is kind of random and it's often per game basis:  in some game, the unit's response is fine, in some other game, it's extremely lagging to a point that it is infuriating.   

This problem has been around since the inception of the game,  and the fact that developers made no attempt to fix the responsiveness of controls made me concluded that it is a deliberate design.

So, yes, the game is kind of "fun" because it is frustrating.  But the way it creates frustration is kind of cheating and should not be encouraged.

This game was actually gifted to me by  friend, due to my reluctancy to purchase it for myself. I've heard a great deal of many terrible things about this game, but as I and my friend found, together for the most part, Sega and the like have gone to some extent to ensure that the game receives it's just deserve. Combat was better balanced, vehicles removed and added, and new factions available for... 'reasonable' fees. I find myself liking the game more and more now, and I am often hard pressed to ignore an invitation to play it, as its fantastic replay value and near constant rewards have enthralled me in a way that I haven't felt since I played the first one. There is a bit of a learning curve, and exceptional player like to develop complicated and advanced tactics, but there's nothing like steamrolling through the enemy lines with a Kingtiger and Jagdtiger spearheading your assault.
 
     To sum it up, the game is fun, the difficulty is pretty well balanced, the fights are epic and the visuals can be stunning. Buy it. Love it. (and end up living it because you'll just NEED to have the new doctrine after doctrine)

[h1] A Great World War II RTS Game [/h1]
If you're familiar to any other RTS game, Company of Heroes 2 isn't that different from the Mainstream titles like Starcraft and etc although the Company of Heroes franchise is always one of my favorite Real Time Strategy franchise out there. The Bloody and Gritty atmosphere mixed with a great gameplay and an Awesome Campaign, Unarguably make them my favorite RTS franchise. 

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] 
The game's overall gameplay feels similar to Company of Heroes 1 with the addition of a bunch of new features. I usually get bored pretty fast in an RTS game because they are fun but very frustating as well. Company of Heroes 2 by far is the most unique of them. I personally loved the World War 2 theme in the game and while the game is pretty similar to other RTS games, the game has it's own several unique features that no other game has. And also one of the the things that I like from this game is the fact that it has base building. Not many World War II RTS Games out there has base building because most of them just focuses on Strategy and Combat and not Base Building. While some people prefers to play an RTS game with no base building whatsoever, Base Building is one of my favorite elements to see in an RTS game.

[h1] Atmosphere [/h1] 
The game has a pretty bloody and gritty atmosphere mainly in the Eastern Front. It actually does kind of reminds me of Red Orchestra 2 which was by far the best World War 2 first person shooter in terms of Atmospheric gameplay. This game actually kind of manages a pretty similar bloody and gritty atmosphere from the game which is why I absolutely love it.

[h1] Singleplayer and Multiplayer. [/h1] 
The game is still pretty populated for an almost 11 year old game. The game has bots like most Real Time Strategy games out there and it isn't a surprise. What's a selling point of this game is the awesome campaign that I absolutely love. While there's a bunch of RTS games out there, not many of them has a great story. Company of Heroes 2 is one of the few RTS game that actually have a pretty decent story. The game also has Co-op mode which is a plus if you're into that.

[h1] Graphics [/h1] 
The graphics is pretty decent for an RTS game made a decade ago and it still holds up pretty well. If you have an old computer from a few years ago that is not pretty decent I am pretty sure that you can still run this game at the lowest graphical settings with the lowest graphical resolution possible

[h1] Suggestion [/h1] 
If you're looking for a decent World War II Real time strategy game to try on then this would actually be a decent choice for you. And on steam sales, most of the time the game's price goes pretty cheap as well. Overall I do highly recommend this game.

An absolutely stellar action focused strategy experience. I find myself enjoying it more each time I come back to it, everything is so masterfully done as far as gameplay is concerned. 

The road they chose to go down as far as your option of commanders and small buffs to specific units is questionable at least and predatory at best. First game had 3 commanders for each of the released Army groups. This one has way more and to their credit they are well done and can give you stylistic gameplay. The catch is that outside the starters the commanders are all $4 each, offering 1 unique unit and 2-3 unique mechanics. Small price yes, but done through individual sales and not packs is meant to maximize profits and is anti-consumer. Years later they made several Soviet and Wehrmacht commanders available to all.

That said this game is !@#$ing tits man, really good.

Another game for which I wish there was a middle-ground for Steam Reviews.
Usually end up playing the Spearhead overhaul with close friends, makes for a good party game with a more arcade-y feel compared to something like Assault Squad (not a bad thing, depending on mood or preference), but this is a micro-transaction hell in its own right.  Paywalling the USA of all things (OKW a bit more understandable in my eyes), a free faction in the previous game, seems so incredibly bizarre to me, and is more or less just gouging extra for your bog-standard western front experience.
The factions all play well IMO, but I'm upset with having to pay for the game again twice over to get all of the options that should be available for me.  Suppose it's not out of the ordinary with Relic, considering the monetization of Dawn of War and its expansions, but still not ideal in my personal view.  I suppose at the very least they didn't go the Airborne route and make skirmish AI a paid feature.
Nevertheless, about all the investment I want or need from this franchise, highly doubt CoH3 will be very enticing to me, even if the Italians or the Japanese make a surprise appearance.

Qualms aside, I enjoy this game and what it has to offer me, just not happy with it popping a hole in my wallet to get the most out of it.  Paradox games do the same thing to it more than enough for more grand-strategy experiences, so I recommend buying this and any extra content on sale just as I would apply to the other studio's franchises.

I like this game quite a bit. The AI is brutal at the Hard/Expert level. I only have about 50 hours in within the last two weeks since purchase but I play it every day. There is a tedious amount of micromanagement involved at the tactical level (called micro in game parlance) and until a nimbleness is obtained I expect it impossible to beat the AI at the Hard/Expert level.  If you observe expert players on you tube you note how the game is more finessed once you reach micro dexterity. It is almost graceful at this level. 

There are a number of single player options that take in typical Campaign modes and DLC available to expand this play. Note: no cross platform Multiplayer play possible between MAC/Linux and PC and very few MAC players online. It really is a PC game for Multiplayer. COH 2 is the child of COH and I understand in reading the forums on Steam and COH2.org there are still COH players but the trend for awhile has been to COH2. In saying this I expect the new version COH 3 will in time displace COH 2 and it is due out in Feb 23 2023. So you might want to dive in with COH 3 and get in on the ground floor so to speak.

There is quite a virulent element in the community as you often find with this sort of thing. The typical fanatic with a 1000 hours of play who stomps around on discussion forums and the rage quitters on team play. Expect to experience troll like behavior in discussions, but that's life.  You do not need Multiplayer to enjoy this game. The AI is brilliant and the scenarios will keep you busy for a long time.

CoH 2 is a fun game, to put it concisely. A run of the mill RTS but with its own touches of gameplay, such as armor battles and snipers, to set it apart and create something great. In my opinion, and this may be a sin to say, I prefer CoH over Men of War Assault Squad 2 any day of the week. The two have their differences, but if you've played MoW AS the two play very alike whereas CoH is simply much more refined. The great things about CoH are the ability to customize units, the possible gameplay differences between nations (between infantry spam or saving for a ridiculously powerful Tiger I), the flow of singleplayer missions, and the abilities (airstrike spam is great). My friend recommended I buy it, and I'd recommend you who reads this to buy it too.

This review is for those considering buying and playing in anticipation of Company of Heroes 3.

Almost 400 hours over the years (and many more than that in CoH1 before Steam existed), Company of Heroes 2 has come a very long way and shaped into my undisputed daily driver for competitive RTS. The action and mechanics are next to none, except, perhaps, it's predecessor. Relic does this kind of RTS like no other studio, and your money will be well spent here if you're looking for the best skirmish and multiplayer experience ‚Äî just be aware, you will need to buy DLC for all the factions.

If you are excited about WW2 RTS campaigns, and are new to the franchise and can't wait for CoH3's release, then I recommend CoH1. I would say CoH1's campaign is far superior. While Company of Heroes 2's campaign is not bad, it is just not the *chef's kiss that is the original.

Company of Heroes 2, through many years of patches, fixes, community input and support, is the mechanically superior game. Atmospherically, the vibe, the feel... I think many will say it did not achieve what the original did. But it came damn close and Relic fixed it up into a pretty spectacular RTS.

I love Company of Heroes as a franchise. I started in 2006 when my buddy lent me the disk for CoH1. I will no doubt sink ungodly hours into CoH3. I have participated in every alpha and beta Relic has had for it. I strongly recommend both games, and yet also recommend newcomers either wait for CoH3 or pick the one that has what seeking:

If you want an RTS campaign in anticipation of CoH3:
-I recommend CoH1

If you want to dive into CoH3 skirmish and multiplayer:
-I recommend CoH2

If you are interested in the CoH Franchise but are not sure where to start:
-Waiting for CoH3 might be the best for you; **OR**
-If you can stomach the wallet hit, start from the beginning and enjoy all the excellent campaigns Relic has made. They hold up 100%.

After the extended time this game has been out, you would think the developer would have fixed most glitches and issues. Unfortunately, after multiple campaigns, there are still major glitches such as disabled troops, inability to regenerate troops, inability to order more troops, cover incentives, and weapon glitches. 
While this RTS is fun and entertaining, the graphics are surprising bad. The voice overs become irritating and repetitive, and the main campaign that comes with the game is not good enough for multiple play throughs. Overall, i have played this game extensively and would agree its better than most however, the developer has let me down with this craftsmanship of a game. 
I truly hope with the anticipated LONG wait for CO3. While i know there will be initial glitches and issues, the developer needs to really step up and continually fix these issues instead of focusing on the additional revenue from all the pointless DLC.

Tried to go back and play this game after a long hiatus and in 2 games I have seen so many MP bugs which break balance. From penetrative shots making the Pen sound and not actually doing damage, to rockets from AT planes simply disappearing when hitting tanks. If you are buying this game and have any desire to play online, be aware the underlying systems are barely functional. Its ironic as COH 1 didn't really have any of these issues, and still ,mostly functions as intended to this day. 

Buying this game at this stage will require ~$100 of money spent just to get competitive commanders for all factions as the game remains as it was on launch, an exploitative money grab. At least they changed the system to allow you to slowly buy commanders with in game currency after 5 years of milking the player base dry. 

I'm not going to comment on campaign as I didn't bother to play past the 4th mission as it was pretty awful and historically inaccurate. If you want the campaign experience just watch Enemy At the Gates and save yourself the 8 hours of frustration. 

If I was a relic employee former or current who worked on this game, I would be contacting SEGA begging for my name to be taken out of the credits as this game is an awful product and an embarrassment of a follow up to COH 1. Hopefully we all remember the state this game launched in and is currently in when we consider buying COH 3 and giving Relic and SEGA more of our money so they can continue to profit off of and smear the reputation COH 1 built.

I used to give this game a negative review... I quoted how I hated that my squads missed targets and enemies would hide behind the same cover that my own units were using. I called this game "arcady". Compared titles like "Men Of War AS2" and "Call To arms" to this one. 
Then I spend a few thousand hours playing Starcraft 2. Then I Spent a few hundred more playing Call to Arms until they released "Domination mode" that turned the game into arty spamming turtling noobs that I honestly.. Got tired of killing. I got so good at that game its stupid. I have a whole youtube on it.
This game however.. pulls the best of both of those worlds.. Its not COH1.. COH1 was a classic and did it right. This game strayed from its roots. Falls short on many things. But it has the punishing cruelty of "learn how to do pvp or get the F out" from SC2 and Warcraft.. and the "complexity" of Men of war. I recently got to try to Multiplayer Tech Test for COH3 and found that the developers have listened to their fans. They are returning to all the mechanics that we loved about COH1. And I apprichiate that.
but for this game (which will soon be dead like COH1 when COH3 comes out). Its good. It's punishingly difficulty to understand how the mechanics work. But once you do, the fights feel real, fast, and actually do make sense. 
Cons- Its extremely hard to make a comback. Just like in starcraft2/warcraft3. If you mess up the first 5 minutes of a match just GG and Re because this games competative and good luck catching up.
Pros- If you take the time to learn the very bare bones of basic PVP, you will find a game that is so intricate and complex that matches can go from a fast 15 minute rush, to 2 HOURS of total war.
Company of heros 3 is sick. I cant wait to get out there and give it a go. I can finnally punish people for not putting their inf in cover! Either way! This games great. Love it or hate it. Get good or get out. COH 3 will be more welcoming for the Men of war fans. It punishes players for not using cover and strategy x10 more.

After years of playing CoH2, I think I finally owe a review to explain my love-hate relationship and some features of the this game.

CAMPAIGNS

- Soviet Campaign is historically inaccurate on a lot of parts. Mission designs are decent but not good and fun enough for keeping you playing it until the end. Pre and post cinematics are well made. I would give it 6/10. 

- Ardennes Assault is just 10/10. Don't need more words.

MULTIPLAYER

Balancing

Axis forces getting smashed every single game and match phases by Allied artillery. You would think Germans would save the day by bringing in the big guns like Tiger I or King Tiger. But guess what, those would get countered easily by TDs (tank destroyers) worth 1/3 of their costs. Guess Axis loses tank matchup as historically accurate.. How about the infantry matchup? Good luck on that as well since Axis squads get wiped constantly by Allied artillery whereas Allied squads usually have room to breathe to gain veterancy without the doubts of getting wiped by Axis artillery since they are nowhere near as good as Allied ones. So in short, you are bound to suffer as Axis in every part of game in the field of infantry, tank, air support or artillery.  In the current meta of the game, I would give it 5/10 to the balance scale.

PS: Keep in mind that this balancing issue pointed on usually applies to 3v3, 4v4 and on some 2v2 maps, around middle ELOs. In high level play, it is usually(!) balanced.

Community

There are really toxic people playing sometimes but other than that it is a pretty friendly and active community I would say. Play mostly with friends in order to avoid those toxic people being in your team, and be sure to block them on steam post-match since some of them are pscyho enough to harass you on steam. Would give 7/10 to the community.

Mod Support

Since I m not much fond of mods, prefering vanilla most of the time, I don't have much experience on the mod support. But I know mod workshop for CoH2 is pretty active and there are some really good modding stuff like maps and new faction units, adding new colors to the game.

Overall conclusion according to my ranking of the features:

7/10

I am a 49 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just, watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. loaded into the game, made my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you were supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he helped me. Loved it as it was the best time had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

For a WWII squad-level RTS, CoH2 and it's predecessor CoH are about the best out there I have played. I was a fan of Avalon Hill's Panzer Leader and Squad Leader, so I reveled in the we-go Combat Mission series - I'm dating myself. CoH & CoH2 are a massive step forward akin to playing the would-be armchair George Mead in Sid Meier's Gettysburg versus Avalon Hill's original. But there are some unrealistic gamey issues of course that make it more like playing Civilization than Combat Mission, which was a fairly realistic game in terms of unit-performance and physics. Examples: Snipers out-of-the-box seemingly able to perform like Simo H√§yh√§. Your AI partner in a Co-op sending its troops out in a forced march thru a blizzard or storming a position deep in enemy territory with a single tank. A 75mm Pak unable to bring down a T-70 with one flanking shot or even two or three in a duel. To be fair, SM's Gettysburg had similar issues but it was still fun - once you got the hang of the quirks. So those are all very tolerable for CoH & CoH2 in terms of contributing to the overall play balance. I can't wait for CoH3! Now for the challenge to both (MoW and CoH) of these platforms: I'd love to see future campaign modes where we can use some better strategic maneuvering on a divisional-level map and then drilling down to the tactical combat. CoH2 introduced that, but it felt too simplistic and more like playing a really weak version of Axis and Allies than a good old AH or Strategy and Tactics game.

A very pretty game that can be fun at times, but suffers from a lack of fundamental, genre standard features. The game lacks any ability to save during a solo campaign mission, or restart a mission. So, for adults who may have responsibilities that pop up while playing, your options are to surrender, or do a hack mission restart by quitting via alt-F4. So you can restart a mission, it just wastes a bunch or time for the game to fully quit, relaunch it, go through intro screens, choose the campaign, choose the last check point and wait for it to reload. 

Some might argue that it gives a more challenging....the designer's intended play experience...blah blah blah. The bottom line is it takes away player choice and wastes time. I have the most play time on Total War titles. For those who want a hard core challenge there's "Ironman mode", no saves at all. For anyone else you can save as much or little as you want. It is the player's choice, and every player can have the experience they prefer.

Having a game provider decree how I play a game is ridiculous. Imagine if a baker told you what sandwich you could make with your bread. Their "dining experience" is that you can make ham sandwiches, but not cheese. You can only eat it in one sitting, or throw a half eaten sandwich away. You're not allowed to bag it, put it in the fridge  and finish it later...because that's not the dining "experience" THEY intended. 

I want to love this game. The genre, era and actual play can be great. I have owned it for years and reinstall it now and then and play it a while. Then the inconvenience and frustration builds until I move on to something else and free up the drive space. I have 1000 hours combined on various Total War titles and yet have never finished Ardennes Assault. This not a difficulty issue, but a lack of quality of life features that are often standard in similar games. It is a lack of player choice and could easily be solved by saves and an Ironman mode, or mods that provide them. Of course this only applies to solo play, not multiplayer.

I probably won't buy CoH3 until I try it for free, and then only when it's been out a while and and on sale. Too many good games out there to sink time into a game that can sometimes lead to more frustration than fun.

It's an OK game in the franchise, helped out by various mods from the community. I never got around to finishing the campaign, but PvE with friends has been pretty fun and intense. Worthwhile game to play with friends committing virtual war crimes, but don't bother buying it unless there's a sale. And don't bother paying money for the skins and commanders, even if they're on sale.

The one thing that saddens me about 2 is the significant player base that flings abuse at CoH3 just because "it's not CoH2." All they end up doing is make themselves look like fools.

I reviewed this game in 2017 and I feel that the review needs an update. I don't have an absolute ton of hours logged but I wanted to weigh in on my feelings about COH 2. Right out the gate, I will say that the game is fun. It is VERY fun once you get a hang of micro and hotkeys. Destructible environments, customization of units, awesome maps (both official and community made), and a great attention to balance make this RTS really fun to play. I greatly admire how diverse each faction is and the design choices. Whether your playing faction A or decide  to play faction B, or C, etc. it really feels different. You almost have to make a dedicated choice as to which faction you want to learn so you can dedicate all of your practice towards that faction. It's amazing how much customization there is - unit to unit.  A unit can receive upgrades that then lock out another set of upgrades making you decide what choices best fit your situation. The doctrines also add a layer of customization that was lacking in COH1. These doctrines allow you to form parts of your strategy, knowing that you will have additional and unique forms of support as the match goes on.

TLDR: If you like RTS games, COH2 is great.

Company of Heroes 2 is a real-time strategy game developed by Relic Entertainment and published by Sega. The game is set during World War II and players control various factions as they fight for victory on the Eastern Front.

One of the things that sets Company of Heroes 2 apart from other RTS games is its focus on realistic unit behavior and terrain. The game's "TrueSight" system realistically simulates line of sight for units, and the game's destructible environments allow players to shape the battlefield to their advantage. These mechanics add an extra layer of strategy to the game and make it feel more realistic.

The game also boasts a robust multiplayer component, with various modes and maps available for players to enjoy. The game's matchmaking system does a good job of finding players of similar skill levels, which helps to make multiplayer matches more competitive and enjoyable. [spoiler] multiplayer is dead [/spoiler]

In terms of visuals, Company of Heroes 2 is impressive. The environments are detailed and the unit models are well-animated. The game also runs smoothly, even on lower-end systems.

Overall, Company of Heroes 2 is a fantastic RTS game that offers a realistic and engaging experience. Its focus on realistic unit behavior and terrain, as well as its robust multiplayer component, make it a must-play for fans of the genre and previous titles.
