Company of Heroes 2 is a very good RTS game, even though it‚Äôs a bit old as it‚Äôs been going strong for over a decade now since 2013. Hopefully, Company of Heroes 3 carries on the game's legacy since I‚Äôve loved this franchise ever since the original game. The graphics, gameplay, units, tanks, and fights are all very well done. The music is intense and it truly gives you that WWII experience.

Since this game is pretty old, the multiplayer is still going on and is decent but will take some time to get into matches against humans. It‚Äôs also a lot of fun playing with friends against AI as I‚Äôm sure when CoH3 comes out, everyone will likely move onto that one for multiplayer so be ready. Once that happens, it‚Äôll likely be extremely hard to find any gamers playing this but at least the AI option is there.

When it comes to the campaign, it‚Äôs also pretty good and immersive as I‚Äôd consider this franchise as a whole to be one of the best RTS games out there you can play. Especially if you also love military-inspired games as much as I do.

The only thing I can critique about Company of Heroes 2 is all the crazy amounts of DLC that when added up, is very pricey. It‚Äôs not an issue if all you play is CoH2 or love RTS games in general but unless they all go on sale, it‚Äôs definitely overpriced.

I sure hope CoH3 remedies this by perhaps going the route of a battlepass or something to keep this kind of content flowing where you don‚Äôt have so many individual options or packs of DLC to buy. Either way, I do hope CoH3 delivers since it could be one of the best new RTS games of 2023 but we shall see. I‚Äôm definitely going to play CoH3 once it comes out because I love this franchise and have since 2006. They did push the release date so at least that shows they know how important of a launch this is in such an iconic RTS series.

Overall, I give Company of Heroes 2 a 4/5 and would recommend this to anyone that loves RTS games as I feel it‚Äôs a must-play title in the genre. I think just like the original, this will be an RTS game that stands the test of time and will still be played for many years after it‚Äôs done being supported. Especially since there are a ton of mods to enhance everything and provide endless hours of awesome gaming. The only knock I have on CoH2 is the overpriced DLC as there is a ton of it here and it‚Äôs too expensive in the grand scheme of things.

For PVE, the games looks good in the first few missions but grows more and more boring and unnecessarily hard, with 3 points being the worse:
1. It is hard and not enjoyable to play. It is hard to play in a sense that you only have 2 hands it there are so many units that you need to control, and sometimes not in 1 way but across the map. In addition to this, you have no key binding or short cut to move the camera so you have to move across the map to find where your units are with your mouse. 

2. The AI are dumb. I have lost count of the number of times when I tried to pull off a tactical movement and flank the enemies but my unit simply runs right into them, or from another perspective, the enemies simply run right into my units, and then everybody just stand right where they are and shoot each other without any cover. If you happen to bring a mortar team or artillery, you will also see the mix of yours and enemies' unit getting vigorously shot at by those mortar or artillery. And the bugs that does not allow you to use ability is just annoying given how strategically important they are.

3. The building and resources system is just ridiculous. I am expecting to control a company, not the whole damn army, which shouldn't have any resources creation involved, and the way they are acquired are utterly inconsistent with unnecessary and unhelpful in making the game more fun. More importantly, the population is just dumb given how it limits the play style and how you can utilize the weapons. 2 sniper cost 6 population while 6 mortar crew also cost 6, it just don't make sense. Plus it limits how much infantry and armored units you can create, and the enemy then throws 3-4 times more of that at you. It just unnecessarily kills the fun.

This was the first RTS that I could find myself committed to. For starters, it's got a great campaign that introduce you to the games mechanics, and general functions of an RTS. But what stands out to me most, compared to any other RTS I've tried, is the cover-to-cover combat. Other RTS's feel like the combat consists of kiting, or just sending units in to duke it out. Here in CoH, you really navigate the crevices of the map, using the various structures for your advantage. It's my own opinion, that compared to other RTS games, the micro-management isn't too heavy. The learning curve is semi-steep, but the fact that the entire genre of the game is rooted in historical realism, makes it a lot easier to navigate in some ways. Fuel is simply fuel, and munitions are used for abilities/grenades, etc. There's no real guess work about what the vehicles do. Tanks are tanks, transports are transports. Same for many of the units. Engineers are engineers, machine gunners do what you'd expect machine gunners to do. Mortars do what you expect mortars to do. It's not like StarCrafts Protos, or Zerg races, which are a lot more complex in their design and functions. There's no pylons, or little structures you build to raise your population cap. You just let the manpower generate, and build. Very straight forward, easier-to-understand combat, very strategic uses of cover. It's my absolute favorite RTS, and the only one that I've put real game time into. I always recommend it for anyone that loves RTS games.

This game has become one of my all-time favorites. I started playing COH after the first one was released and continued ever since. The AI has become impeccable (credit being given to player feedback, devs fostering a welcoming platform for feedback etc.) , and the multiplayer ever more gratifying. I've been playing video games of all genres for over 25-years and this one has had me hooked. What really attracted me to this game was the realness and genuine aspects to our different military's across the globe and the investment made to allow the player to not only be educated on actual history but how each country's military was different. I have recently used this game as a great way to teach my son about history and show him a fun game that has real substance and not just another "hack n slash" or "Fortnite type game" that shows violence in a romanticized way. I would recommend this game to anyone looking for a fun RTS type game that has real substance, especially some dads out there looking for a good game to play with their son that actually has context/history.

It doesn't help that some of the more memorable battles on the eastern front aren't in my opinion covered very well in this campaign like the iconic Stalingrad river crossing being a tutorial. But again over all it is still worth a play through tho preferable when on sale.

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single father to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So i decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

Steam, you suck arse. I typed a massive review and you deleted it.
CoH 2 base game is quite good. Skirmish mode is quite fun but they cold have modified it to be a map where you choose the territories you want to invade or defend.
Bring on Ardennes Assault. They did it, they brought in territories. Then completely screwed it up. You have 3 armies you move around. There is allied and enemy territory which you can move onto. Instead of moving one territory at a time you can move as many as you'd like in allied and enemy territory but you lose 5% strength every time you move in enemy territory even though there are no enemies there. Moving onto an enemy territory doesn't capture it though. You have to move through enemy territories until you get to an occupied territory. So why did you take casualties in an unoccupied territory? Because the Devs broke the game. When engaging in battle you Win or Lose. Regardless of the outcome you take casualties of a certain amount. Upon winning you gain some points to spend on either skills or reinforcements. The reinforcements will not be enough to replenish your forces so you will bleed continually until you are too weak to fight. Also, when you beat the enemy they don't die. They move into other territories and reinforce the armies there. So you end up getting weaker and weaker and the enemy gets stronger and stronger. As you are invading, every map starts you with nothing and the enemy are entrenched. The enemy never attacks your territory so they never weaken and you never get the opportunity to weaken them. Your armies heal every time you use a different army to attack but not enough to make a difference. You will bleed to the point your armies are nearly dead. AA doesn't have the ability to Save and Load when you screw up. If you save you also quit. Every decision counts, no going back. I tried the campaign on normal and got to 67% captured and found i was as 25% strength fighting 5 star armies, not fun. I started again on easy and though a bit easier, it wasn't significantly easier and at 60% in i'm finding my armies down to 60 to 70% and the enemies at 4 stars. 
I can't recommend the expansion. It's frustrating as hell though it could have been excellent.
Oh, and if you play on easy and load the game it will put you into Normal difficulty, every time.

The strategic and tactical aspect of the game is fun and engaging. The gameplay mechanics, environment physics and ambience overall give good immersive experience. Balance across the factions are also more or less equalized with few notable outliners. Both the PvE and PvP aspect of the game are enjoyable especially with friends. The game has quite a steep learning curve, so it will take a while to reach the upper echelons of the leaderboard. 
The big drawback of the game are the enormous amount of micro-transactions for every single type of items starting from aesthetics to all important commanders with valuable units/abilities locked behind paywall. In case you are unwilling to splash the cash, there is a prolonged grinding mechanism in place which allows you to buy in-game stuffs using 'supply points' earned by grinding games. 
There are multiple DLCs with one with campaign, a few for theater of war missions and most importantly the factions (US Forces, OKW and the British forces). The faction DLCs imo are worth picking up during sale as all 5 factions (2 from base game) have radically different playstyles which can be pretty entertaining and interesting for different types of players. 

TL;DR: The game is good, microtransactions suck, definitely worth a shot esp during sale.

Do not mind those who play 3-5 matches and lose and then say the game is unstable. It is a difficult game, it teaches the person to be defeated. The tactic you make in one match won't work in the other; Because, your opponent, a momentary change of strategy will turn everything upside down.
Is this bad? On the contrary, it requires always being vigilant, establishing tactics from scratch according to the opponent and thinking fast in each new match. It is a difficult game but it is the only game you enjoy even being defeated :)
My advice is that players who say I'm ambitious should play, arrogant players who say I cannot lose should stay away. .

I run this on a Generation 9 i7 with 32 gb of ram and a RTX 2080 Ti, I can run all modern games at ultra settings easily, but this game that is 6 years old still has frame rate issues when you tilt the camera down. I will be upgrading to a second RTX 2080 Ti for 22GB of VRAM, I will run the game again after that and let you all know if its enough to get a decent frame rate out of this game. Don't buy this.... they didn't program it well. You have been warned. (the benchmark said my frame rate was around 127 fps btw)

So its about 2 years later in Oct of 2021 and I have a RTX 3090 which is a 24 GB graphics card, as well as a 11000kf i9 processor and 32gb of ram as well as a 2tb mme ssd that the game is installed on. Dropping all graphics settings to the lowest possible I still drop to 38ish FPS by tilting the camera. I think at this point the only way to get any kind of framerate out of this 8 year old game is quantum computing. Obviously we have to break the very boundaries of space and time to make this game playable at any time ever.

Welp I upgraded again to a 12th gen i9 processor, DDR5 RAM at 6400 mhz and a 4090. With this I am able to run this around 275fps until I tilt the camera at which time I get dips to the 45 range, This has to be some kind of record in the garbage programming hall of fame.

Great multiplayer, boring single player, mediocre to awful community right now. It's a great time if you play just between friends or online with competent friends. Otherwise the experience is all over the place. I'm no RTS master but I did do pretty good in Starcraft 2 (almost platinum) and I've been playing RTS itself since 2002. So I have some knowledge about this stuff. And with COH 2, there are unfortunately some major barriers or pitfalls in this game that might absolutely piss you off:

Player pool - Eventually, the playerbase shrinks to a degree where you're going to have a tough time finding other players of equal skill levels. The problem with COH 2 is that my games are about 49 percent insanely good players who walk over me or 49 percent that suck. Seriously, I have disabilities, I can't process tons of information at once without getting overwhelmed easily, and I still absolutely ruin some of these people because they just play so terribly. There's a difference between understanding COH 2, understanding RTS, and understanding how to use a mouse and keyboard and I feel like the other 49 percent of players are barely scraping past understanding how to use a mouse and keyboard. When you get a good game where the opponent is at your skill ceiling and "gets" coh 2, it's really fun, win or lose. But that is rarely the case because....

Guides online are outdated - there is no proper meta-wiki for this game despite being out for almost a decade. So many guides are totally outdated yet they're the first results that show up on google. Talk shit all you want about how people obsessing over meta kills certain games but the reality is that if a strategy is optimal it will be used. It's fun to try out different builds against different factions though, it's fun figuring out mechanics. What isn't fun is having to spend 30 hours figuring out what build order or tier units work best for your faction for the most basic counter players. There is no one making comprehensive guides on what units to avoid in certain matchups or solo/team compositions. Rocket trucks as OKW are crazy good in teams, they suck in 1v1 unless your opponent is cheesing. Having guides helps players understand what units counter what. Do you have any idea how frustrating it is to fight a faction where they spam the same unit or building and despite you playing your A game and they're obviously barely competent with a keyboard, yet they still somehow win? Now you're searching for the one in-date guide to figure it out after dying to the same cheesing composition 5 games in a row. It's annoying. Not that I expect the community to come up with guides because...

The community sucks - I don't b*tch about toxic communities in games because it's a meme. Trash talking is fun as shit because it comes from the dumbest players whom I just stomp into the ground and it's fun as hell to do that. Unfortunately, what's not fun is them leaving early and not giving me any points for the game, what's not fun is dealing with them on your team in 2s, 3s, and 4s, where they will leave at the slightest problem or complain and ping incessantly the entire game. What's not fun is the enemy player, despite 0 chance of winning, still stalling the game out because he doesn't value his time at all. 1v1s are the only time you can get close to a fun time because its just you and your own skill but even then the other player finds ways to be a bitch by dragging out games. They always GLHF with me at the start but they never GG me when I win. That sums up the entirety of the community right there. "it's fun until I lose". I'm sorry but if that's the case then your game just sucks and so do you. Speaking of which...

The Campaign & offline experience - It's boring, I peace'd out halfway through the first few missions in COH 2 and apparently from what I read, the narrative sucks too. Generic soviet hollywood war movie retelling of their conflict. COH 1 had amazing campaigns even though that game's engine was like a jetski running on sand. They added two campaigns since via dlc but they're not what you'd expect. The expert AI for skirmish is fucking broken. Basically gets like double your resource pool and makes cheesing for certain factions a requirement. You wanna get good at this game? Don't play against the AI. You will have to come up with sub-optimal strategy that just involves exploiting them rather than actually playing well. The campaign is chock full of bad mechanics. The cold weather mechanic was an awful idea and has been pretty much omitted from multiplayer, and that's due to one of the biggest problems with the game...

The technical systems behind everything suck a$$ - The physics, the bugs, the glitches, the damage calculations. This game is shockingly bad when you approach it from a competitive standpoint. I will see shells hit the sides of medium tanks and somehow no damage will occur, I've seen units glitch out and not move or attack despite not being pinned or anything. I've seen units become one with the tank they're repairing... No not physically, I mean they will attach themselves to the tank mechanically so they move when the tank does but have zero abilities and can't retreat. It's insane. The engine is superior to COH 1, but everything is still held together with duct tape. I will often surrender or win matches yet the server still doesn't give me any credits due to an error. The entirety of the vehicle system whereby front/sides/rear have different armor values in addition to some special pathfinding and terrain and how vehicles have weight to them, all that sounds fine on paper but in practice, it's a nightmare. I've even seen really good players struggle at times with how all the calculations are working behind the scene regarding tanks I will get hit by shells and yet there's zero damage, or the shot won't line up despite the guns being stationary, or how the tank will just have a spastic moment of ADHD and look at a squad of infantry to do .000001 damage to it with a shell while the enemy tank is entering the fog of war so the gun has to re-align and the enemies tank suddenly goes from on the run and about to die to getting another shot first or getting away clean. Shit will just not work when it's supposed to at best and it's a nightmare to deal with as a new player at worst. COH 3 is having vehicles turn on the dime by comparison so maybe they'll improve the system. At least everything works a lot better than COH 1 although that game at least had several good campaigns. But I doubt they'll fix the mountain of new bugs in a timely matter and make a campaign worth a damn. There's a reason one of the best compositions online is to mass infantry with AT, Tanks suck.

I'll still recommend the game if you can get it off a third party key site complete with all the DLC for 10 bucks and got an RTS itch or friends to play with but if you're not super into RTS this game can and will absolutely piss you off or put you off of it entirely. I still like doing ladder and a game night with the boys, even online but there are so many massive problems with this title that I can't see myself recommending this one to many casuals or even hardcore players.

Update: I beat all the cheesing players and now I'm at the point where I play great in 1v1 because I understand the mechanics. Jesus that took awhile but I'm running out of players at my skill level, but now I'm bored since there are limited comps to play with (if there's more than 1) for each faction. So I switch it up and do Teams online by myself. Holy god this is the most miserable experience ever. It's almost as bad as a Moba. Braindead players everywhere. Do yourself a favor and save about 5 years off your lifespan, don't play teams online alone. Even when you're winning its not fun. 1/10 games is balanced and fun the rest is a one-sided stomp.

I have a love-hate relationship with this game, let me explain; 
  The battle feels just right, your troops talk like human beings and you feel their presence, you feel like commanding real troops. 
  The singleplayer has a lot of content to go through you can never get bored. 
  The A.I. is good, it's not braindead and can make you sweat on hard difficulties. 
  You can customize your troops and vehicles with skins. 
  You can build your strategy with lots of commanders (they give you special kind of abilities/vehicles/weapons) 
  You can use the enviroment around you, for example you can position your troops in buildings or on top of hills to give them bonuses. Troops on roads and lower grounds have a disadvantage when defending/attacking. This makes the game more fun. 
Things i hate about this game: 
  There're lots of commanders that can change the way you play and can benefit you, and buying them with game currency is almost impossible, they give you so little cash that you can't buy anything really, it's just an illusion. I bought every commander DLC on the steam store. EVERY ONE OF THEM, and when i opened the in-game store, i saw that they have more commanders that i have to buy to experience the game fully. This was frustrating. 
  The A.I. is cheating on expert difficulty. Just knowing this lowers the fun.

This is a great RTS game!  It does not require TOO much APM (i'm not 22 anymore), but still quite a bit.  The tactics involved in laying out your defense, or planning your advances is signficant.  Coming from StarCraft (which I also loved), their is a bit more involved here in mixed weapons and how they are deployed.  SC was more about building a large force and charging forward with it (well, not quite that simplistic), while if you do that blindly in COH you will get eaten alive.  

One thing I HATE about COH though, is the randomness involved.  Sometimes a grenade may slightly damage a squad, others it kills 90% of it.  Some call that fun, 'part of the experience', I call it annoying.  If I want the suspense of randomness, I'll watch a movie.  When I am competing against another, I prefer no randomness.  SC did not suffer from this, and from that aspect is a bit more of a competitive game.  All in all though, I really enjoy playing COH.  But if they were to get rid of the randomness, man that'd be a game....

I am a 45 yo father, probably one of the oldest people playing this game. I am a single farther to my Son, who is 14 now. My son got this game for Christmas in 2021 from his uncle, so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me, as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son, as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game, picked my character and started playing but I was stuck on what you where supposed to do. I asked my Son for help and he hosted a game for me to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything, and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.

This review is strictly for online multiplayer, which in my opinion is the best way to play rts. When the game was first released in 2013, I didn't like it as much as CoH1. But a few years after with a bunch of updates and changes I like this game more than the original. It is more strategic and with reduced population cap, requires you to make a decision on what units you want to make up your army. You can't have everything. This requires you play strategically. Instead of simply overwhelming your opponent when you are ahead. Best RTS of all time even better than the original. After 8 years this game is still getting balance patches and updates to keep it fresh and fun! Ive been playing this game almost everyday for the past few years. And 6 years of COH1 before that.

I hope the devs don't take this the wrong way, but I have to give this game a no if I were to recommend it to someone who likes RTS and plans to buy this game. The game has a lot of bugs. Companies malfunctioning especially in the Ardennes Assault missions where the weapon rack upgrade ruins the mission progress causing it to be stuck in a mission forever, Rank Specialization (Lieutenant, Captain, Major) doesn't work anymore even if you achieve it, units going opposite directions whenever you're pointing them somewhere specific, and many more. We tried all the fixes that we could find online, but nothing's working. I could still change my review if the issues get solved soon. Yes, I got this game for free and bought the DLCs, and played it for long hours, but that doesn't mean I enjoyed the game to the utmost extent, probably because of being unable to maximize the use of the game's functions that are affected by critical bugs. That's all. It's a good game. Just infested by so many bugs.

Update: Game always crashing when loading saved games now. It went from average stupid to advanced stupid. Several commanders and units are now malfunctioning (maybe because of updates?), and Ardennes Assault DLC always loses saved progress when logging in to a different computer. This game's hopeless. Guess the devs broke this game so that the players will switch to COH3. Bad investment (purchased DLCs and game time) for a game that I got for free.

This game is awesome. I play exclusively on skirmish mode against AI and it's one of the most fun and rewarding RTS games I've played. 

The fact that you have to use combined arms tactics to be successful is really tricky, and was very frustrating at first. Other RTS games didn't really prepare me for that. But once you get over that hump, the reward is a massive, never-ending war with tanks, infantry, artillery, and even planes at times, just running amok and fighting to the end in glorious chaos like an orchestra of destruction.

This game is fun at first then becomes an exercise in futility. It's dumb and hopefully COH 3 will actually be worth it. Don't play this one go play the first game

I think the game is really fun, but I am absolutely disgusted by the monetization schemes they employ. You can buy all the DLC it has to offer... But you will still be missing at least 26 commanders, Each which cost 4 ENTIRE DOLLARS. But you can buy each of them for 15000 supply. How do you get supply? At the end of each match, you get 2000 points if you win, I think 1000 points if you lose. You need to get 6000 points to level up, which leveling gets you a crate that can have either an item, or 500 supply points... You would think the game would give you like, 1000-2000 supply points per match, but no. You get a crate after 3 wins or more losses with a chance, of having 500 supply points. Or it could have a random skin or bulletin.

Meaning that in order unlock what should be free gameplay features to those who already bought the game and all the DLC, you need to do a combination of grinding and paying out the ass, OR pure grinding. Why, on earth, would any game that charges 20 bucks upfront... Require intensive grinding/ purchasing of bundles to get in-game advantages. It'd be one thing if supply was a resource you got from battles and was only used to purchase skins and cosmetics. But it is literally a grind/p2w game. I cannot possibly recommend it, it's better with mods that remove this garbage.

Certainly a step up from COH1, I remember only playing the first for a very short period of time before throwing in the towel, I decided to pick this one up during the sale just to try and scratch the itch of the genre and give the series another go. I feel like the tutorial and opening missions are much more forgiving than it's predecessor and even though the intro to the campaign is essentially a losing simulator it's kind of a smart idea to prepare the player for defeat and emphasize strategy.

The graphics are nicer than I thought they'd be, and even though I went and watched a tutorial or two, the majority of the mechanics and menus in the game were pretty easy to navigate. 

I definitely think I'll pick up the DLC once another sale hits, I avoid multiplayer in RTS games so I can't speak on that although it's pretty toxic from what I've read. Plenty of achievements to go hunting for which is nice, and I haven't touched on the story because it's pretty average and I didn't really retain much of what I've already seen so I can't really judge.

This game is really fun. If you like WW2 and can ignore some historial liberties for the sake of fun, you will get a quite a few hours of fun out of this game. If you like RTS games, then you probably bought this already. The DLCs are...well Relic and Sega are going to take every penny out of your pocket they can. Most are worthwhile if you catch them on sale. The Western armies are well made and have unique playstyles. Still wait for sale.
The commanders are only worth it if you have a particular hard on for a certain unit or playstyle. I for one love the Pershing and Easy Eight so they got me on those. The special units are as well made as base game stuff. I cannot accuse Relic of skipping on quality.

TL;DR 
- Fairly steep learning curve to mastery. Multiplayer is brutal on newbies.
- Toxic online community (way better with real-life friends)
- Updates are infrequent and sometimes controversial
- Single player offers average entertainment value
----


== Here's what's great about it ==

- At the time of writing, you won't find a better WWII RTS with this level of immersion, versatility and polish. The Essence engine is a marvel: the graphics look beautiful at their maximum setting, and there is nice detail to see when you zoom in close. Think of vehicle engine sounds, splattering terrain, pockmarked battlefields, smoke and foliage beautifully drawn and highly dynamic to grenades, fire and artillery shells.

- Replay value is high because of the sheer variety of modes: victory point, annihilation, theatre of war, campaign or a fully modded experience. 

- Hardware specs are reasonable (your potato can run it). Recently it has been cross-ported to Linux, Mac and even Proton for your Steam Deck.

- You'll be learning your WWII history through animated models (e.g. that T34/85 took out my Sd.Kfz 142 StuG III)

- Voice acting is pretty good, with larger-than-life personalities balanced with dynamic feedback, e.g. I‚Äôm under attack!‚Äô, and occasionally quite funny if you listen closely.

- Campaign/Theatre of War and the Tutorial are well thought-out and engaging, though repetitive and lonely if you don‚Äôt find a buddy.

- There are 3 allied and 2 axis factions to choose from, each with options to suit your play style (see caveats).

- Theatrical music is pretty good and varied across factions... though the menu music can drive you crazy when waiting.

- Online play is free (no subscription) and very good for latency for up to eight players in a single match.

- You‚Äôll experience a rush of adrenaline like no other RTS game, thanks to the quick paced combat and strategic thinking necessary to pull off a win. Victory point games leave you on the edge of your seat. Annihilation matches can be a marathon.

== Here's what's crap about it ==

- The dreaded 'bugsplat' (crash to desktop with an error submission prompt) is an inevitability for most gamers, and can happen at any time during your gameplay. Who knows the cause? Everyone has a theory. My friends and I usually cycle the game open-closed and pray to the random number generator gods that it doesn't happen in our match. All we know is you're in the middle of a multiplayer online match and suddenly, you're staring at your desktop wallpaper.

- Community opinion (mostly forums) has an overwhelming influence on game balance changes. There used to be lovely surveys you could fill out, but they just went into a void somewhere. 

Now you'll log in to Steam one day and find a newly released patch has run a rough-toothed hairbrush over the UI like: rushed descriptor tiles with spelling errors and broken hotkeys, unit abilities nerfed, commander skill trees rearranged, and building resource prerequisites changed.
 
- Custom (non-historical) skins and/or victory strikes cause issues in the multiplayer lobby. You'll usually be asked to disable them before a game commences; for whatever reason, this just wasn't implemented properly.

- There are too many commanders. These were a selling point for the game back in the early days. I've played a great number of them. They're mostly repetitions of the same theme:  underpowered or poorly balanced.

- Community management is a joke. Certain swear words are auto-sanitised (the F word becomes garden), and that's just the beginning.

Toxic players are rife. You‚Äôll be hard-pressed to find good natured people who want to play collaboratively, which is a must to victory in this game. Lone wolves are ostracised quickly and viciously.

Tall poppy syndrome is also real. Don‚Äôt let your shine come out too strong.

Newbies in automatch games are witness to the community at its especially mean, vitriolic and rank/status obsessed worst. Team-stacking is common (they suck, we're pro) and divisive. 

There used to be a ranking system, but it never worked at the best of times.

- High munition call-ins (200+) delivered by plane are often shot down pathetically easily. What was the point of all that sacrifice if they can't even deliver a payload?

- Halftracks typically have paper armour. They don‚Äôt last long against small arms fire. Meanwhile, the Kubelwagen 'sedan' is comparatively a damage sponge, which makes no sense.

- Mortar fire is too fast, accurate and furious to make for enjoyable tactical play with your infantry. The Soviet heavy mortar is particularly ridiculous. Forget about long engagements behind cover, the heat-seeking projectile of mortar will demolish you.

- Grenades are hard to use. They require excellent timing, precise aim and a good interpretation of cover, terrain & enemy squad model positioning.

- Small arms close-range units, like the Thompson, have really wild RNG, even at obscenely close range. Sometimes you unfairly ruin an enemy squad with ridiculous high damage. Other times, you might as well be throwing potatoes.

Many maps are wide open, dirt-ditched with flowing roads and fences; choose an assault commander and it'll will ruin somebody's day: yours.

- So. Many. DLC components. I mean seriously, the start menu is literally a carousel with ads for its upgrades. 

- Laying mines, making caches and using resource trucks is weirdly divisive in online games. Don‚Äôt be an altruist, nobody will thank you for it.

- Like real war, the CoH2 battlefield is full of yelling, death throes, explosions and radio static. The cacophony of these sounds mixed together is too much sometimes. If you turn it off, you lose valuable battlefield info.

- Online games have no pause function. It can be incredibly stressful if something happens in real life that sees you AFK, like the doorbell ringing. You‚Äôll come back to all your stuff dead, your fellow players raging and your enemy gloating. 

- Some vehicles, particularly the medium-heavy tanks, have laughably bad pathing. A key point of the game is about hitting weaker side and rear armor; good luck striking that Panzer IV on the arse when your Cromwell tank is doing burnouts.

- Blobbing ruins this game. I don't care about your faction. 5-6 squads of infantry are just an abuse of the population cap and defeat the spirit of the game. 

The only counter to masses of infantry is to throw missiles/projectiles, or blow up with a charge, rinse and repeat.

This is meant to be a game of flank cat-and-mouse. What good is that if you can just overwhelm anything with bodies.

- Because of the variable player base, it can take HOURS to play a satisfactory online game. Expect to be sitting in the lobby twiddling your thumbs. Or, expect someone to rage quit in the first five minutes and ruin the game.

- Expert CPU is a belligerent, bona fide cheater. Nobody wants to play against CPU in multiplayer matches online for this very reason. It sees through fog of war, has ridiculous resource bonuses, and never gets tired like a human.

- Mac, Linux and PC clients can't play together online. This is more of a Feral Interactive decision, perhaps because of the code base. This means you have disparate communities for what otherwise amounts to a great and still lively fanbase.

- There will never be perfect fairness parity between factions. This is an extremely divisive point, whether allies or axis are ultimately more powerful.

Let‚Äôs talk tanks for example. German armour has high HP and deflects a lot of hits. US armour has low HP only the Jackson penetrates reliably, Soviet armour is more diverse but hardly deflects hits, British armour is expensive and sluggish. Call it historical accuracy if you will, but these are my findings.

- Games are won and lost on the fuel point.

== Here's what I recommend ==

Try it anyway. 

Despite all of its flaws, it is a good game, but it doesn't have enough redeeming quality to keep it an evergreen title.

Overall CoH 2 is a great game. The units are balanced quite differently than the original CoH. Your infantry is less vulnerable and tanks are not the death machines they used to be. The game has changed a lot since its release, but has finally become a fairly balanced game. Oberkommando West is a bit overpowered in my opinion, but I feel the same way about the original CoH's Panzer Elite faction.

I also feel some commanders are significantly better than others. In particular, I feel that commanders involving air support are some of the weakest in the game. Your air force is great for dropping paratroopers, team weapons, and supplies, but is not very effective at attacking the enemy from their planes. Why make commanders (and sell them to players) that are not very fun or competitive? Still, all five factions are fun to play. The original campaign is fun and the Ardennes Assault campaign is even better, adding an element of grand strategy to an RTS game.

I strongly object to the way the DLC is handled. Access to all of the game's units and abilities requires owning all commanders. Buying all of the commanders can be expensive and certain commanders are only available in the Relic in-game store. I have no problem with publishers making money on overpriced cosmetic DLC, but when the DLC is integral to the experience of the game, I don't think it should be treated as a cash cow.

Ok first off i do understand why most people hate this and prefer COH1 more. But personally i prefer this one because i find maintaining your units to be easy in this one rather then 1. Although  1 had better infantry  combat and a bit of a pain in the butt to get all your men in cover it was still fun. I do miss how  medics wont bring back wounded yeah.  

Yeah the armor is not super realistic and a light tank can destroy a tiger, honestly it pains me to say this i am actually ok with that in a sence. Sure it brake historical armor accuracy but it adds balance to a degree. And if you want realistic battle search the super active Workshop with tones of gamemodes and maps along with tuneing packs. And the most fun and intence part i get with the game is the "all units 150 mod & cheat commands" i use cheats to give both me and ai infinite resources so they spawn a good amount of weapons and tanks. Play it on victory points and you will fight for your life. But the way i play with infinite resources is, i use a bit what the enemy uses and try to counter then but try not to spam. And i even added tiger 1 with OKW. Now i understand the pain of DLC microtransaction but Ardennes assault is super fun and it has a replay value to it. And the 3 armies are tricky but as soon as you understand how they work they are worth it. But other then that i would say COH2 and 1 are both equal in there own gameplay style but i slightly prefer 2 over 1.

And again with the DLC i understand people hate DLC and hate needing to pay money for other commanders/Skins. Well your wrong the skins and Commanders can take a long time to obtain via loot but when you do get a Commander or enough Gold to buy one for your army you feel so rewarded as if you just obtained a gold Medal in a sport. (at least i feel that way) Mods also make the game a tone of fun.

I absolutely love the original COH (and most of the DLC). This game has none of the soul of the original; after 30 minutes I requested a refund. It generally feels like a beta version of the original. The GUI is amateur, the animations are basic and unimmersive. Examples include the fact that all soldiers in a squad are often in the exact same animation at the same time, sometimes soldiers occupy the same space. They also just walk up to enemies and don't react to incoming fire or use cover as naturally as in the original. It all just spoils the immersion and makes it feel very mechanical. Never noticed any of this in the old game.

My advice is just to replay the original game, which has plenty of depth and walks a very precise line between realistic immersion and great gameplay.

- And for the love of God, watch the f**king flanks!

Been playing the game for many hours now and i'm kinda addicted to it. yes it was not your typical RTS game which is very unique. Problem though is if you purchased Buy COH 2 - The Western Front Armies (Double Pack) - Multiplayer Standalone, the first 4 forces will be available for the multiplayer but the soviet campaign is not working at all(So technically, that is the only thing that is not working. I think the heiarchy of downloading it is Company Heroes 2 -> Buy COH 2 - The Western Front Armies (Double Pack) - Multiplayer Standalone ->Buy Company of Heroes 2 - The British Forces - Multiplayer Standalone -Buy Company of Heroes 2 - Ardennes Assault(i prefer the 2 bundle which can be purchased in the game itself instead of purchasing it in Steam. The reason for this is because if steam detected that the COH2 is already installed, it will not download the COH2 but only the others in the bundle itself.

Prefer the first one over this one, the balance is pretty bad.

If you think this is a strategy game that actually requires tactics, maybe at the top tier of the game, but most players just send out blobs of infantry in mindless waves or what I have dubbed turtle waves (spamming support units) and then if you're facing any faction + commander that can build fortifications they just spam those. 

I'm sure all the "haters" will come flowing out and start saying "Get better, get good, you're dumb or whatever". I've utilized all sorts of counters to those strats and enter the imbalance.

Massed infantry = broken if you're allies. You think your MG is going to suppress them in time? Wrong. You think two will supress? Maybe but oh wait there is their teammate with their blob. You think the few squads and a mortar will stop them? Nope, wrong again. If you're playing anything but allied factions, you're going to have a rough time. Apparently, all Axis infantry were made of torn in half paper wads and bubblegum because the wind blows the wrong direction and half of your squad is blown away.

But, wait....why don't you just play the Allied factions...well mixed bag. I have played all the factions and I would like to play all of them, but I'm not one that likes to dig in and wait for a countdown constantly. This is WW2 setting not WW1 where offensive actions were planned months in advance for just a few inches of earth. Which unless you're facing some crazy overwhelming axis players, its usually an easy win if you do this. Unless your allied teammates are failboxes.

Overall, I like the setting. I used to like the gameplay, but its a mixed bag of luck + if you learn from your own mistakes then you have to deal with poor teammates ~60% of the time until you can get to the higher tiers of players. Which good luck with that.

I have never played and replayed a game so much in my entire life.  More hours spent on this game than masturbating.  Let me put it this way:  if you like RTS games and are a WW2 history buff and you don't get this title, then F**K YOU!

Fun experience with or without achievement hunting. Should run great. Multiplayer's had updates even recently, though I only played a few matches when it really mattered to me (and when I had rather shit local internet, I might add). Might try again, but no guarantees; prefer playing games with the same people over a mic, or not at all online but with a great enough narrative in single-player.

Soviet/base game campaign has a great background narrative about it (with inconsistencies to IRL for those in the niche). The Soviet war machine is presented in both a good and bad light, so as to allow the viewer to decide whether all warfare is based (or not). Your humble beginnings in the footsteps of Lev Abramovich Isakovich will bring you from the front lines a mere footsteps away from Moskow, to fighting Germans during the harshest of Winters, to pushing the Wehrmacht lines back, all under the careful guidance of your local Commissar. Eventually you will reach the famed moment of rushing down Berlin and the Reichstag itself. Much history, wewo.

Only recommend the Ardennes Assault for the truly sadomasochistic. The Multiplayer updates entered conflict with the way the Campaign files were designed, and the Devs still weren't given permission to edit Campaign files due to some bullshit technicalities. Shame on them, honestly; the Airborne company are practically crippled from having snipers, requiring you to purchase an additional DLC for the Fox company and their "le epig" rangers, so as to replace them. The Ardennes Campaign dynamics are only somewhat predictable, and even on normal difficulty it's not uncommon to suddenly encounter a Konigtiger or a well placed Panther. With guns that big cover won't really matter. There are people that counter these, glitch through them or refresh the mission through editing or alt+f4 (=rq).

Trial and error can produce results.

(ticking the "product for free" box; I only bought Ardennes for the US hype train, in spite of my later frustration).

2022 Update: Game is getting worse. 4v4 is most played gamemode, devs balance *exclusively* around 1v1, the least played game mode *by far*.
Mathcmaking will repeatedly put the *literal best players in the entire game* against you and a team of people who barely know how to play an RTS. Reporting people is a colossal hassle, requires nebulous 'proof' that basically means "do literally everything for us and then half the time we'll tell you the screenshots you barely had time to take and the steamid and other info you found juuust aren't quite  enough for us". If YOU get banned, you get a nebulous "chat violation" with no idea whether it's certain words that are automatically filtered out by the game anyway or what.

Games balance has slightly improved outside some serious issues being patched out, but the matchmaking has gotten far, far worse. They put a rank 1000 up against literally rank 1 in 4v4 automatch. Being rank 300 means you might have a chance if you play hard, but doing 4 randoms vs. the top player who's in a premade team has no excuse.
The community is as toxic as ever, with people either going afk, belligerence, and reporting players has become *even harder* than in the past.

And in 2022 you have more maphacks than ever, RNG that is completely broken and makes no sense (Your squad has 2 models left at full health? Watch them both die on retreat at max range. Enemy squad has 1 model with no hp left? Watch them walk away POINT BLANK from 3 squads and never die). Rockets vanishing into thin air instead of missing or hitting anything, just vanishing NEXT to the target they were shot at. Rampant toxicity, and a balance team that does anything but.

Finally installed CELO to see what the actual ranks of people in matchmaking were. Turns out THAT feature is COMPLETELY broken. 4v4? You can tell who wins before the match even starts, since one team will get a literal top 10 player and 6 other people in the match will be mediocre and the remaining player will probably be opposite the top 10 guy and fail so hard they couldn't beat the tutorial.

Any positive reviews are lieing to you. The campaign is broken because the devs used the same units for multiplayer rather than keeping them separate, so that balance is 100% screwed. DLC? Game will tell you "you already own this" on Steam, but says "You don't own this" in game.

Never buying another RELIC product again. First DoW3, then finally realizing this game is specifically designed to both "be realistic war with randomness thrown in!" but also "totally legit competitive game with balance, yo!". Handed off to community balance team years ago, who focus solely on 1v1, ignoring the MOST played mode of 4v4. The FUNDAMENTAL DESIGN of this game having so much RNG prevents it from EVER being a competitive E-Sports game, yet that is precisely what the devs have pushed for for years- despite nobody wanting that.

As of 2022, the game is still unbalanced despite hundreds of changes, things that are fine got nerfed or buffed, things that are overpowered remain the go-to meta, and thing that are underwhelmed stay useless for the entire match.

Basic quality of life feature are missing, like rebinding the hotkey (yes, you read it correct, you cannot rebind a hotkeys in this supposed strategy game, if the default key does not suit your hand then sucks to be you), there is no player count during matchmaking and no rejoin during the match.

In game monetization are a grind, these are not one of those cosmetic-only items that you purchases, these things include abilities and commanders that affect the gameplay, so if what the game provided at the start does not suit you then good luck grind it for weeks until you can buy ONE new commanders.

Let's talk about grinds, when you finish a multiplayer matches the game give you 1500 score points plus 500 if you win, now for these score points when it reach 5000 it will convert into a "lootbox" that will automatically open for you. In this "lootbox" can contain new abilities or new commanders that can be useful in improving your gameplay, however most of the time you will get a random skins for your tanks (which are almost useless) or a WHOPPING 500 coins. And how much a new commander costs? 15000 coins, or you could pay up with your real money. Assuming your average match take around 30 minutes (which depends) and also assuming you win every match, you will get 1000 coins for every 3 hours, to buy a new commander you will have to play for a total of 45 hours plus whatever additional time spends in matchmaking, and this assuming you win every match (not possible for me but maybe you could), not prematurely disconnected because Relic server does not like you (which can happen often depend on the day), not crashing mid-match and most importantly the "lootboxes" consistently give you 500 coins and not some random useless tank skins that are painfully plentiful. To get what you want, you will either grind for weeks or pay with real money.

My riflemen did their best to put the sandbags up. We've already fortified 3 of 4 bridges. My reinforcements are already stacking on the line before the last two sandbags are even built. The Wehrmacht are moving in FAST to our position from the last bridge, facing our right.. A narrow passageway, one side a 30 foot drop to a river and the other side trees so thick, you couldn't fit a house dog. I order 3 Riflemen to pop smokes to make a wall between us. I had to think quick or else my unit was going to be overrun. Sacrifice sometimes comes unnoticed, and my unit was full of heroes. I sent in my finest paratrooper squad to place a timed charged within the smoke wall. As soon as they placed it, the soldiers of the beast came pouring through the smoke screen. Heavy MG fire and marksman rounds came zipping and cracking through the air. 3.2 seconds... 2.7 seconds... 0.5 seconds...
There was a ball of red, limbs, clothing, and weapons. An explosion of sacrifice, and heroism to stop an enemy from advancing too close to my Railway Guard unit. This gave us enough time to push past the sandbags, push past our fallen brothers, and take the next point. This was just for ONE point. Sometimes my battles last 2+ hours, and that's with Ai on Standard. The more strategic you play, the more fun. Can't believe I didn't play this until 2022, I definitely have been sleeping. Pick this up for CoH3 readiness :D

Solid gameplay. Units have individual upgrades and veterancy. Weapons drop in the field and that swarm of conscripts now has an anti-tank rifle or HMG or 3 of them are manning an artillery piece. Interesting mechanics because of it. Tanks are incredibly powerful vs infantry. Haven't played long RTS-style engagements as most campaign missions are more about surviving a massive amount of enemy troops with equipment appropriate for fighting them (trope used by many RTS games to introduce mechanics/strategies). Plenty of different nations to play with quite different play styles. DOES have a pay-to-win mechanic with rare and more powerful leaders but.... ugh. common

If you like RTS games, squad based especially like Dawn of War 1&2 (we don't talk about DoW3). Definitely give this a go.

Now, why did I give it a "No"? EVERYTHING IS PAY TO PLAY!!! EA Style BS. Each army besides soviet and nazi's have to be purchased individually. Want that nice Rilfeman upgrade for the new U.S. army you downloaded? PAY WALL! It is batsh!t crazy how much they skimped on the core game (one halfway decent campaign.... that's it) in order to ensure multiplayer was locked behind a truthfully MASSIVE paywall. Even now! YEARS after release. Still not bundled into a cheap pack. F()CK THIS. DoW was similar but at least had large campaigns and giant discounted packs....

Company of Heroes is the Call of Duty of the WW2 strategy genre, whereas Men of War is battlefield. More players does not equal better game as you'll find if you've played both.

I really really want to enjoy this game. I really do. I know it's an old RTS game, but for heavens sake. THE AI UNIT NAVIGATION IS LITERAL GARBAGE. I've extensively played other RTS games like SC2, C&C, etc, that are older by 10+ years and they ALL have considerably better unit navigation. It really feels like they spent 95% of the game's development in graphics and game mechanics, and 5% in everything else. Don't get me wrong. The game is pretty good for being over 9 years old. But It's really a game breaker for me when I tell a unit to do something and it decides to take literally the longest damn route to get to that location, or CONSTANTLY does it in a way where it is showing its arse towards the enemy for the majority of it's movement. While there is a feature of doing a "reverse" maneuver, it literally never works as you want it to. This is on official maps btw. I can understand some unit nav being wonky on custom maps.
Besides that, Def get the game. It's fun with players that actually when what they are doing.

For a 9-year old game, this iteration in the Company of Heroes saga improves on many aspects introduced in the first game, while adding a few novel touches.  Of course, after two or three playthroughs, the weather effects grow somewhat tiresome.  Fortunately, Relic allowed you to turn them off, so it's not really an issue.

In comparison with the first game, the unit roster is a bit more streamlined.  And the focus shifts from overwhelming the enemy with a tank rush to coordinating your strikes alongside fellow players and/or with mixed arms tactics.  The game engine itself (again 9-years old) has held up remarkably well.  Well enough to keep me playing almost a decade into the game's life cycle.

On the cusp of the CoH3 being released in less than 90 days, it was high time I dropped a review.  Hopefully, you won't need any convincing.  But, if you do, wait until a Steam Sale and pick it up along with all the expansions.  It's well worth it.

Ah yes, CoH 2. The sequel to a classic RTS. How many new ways may we appreciate the war crimes?
Well listen up gamers, I am excited to inform you that we have methods to our madness. Medics with pistols, White Phosphor gas, Flames up the wazoo- you want war crimes? We got 'em.
The beloved V-1 rocket may have been removed, but never fret. Allocate a SturmTiger and deafen everyone with the force of a Depth Charge.
Want to rain death on the battlefield? Sure, the Nebelwerfer's gone, but in place stands any form of Rocket Arty you wish - Panzerwerfer, Stuka zu Fus, Sherman Calliope, Katyusha, and Land Mattress -because the naval fun doesn't end at the sea.
Was ist das? Ju vant flammen? My brother in christ, we have flammen. SturmPioneer flammenwerfer, Pioneere flammenwerfer, Rear Echelon flamethrower, Infantry Section flamethrower, Engineer flamethrower, Flammpanzer Hetzer, halftracks with flammenwerfers, Churchill Crocodile with flamethrower. Fun doesn't stop there. Get inventive. "Clown Car" with flamethrower engineers aboard. Mortars with flame rounds. U.S. Pack Howitzers with White Phosphor rounds, U.K. Land Mattress with White Phosphor rounds. You want flames? We got flames.
You ever wanted to just go onto forums and bathe in sodium? Fear not comrade. You no longer have to delve into the pits of League of Legends. Two minutes on our fine forums will be enough salt to turn a lake into an ocean, then enough toxicity to turn the ocean into a biohazard. Or is that not your cup of tea? Cope harder on the single player matchmaking and kill AI til the end of your days. Can't even complain, 2k hours of that BS. God help me.
Needless to say, CoH2 is an experience. It's like 20$ to get the game, free if you find a special occasion (or have chad friends), and goes on sale every now and then. Throw this bad boy on your wishlist and wait, soon enough you'll get a 20$ game for 5$. Then the DLC, since those are seemingly mandatory in modern age. Get 'em on sale. Space 'em out. And buy the Western Powers pack, not the Ardennes Assault one. It does not give USF. Learnt the hard way. I spent 2k hrs alone with my thoughts, I'm not the brightest tool in the shed mkay? Regardless, if you want to kill some krauts and chill, this the game for you. This has been kamerade Kuppe, signing off.

After playing for some 350+ hours I say that you shouldn't buy this game if you don't have friends who already play this. You can't play this game alone (sure, you've 1 v 1, but that mode more competitive than fun) and coordinating with strangers is difficult.
The game is very unstable. This is the real reason I'm writing this angry review. Even if you have a decent setup like I do, the game crashes 6 out of 10 times you get into a match. You wait 5 minutes to get into a match, play hard (as Allies; the game ridiculously easy as Axis by comparison, especially against the AI) for some 20 minutes and.... surprise! The screen freezes and you drop from the game. Dropping this way doesn't give you any rewards either, so you lost half an hour of your time for nothing. I can't tolerate this nonsense anymore and I'm abandoning this game for now. Let's be real, there are plenty of other games that I own and I don't want to waste my time with a game that crashes all the time: you might want to do the same.
The base game's campaign is a pathetic. The story vilifies you-know-who. I played most chapters on all three difficulties just for the achievements. It has incorporated every conceivable stereotype there is about the war in the Eastern Front. It's depiction of the brutality of the war is fake. 
Besides the community can be dreadfully toxic at times. Plus your typical Axis player spams "izi, good game" when they are winning and quit the moment they lose a few vehicles. I recommend practicing against the hard AI (DO NOT try to play against expert AI); and since it's AI, there is very little room for toxicity. 
The Allied armies are not strong enough and playing them will probably remain difficult for new players. The game is unbalanced since it's said that the developers care only about feedback from a small minority of competitive players (Don't believe me? I believe I've written enough.

If you're used to other RTS or strategy titles, this game will be a significant downgrade in quality. Situational awareness is arbitrarily difficult from "features" like the zoom level and units. Game is very linear in strategy and tactics and leaves little room for flexibility outside of some basic rock paper scissors, Unit responsiveness and pathfinding can have issues leading to a loss in relative material and reacting by instinct and memorized strategies are the only ways to improve.

However, if you've never played a strategy game or dont like them, it'll be easy to pickup and makes for a decent first choice. Graphics are nice and gameplay is easy to learn.

This game has many valid criticisms. It launched with bad monetization. It lacks a lot of the tactical finesse of the previous entry. This makes it devolve into a tank rush grind. I guess they wanted us to really feel like we were sending wave after wave of expendable conscripts into the meat grinder. Well, mission accomplished, I guess. And, the challenge levels are really lacking in personality and narrative. You might say that's not required. But, you could say the same thing about the main campaign. It was still nice to see cinematics, and flavor dialogue in them.

What isn't a valid criticism is the complaints a lot of Russian fans had about the unflattering portrayal of the Soviets. I guess they wanted a game titled "Company of Heroes" to emphasize the heroism of the Soviet soldiers. And yes, while it did have some of that, it could have done it more. But, I don't think showing the faults of Communist Russia was a mistake.

(Oh and as a quick aside, on the subject of current events with the Ukraine, [spoiler]I'm more sympathetic of Russia than most of my fellow Americans. Then again, military aggression is military aggression; and Putin just didn't have casus belli to do what he did. Saying there were Nazis, or at least people who self-identified as such, on the Ukrainian side doesn't change that.[/spoiler])

The game showed the Russian Army (1)burning fields with their own soldiers in it, (2)blowing a bridge with their troops still on the other side, (3)shooting retreating soldiers, (4)abandoning the Warsaw Uprising to the Nazis, (5)killing Poles. (6)It was strongly implied that they were committing war crimes against German civilians. And, (7)they put dissidents into the gulag. Or, as one Russian put it about this game, "They would have us believe that each one Russian was in the gulag; and each other Russian was guarding them." I'm sorry though, what CoH 2 showed was a lot closer to truth than to slander.

Sure, I imagine that if the NKVD set fields alight with their own soldiers in them it was with the belief they would be able to escape the flames. The Russian Pole murder we know about was the Katyn massacre, not during the Warsaw Uprising. And, the shooting retreating soldiers things is debatable. Mind you there were blocking units, and their guns were not for show. Then again every army in the world has military police that may have the same duty in a desperate war. I mean, why do you think U.S. M.P.s have Ma Deuces?

Which brings us to the bridge thing. I'm certain that happened. Why? Because, just as every army in the world has a doctrine for blocking units, every army in the world has clear doctrine for what you do with a bridge rigged to blow, your own soldiers still on the other side, and the enemy in sight. That's S.O.P. You blow the bridge. Every time. Mind you, the thinking is your soldiers should be able to, abandon their vehicles, and swim across, with your forces providing covering fire.

As for the abandoning the Warsaw Uprising, that's another debatable one. The Russians claimed a German counter-offensive prevented them from relieving the city. Though German accounts are a bit lacking in their successfully driving off the Soviet advance.

The war crimes against German civilians, especially the rape of 10s, if not 100s, of thousands of German women, and girls, is well documented. The Soviet Army leadership didn't even deny this. They sort of took the attitude of "boys will be boys". (Yeah put that in your toxic masculinity ad' Gillette.}

As for the gulags, look the Soviet economy sucked. And there was a drive to ideologically purify the Russian people. They needed slave labor; and they needed to do something with the millions of citizens who needed to be reeducated into being better Communists. The gulags were seen as a way to solve both problems at once.

Gotta say it's a pretty engaging game.  A friend convinced me to give this a go because he likes it more than AoE2, the other RTS we have in common.  In many ways this is really 'basic' in comparison.  It doesn't feel like a serious game: the online wiki is trash, balance is questionable, games at a similar level seem to have a huge luck component with massive swings in results (just look at the AI stats after the game), the number of playable factions is amazingly limited (the base game is basically germany or russia, that's it).  You can't even change the hotkeys, you need to install a third party script to hack your keyboard to fix it!!

But... it's a great, chill RTS where you don't need to stress much about your build orders and your economy, you can focus on your troops and engagements and use of the terrain and map control.  It's now basically my go to chill game

To be honest, next to StarCraft, this is my favorite RTS of all time. Going on nearly ten years old, you'd be hard pressed to find any RTS games within that time frame that remotely hold up against CoH2. While not perfect, I do love this game. 

The factions all feel very unique from one another, which is no easy feat since there are no genetic differences. A lot of RTS games rely on fictional races to differentiate between factions, which is not bad by any means. The combat is addicting and challenging. It has very competitive levels while also chill levels in co-op and big 4v4 games where stress is taken off of you as an individual player. The community is also really solid, and you'll find great videos on YouTube and streams on Twitch.

The campaigns are also really engaging and tell good stories. While I imagine some of the Soviet story has some exaggerations, it tells a dark tale of a Lieutenant becoming a reporter after being wounded in battle. Truly a well told story for an RTS. The Ardennes campaign - DLC - is also great by engaging the player with three companies of American troops for the Ardennes campaign during WW2. Ranger company is DLC. 

To be honest, the only negative thing I have to say about the game is SEGA's handling of monetization. They do the same thing with Total War as well. They nickel and dime you for commanders, factions, etc. Thankfully I got everything on sale. The game is old, so it's easy to get the stuff pretty cheap. 

The game has a steep learning curve, but don't get frustrated. Just keep at it, and you'll enjoy it like me. Can't wait for CoH3!

Great WW2 strategy games. Control small squads, mechanized units, tanks, and offmap support to achieve your objective. Whether that be a workshop ruleset, Victory Points, or simple Annihilation, CoH 2 has all the right pieces to feel like the commander of an army. Has both single player and multiplayer. The former more story driven unique setpieces and the latter a deep pool of gameplay, especially with the ability to utilize the Steam Workshop for mod content.
The game is challenging, and in scenarios where pause is disabled, the pressure can really ramp up.
When you are neck and neck with your opponent and multiple fights are breaking out across the map, you may struggle to keep up with the pace of everything. Learning keybindings, squad grouping, and cover advantages will be key to tipping battles in your favor.
CoH 3 is on the horizon, and longtime players are looking to move to the latest and greatest, but that doesn't mean there isn't game to play here. I spend a significant portion of my time against custom AI arrangements and still manage to have a challenging good time. I personally recommend picking up the camera zoom playmodes, as the standard camera range is uncomfortably restricted. There is some graphical and gameplay fidelity but it is worth it in my opinion for the better battlefield visibility.
DLC content isn't mandatory, but certainly expands the available scenarios and playstyles. If you are hesitant about starting out, pick it up on sale without any DLC and try it out. Most people will quickly pick up if this is their game or not.

In comparison to its release state this game has been massively improved over the years. Multiplayer was dominated by a lot of shady commanders strongly resembling P2W and questionable map balance in the early years, followed by times of mixed developments. The start of dedicated community involvement in terms of faction balancing and map design has sparked an age of massive improvements for this game. This was quite obvious the case in the last years. Faction and map balance might not be as polished as in other RTS games, but are in a great spot currently, despite the perceived lack of a long-term strategic vision from the developer and/or publisher.

While Company of Heroes 2 has introduced criticizable changes and innovations, such as a simplified resource point system and the blizzard mechanic, it stays true to the spirit of its legendary predecessor. In order to succeed in the game's unique style of tactical skirmishes, adaptive and smart decision making, such as proper unit positioning, is demanded rather than pure APM-based micromanagement of units. Yes, you will need a certain amount of APM to succeed in the game's automatch games, however, the threshold is far lower than in other RTS games.

With the help of community activity and involvement Company of Heroes 2 has become one of the pillars of the RTS genre. In fact, this game has eclipsed a lot of newly released RTS competitor games, such as Grey Goo, Dawn of War 3 and Iron Harvest, and its playerbase is still quite healthy today. When analyzing the recent "30-Day Avg." statistic in Steam Charts (27th June 2022), Company of Heroes 2 even outperformed Age of Empires IV by a small margin, reinforcing the fact how dedicated the community is.

As a former long-term player having focused on 1vs1/2vs2 I highly recommend Company of Heroes 2 for every RTS enthusiast.

Who in their right minds would want to see the "Warhammer 40,000" guys take on actual history? Surprise! They don't do a very good job with it! It's true there is a lot of WWII "media" that's in pretty appalling taste, but this one is *especially* offensive. It's not a "fun" kind of offensive either, thanks to a half-baked campaign and broken multiplayer. There is none of the sadistic glee of "Carmageddon" or "Postal 2" in "CoH2", only a dreary revisionism cribbed from Hollywood trash, and systems and mechanics cribbed from Relic's better earlier RTSes. Those who want to learn the actual history of WWII, and want a compelling RTS experience, would both be better off replaying "Red Alert"

Ok well, I used to enjoy playing this even though it has huge flaws, like way too low pop limit & the fact there is only one axis nation & the fact the you have to play the campaigns in vanilla & they pretty much suck in vanilla, cos you cannot use mods. Also not keen on the fact the game mostly concentrates on winter warfare & really don't like the way they have implemented that. Also there are only 2 proper campaigns, both allied :/ The only German ones aren't really proper campaigns just a series of missions, they are set early in the war (1941) but the proper equipment isn't supplied ie no Russian T26's BT tanks etc, plus no German Panzer III, which was the main Battle tank of that period! SMH. Having said that I did enjoy playing the skirmish maps using MODS that really brought the game to life & that was the only reason I enjoyed the game. Sadly though now all the thing does is crash on me a few minutes into each  map so I have finally given up with it. :/

This game is incredible! If you like strategy games, then this game is definitely up your alley! The combat is paced well, and working together with your team to outsmart your opponents is really exciting! The feeling of out flanking a dug in position, or working your way around the back of a tank and crippling it so your AT gun can get in the perfect shot; its not something that any other RTS game I've played has made me feel! The campaigns may be a bit rough around the edges, and the Ardenne Forest DLC may have a lot of kinks in it since the game has been updated so many times, but they're still great fun if you're able to look past that! The multiplayer really is where this game shines though; if you see this game on sale I would definitely pick it up! I rate it a solid 8 out of 10; it would be higher but as I said, the single player aspect of this game can be rather lacking at times.

Ah, Company of Heroes 2, a wonderful game. As you can see by the hours there is a lot of fun to be had in this game. If your into WW2, tactical strategy, or stories of the past then I would recommend you try this game. You can learn quite a bit about WW2 from this game, mainly the weaponry of the war. Now if your in it only for the story while it has a good one, Company of Heroes 1 had multiply good and great ones. If any of that sounds appealing then go and purchase the game. I would recommend (If you have the money) to by the bundle with the major DLCs and other game.

Good, respectful war game. The Soviet campaign was good. Its cold mechanics were cool though I wish they'd persisted through more missions. There were a good mix of objectives and the pace was great... although sometimes it seemed too easy to sit back and relax without being harassed meaningfully by the enemy. 

On the other hand the US Forces Ardennes Assault campaign was a mess. Its grand strategy and progression elements were commendable ideas but turned out to be more frustrating than fun. The lack of a proper save/load function is what killed it for me, as unless you're the gamer equivalent of the 101st Airborne the difficulty is... Nuts!

Im going to start this review by saying that this game is a gem that worked on for a long time to bring it to the amazing state it is now.

So lets talk about the story part of them game. Yes it does show soviets as blood hungry monsters that make you sometimes sympathise with the germans but that has been the theme in every game of this period. USA story brings you to the ardennes forrest and its a great bit of fun. I do recommend them both.

Now on the multiplayer. My god the cinematic competitve gameplay is something that will have your mind blown. The screaming amazing voicelines of the infrantry, the roaring of the engines from tanks and light vehicles. I never had a copmetitive style game immerse so hard into its self that i feel like a genuine general during a war.
The community in my almost 1,7k hours has been pretty helpful and kind. Ofcourse there are toxic people but many others over exaggerate the amount of it (Dont worry this is not League of Legend or CSGO). It takes sometime to pick up the games mechanics but nothing too crazy.

Now onto the DLC. Honestly pick up the platinum edition from Instant gaming or where ever if you dont want to spend the full price but i did buy my the legit way to support Relic.

All in all to end it here i will say you will not make a mistake by buying this game, it is one of the best RTS games out there and its great bit of fun with the 3rd instalment on the horizon.

Hope to see new faces on the battlefield :D

For those who have played multiple games and know the difference between a shooter for fun and a tactical one, Company of Heroes is like games like Battlefield or even a Counter Strike... it's a game to have fun but where the mechanics of Game elements are very streamlined, as is the ballistics!

Unlike its rival MEN OF WAR ASSAULT SQUAD 2 where a tank has ballistic penetration points, has weaknesses in specific points and can even ricochet small and large caliber weapons where the projectile can hurt allied or even enemy troops. , the tank crew can not only be disembarked but everyone has personal inventory as well as the vehicle too!

Ammo expenditure, fuel and many other factors were thought of in MEN OF WAR, which is different in COMPANY OF HEROES, in this the focus is on tactical fun without being tied to many individual details, troops and some vehicles have special powers conferred that faction, yet both super fun games for lovers of a good RTS.
