This game is decent honestly, but the more i stroll around looking for other games i find Company of Heroes as a franchise to be really underwhelming, with the second piece especially uninspiring. More than anything else, CoH2 increases the monetization capacity without all too new mechanics or units. CoH2 is not much more than a DLC with extra DLC on top of it , when compared to CoH1 and i don't think the "upgrade" is worth the money. I feel like there are 2 situations where i find this game a somewhat recommendable purchase: 1. You don't have CoH1, 2. You are new to strategy games overall.

I find this game to fail at delivering an authentic experience. Units unable to fire more than 50 meters, unprotected soldiers surviving a million shots, Tanks having a really unrealistic damage calculation, leaving you with extreme RNG and sometimes weapons are just so underwhelming compared to their visuals. A direct hit of a 75mm Shell, causing a big explosion and a 10 m dustcloud, on a single soldier? Nothing, The soldier will take 5 more of those. The same shot hitting a Tank? Blasted into oblivion. I get that that is by design to keep the competetive integrity, but it just feels so underwhelming. 

The AI, both for AI-Opponents as well as for your units is aged at best, or bad at worst. Giving orders will function quickly, but units executing the order just does not. A movement order will see your infantry collecting at the center of their formation before running to where you commanded them to go every now and then, making explosives extremely powerful everytime this happens. 

In my honest opinion games like Men of War or Steel Division are way more enjoayble experiences, since what happens on screen makes sense, with CoH there is almost no logical link between what happens visually and what happens statistically. That combined with the fact that the main step made by CoH2 is reused DLC's and assets from CoH1, combined with an ingame shop for gameplay affecting items that are extremely slow to obtain by playing just doesn't do enough for me to give it a positive. I don't hate the game, but i find it to be a below average product.

I love the gameplay !

I have rarely played something so unbalanced. As British you can struggle to counter just one tank, swing and miss with several AT, Bofors, tanks, whatever, while the opponent can just drive around being fucking care with one tank. You are lucky enough to have a tank? Better keep an eye on it, because it can get wasted in a second by just a bunch of troops with AT (who rarely miss, like yours). Or better, you finally got one tank, havent even used Fuel on Bofors, but hey, the enemy have 5 OP tanks ready to destroy you, along with their OP infantry, even thou they lost all the resource points. Hella fun!

You know the tank spam are coming, but even with several AT ready, you need so many hits to take out just one tank, and mostly they just drive away before that and come back with even more tanks. Only way to win is if the enemy makes a blunder and that rarely happens on higher levels. Even if you build a freakin TANK DESTROYER, the shot just does nothing on higher lvl AXIS tanks, I mean WTF.

But sure, let me try to micro like a MF and struggle to see if I can get lucky and wheel my AT in position without losing them aswell. Then pray that the enemy dosent notice the 10 hits i need to take down one tank before he moves it, or just run me over with 4 units of mid ranged SMG¬¥s and whipe me in a second. 

Luckily I got the Bofors and AT cannon. Two static positions that can just be bombarded as soon as discovered by the enemy. Or just smoked off and spammed with the AT troops. Great way to waste resources.

But no worries, really, really late, you can make one decent tank on the same level as your enemy. Only problem is all that time you have been harrased by better tanks and the enemy now have 5 of them. GL Chump!

Company of Heroes 2 or CoH 2 it's a far rewarding experience in the RTS genre. You're tied anymore with the triad (harvest, produce, upgrade), where the player capable to expand earlier has the advantage. 

In the CoH series, we can see supply points, such as:

- Manpower
- Ammo
- Fuel

In several moments through a match, you can take advantage (or depend of) one of those resources. Each supply point will be fought fiercely and sometimes, only one extra point can give a tactic advantage leading you to the victory!

Playing 1x1 , 2x2, 3x3 or 4x4, you combine several types of tactics using Commanders or Intel Bulletins. Some will match with your own strategies or can be decisive to support your allies in a push for victory!

I've playing CoH 2 for years and it's a grateful surprise see this game is still being updated (We got a more stable 64-bit version of the game a couple of years ago!). The community creates their own ladders and Championships, keeping the flame lit, of this great WWII RTS game!

I'm eagerly waiting for CoH 3. The legacy still goes ON!

This game is fantastic and has a ton of depth in the gameplay and strategy. It's quite a bit different from usual RTS games as it heavily rewards keeping your units alive which is frankly a bit of fresh air from many others where swaths of units are laid waste only to be instantly replaced. The controls are a bit difficult to pick up, but once you've got it down it's very satisfying the amount of control you have over the battlefield and your units. This game really rewards both strategy at micro and macro levels. If you are interested in the subject matter and like RTS, this game is definitely worth a look.

A word of warning is that it has a fairly steep learning curve, even more so if you are a veteran of RTS. It plays quite a bit differently and takes some getting used to. Additionally, the community surrounding this game and its multiplayer can be very toxic. I would highly recommend playing with friends or finding people to play with through discords/reddits etc. The random matchmaking can be really hit or miss, both for matching proper skill level and for wild fluctuations in toxicity.

Overall, its a great game that WW2 enthusiasts will likely love.

Company of Heroes 2 the second installment to the series is a great overall improvement to its predecessor. The Campaign follows the Russian offensives against the German advances during World War 2. You can also play other Campaigns through DLC. From the famous "Battle of Stalingrad" to the historical "Capturing of the Reichstag" you will put yourself in the position of how the Soviets overcame the unstoppable German blitzkrieg. 

The game is quite simply an amazing real time strategy. With improved graphics, terrain, explosions, sounds and of course the addition of units (some that dont come into play until the later years of the war). The game must be played precise and approached in a strategic manner, world war 1 tactics will not work here. There are times when units vs units collide, one will always have the advantage over the other. You have to include support, abilities that can be attained to aid in your advances, you must protect your economy (i.e munitions and fuel). At times you must be cautious of ambush, or at times you will be pressured to take an aggressive position more than a defensive one in terms of being bombarded by say a German Haftrack with multiple rocket launchers.

I believe the best action in this game is the might of the tanks of the factions. From the German heavy tanks such as the famed "King Tiger" and the monstrous "Elefant". To Russia's answer of the IS- 152 named after Stalin himself and other notables such as the T34 and the KV series. The precision and attention to detail is highlighted and weaknesses are shown depending on your position and angle or approach of the attacking. It really does show that when a minor tank such as German Stug tries firing on a IS-152, the shells just bounce off. However watching the IS-152 returning fire, I did enjoy the full force of a heavy shell hitting it and rocking the chassis like a chair. Tanks are also prone to being ambushed by anti tank guns such as the notorious PAK43 88mm and the Panzerschreck.

In closing, a quite incredible and fun game to play. A must play if you are interested in realistic War based RTS. I do look forward to the next installment of Company of Heroes 3!

My thoughts on this game have changed. I would not recommend to buy this game. Though the core game is fun, and I respect several aspects of this game. The direction on which this game has taken since the original developers dumped it have taken a horrible turn. 

Firstly with respect to campaign and theater of war. 
Several of the DLC Ardennse missions are bugged and with the original game code locked away, there is no hope of fixing them. (tank grab missions don't allow German controlled vehicles to actually be destroyed, or recaptured, especially on the harder difficulties)
Several Theater of war missions are drastically impossible and cannot be completed on all difficulties because of the impossible bonuses the enemy ai have acquired from the modding community in recent years. (Tiger ace, Oka river, and Kharkov pursuit are the three I know of and have persisted in trying to beat)
Other then that, several campaign achievements and theater of war/ skirmish achievements are now totally unachievable due to changes the mods have made to callable off map units, or bugs within the campaign code. (since the campaign code is locked from public, those achievements are locked, the others include issues with Partisans and German light cav units)

Secondly Multiplayer.
The community mods have taken a direction that seems totally passive for allowing illegal mods and droppers to persist. There are in fact several playbacks on various media platforms that shows blatant and disregarded hacks coming from playing multiplayer across the pacific ocean. These hacks are always summarized as basic loopholes or *chance* but never investigated even though several very true players crunch manpower ammunition and fuel consumption and some spawned vehicles or abilities should not be accessible. The other side of the multiplayer problem is that the community mods will never try to ban or punish people for intentionally dropping, or accidentally dropping but repeatedly. An example of this, is that I have personally encountered one person who would drop an auto-match ai game, regardless of difficulty just because it was a map they didn't like consistently (4 recorded times). After I tried to call them out for it, I was actually berated and warned for it. Seems totally fair right?

lastly to Community Mod behavior.
The last thing that happened that altered my attitude toward the game was A constructive criticism that I made on the discussion page. After posting it, and continually commenting on it for about a week. I was reported to steam community on *language* for a post that literally had zero *language* on it. The most offensive thing that was said between myself and another player was "POOPOO GARBAGE" in regards to poor and unbalanced ai scripting for campaign and skirmish battles. Note I did suggest a few options that I thought would make for better ai game play so the post would not constitute negative feedback. 

Summary.
Over all I'm almost ashamed to have played this game for so long (current playtime is about 1800 hours) when the original developers and a multiplayer only minded mod community have cared so little about what players want and actually need for the game to continue to thrive. DON'T BUT THIS GAME! At this point, there's zero community support and overall the game is a waste of money. Thankfully they are working on a third game that will hopefully be better monitored for hacking and community support then this seemingly failed project of theirs.

There seems to be alot of confusion among the community about the differences between this game (apex legends 2) and company of heroes. Many were turned off that with the second iteration the developers chose to go with a rustic WW2 European theme. I feel this lends itself well to gameplay and allows gamers to explore scenarios they otherwise couldn't . Simply a masterpiece really, definitely worth the download size. If your friends are still confused and are asking you to play company of heroes, kindly remind them that the true title is apex legends, and you'd be happy to play. You'd be happy to experience visceral WW2 squad based strategy combat. If they wanted to experience squad based first person battle royale, they would invite you play company of heroes.

Up to 4v4 (we play vs AI most of the time) top down WWII RTS game. The maps have a decent amount of destruction, allowing for a fairly dynamic battlefield. You command units in squads, moving your infantry into cover and flanking positions, constructing field guns, sandbags, and bunkers, and positioning your tanks in important locations. Super fun to play and it provides a decent sense of improvement as you get better and better... I found a mod that lets infantry ride on my T-34s as well. If a flamethrower squad on top of a tank isn't enough to sell you on a game I don't know what is.

This is the best RTS game I have played so far. Even including classics such as Starcraft, Warcraft, Command & Conquer and so on. 

Having said that, the game does have a tendency to nerf on faction so that it is significantly weaker than the others. In the beginning, the British were made out of paper and very static, so playing with them against anything except AI opponents was a challenge. The Soviets were also quite soft, but they made up for that with numbers. Their tanks were cheaper and they had some very good artillery and other indirect fire.

The Americans have always been resonably good. (The Americans usually are in any game, for some reason...) The Axis have two main army types in the OKW and the Wehrmacht. The OKW USED TO give you an edge with their main builder troops being very good for close range combat, but they were nerfed so now the only think OKW has is the ability to build base structures elsewhere than in the starting area. (Sort of like the British in the first game.) The Wehrmacht is ok, but also nerfed nowadays. The downside of playing with the Germans used to be that they cost a lot but they were always very good units. Nowadays, they both cost a lot AND are made out of paper.

[h1] Overwhelming newbie battle with stiff controls & one jilion features [/h1] 

[h2] Game play feels like eating a soup with a fork, or using your mouse with the chopsticks [/h2]
You have to Micromanage with Crude, Crap controls. Half the time your troops don't respond to move orders, or take the wrong cover. Sometimes half the unit randomly stands in front of cover it's supposed to be behind, while the other half is properly behind it. Expect your mouse to be stuck in some [i](what feels like)[/i] multi-step command preventing you from executing a completely separate command. You will find yourself mashing Esc key a lot to exit from whatever bullshit multi-step command you're in. Unit selection and control is major pain point as well - it's many little things that happen often.

[h2] Game is like those massive Swiss-Army knifes - a bunch of functions & you got no clue what half them are and what they do  [/h2]
There is pretty much no tutorial: 1 tutorial mission that goes over the basic movement, cover and flanking. Not much else is explained, so once you go to campaign, most of the time you feel like you don't understand WTF is happening & what you're supposed to do. Units have many abilities most of which are not explained, apparently there also are a bunch of in-game purchase commanders that allow you to have even more troops with special abilities. Barely anything is covered, of course. Funny enough - the tutorial only goes over some of the German troops, while the only available campaign is Soviet - thanks game, it was sure useful.

[h2] Game is fun if you're the type of person that enjoys doing homework or preparing for assessments  [/h2]
Not having a clue about what I'm doing, I turned online to hopefully learn what was left out in the tutorial. There are a bunch of separate tips&tricks videos, however if you want to learn anything of substance, you'll find yourself spending more time searching for info & watching videos of game play, than you'll spend time playing the game. Reminds me of when I was going to college & had to be preparing power point presentations for assessments about a thing, rather than actually doing a thing.

What I have also learned online is that you're expected to memorize many different troops [i](there are a lot of those)[/i] and their abilities just so you wouldn't get absolutely wrecked. I can see how this can be fun from a veteran perspective - means there is a lot of content & strategies. However, what this means for newbie player is that you'll need to be memorizing a bunch of shit - an experience reminiscent of preparing of an exam. The game has a steep learning curve & you should expect to keep on getting wrecked and not understand why, until you memorize enough little details, or until by pure chance through sheer quantity of time wasted you'll stumble across a sequence of actions that tend to work for the most part.

I was pretty surprised to see a fun strategy game in COH2. I was expecting a game with slow and laborious units with little territory gains, instead I got a point capture game with multiple strategic elements. My original post recommended this game. However, after I encountered so many BUG SPLAT errrors and disconnects. I've decided to thumb it down. It's also Pay To Win. They were selling the rare British commanders (Blue) for cash.

$9.75+$5+$3.25

[h1][b]PROS[/b][/h1]
1. No Bob-the-builder
You don't have to build many production facilities to mass produce your armies. It really helps that you don't have to worry about issues like trapping your units within your building maze.

2. Model Orientation
Having a zone of fire, front and back armour, angled shots and wall blocking really helped in creating strategy for the game. This is the one thing I don't really see in other Real Time Strategy Games, rushing from the front or the back yields the same result for other games.

3. Campaign
A lot of historical significance from World War II. I am unsure of its accuracy but I do hope that they got important details like dates, names, locations, who won and what went on correct.

4. Unit Cap / Pop Cap
Works pretty well. Having lesser units to control helps to balance the game for those with lower Actions Per Minute (APM)

5. Retreat
Very convenient button. It's good to use when you want your troops to run fast and back to base. Don't know why only infantry have them. Vehicles do not have retreat functions oddly.

6. Terrain and Weather
Surprisingly, there are a lot of interesting terrain. Ice which breaks when fire upon or when heavy tanks run over. Snow and Mud which affects your movement. Blizzards which kill your infantry (don't really like this one since tanks seems invulnerable to blizzards, making them more valuable).

[h1][b]CONS[/b][/h1]
1. DLC, DLC, DLC
Everything I see on the store page is DLC, DLC, DLC. It is annoying to know that you can't play certain sides unless you splash out the dough. I've heard that there are expansion packs but you can see that they are divided into smaller packs.

2. Retreat
You can't stop the troops mid way of a retreat. They run all the way back to base. I would prefer a retreat that lets you choose either 50% or 100% of the distance back. Why? Because some times I just want to flank and I need to move fast, but retreating at 100% means I have to call them at base.

3. No quick end strategy
There is no zerging in this game. You can't just end the game early as all bases have machine guns and infantry die very easily to them. I don't know if this is actually that bad.

4. Mine placement
Very, very slow and tiny. No circle to show the radius of explosion. They only work well with chokepoints. I was hoping if they could make a grid (minefield) instead of an extended line. Since the mines cost ammunition to plant, players can't spam them abitrarily. Also, more mines would make mine detection actually useful. You could also add abilities to scan for mines that way.

5. Mine sweeping
Absolutely redundant. If there is a mine, there is usually a machine gun guarding the location. Thus, the engineer will have trouble removing it. Never played a game where engineers needed mine detection.

6. T1<T2<T3
Most games I played tend to be won by high-tech tank domination. The game seems to end only when one side builds up their most powerful heavy armour tanks e.g. Tiger Ace, Panther, KV-8, Elefant. I don't really remember games when light and medium tanks won.

This is a linear strategy that obsoletes infantry in the end-game. Instead of T1 being weaker thant T3, how about Infantry (Barracks) vs Tanks (Workshop) vs Planes (HQ)? 

7. Bug Splat Errors ******
Too many to count. Every time someones disconnects it's usually a Bug Splat error or a map problem. The game isn't complete at all. The errors just occur randomly or when servers are full.

[h1][b]SUGGESTIONS[/b][/h1]
1. Infantry (Barracks) vs Tanks (Workshop) vs Planes (HQ)? 
Higher tier infantry would include Commandos, SS, spies and codebreakers (maphack). Think Tanya from Command & Conquer with sticky bombs that damage and disable tank treads.

Once upon a time this game was a work of art. Each of the five factions had a unique playstyle and with the selection of commanders at your fingettips you could either specialize your playstyle or operate on a premise similar to another faction. All of your decisions had weight and an uphill struggle could turn in your favor with the placement of a single mine or HMG while at the same time a single mine or HMG could ruin your entire deployment. With buildable cover, a destructible world and five different armies to play around with this game has given me years of fun. And it was fun, it was special, its consumed five years of my life. Once upon a time I would have given this game glowing reviews.

But now the game is different. Everything changed when a very specific country invaded. The war is the same and we use the same tools but the rules of engagement have been rewritten. No longer do your tactics matter much so long as you keep your men alive and your company has the bigger blob. The tide of battle can be changed with a single mine or a single artillery shell but you can't do it alone. This game is utterly unplayable now if you don't have a premade team, it was a challenge before and if you won despite the odds the victory felt significant. No longer. Now you struggle to fight battles and keep your teammates in the game. As soon as the battle starts to go downhill you'll find your teammates dropped from the game. They leave you alone to get stomped by 1-4 enemy players that copied the tactics used by a very specific country to win EVERY SINGLE GAME and even though the players from that country are gone the scars are lasting... and they took the fun with them. This game is no longer special. This game is no longer a work of art. Its just work. Just the cheapest tactics and the most frustrating gameplay. Now the game plays like any other RTS games and the things that made CoH2 special just don't matter anymore. If you‚Äôre a fan of RTS and like WW2 this is definitely the game that will fit that bill and it does it very well.

It has everything you‚Äôd expect from a AAA title to good graphics, sounds, gameplay, good control setup, unit variety and the number of factions (with the DLCs). At the time of this writing, the game is coming close to 20k reviews with a mostly positive rating which really speaks volumes on how this game is. 

This game is great as it offers huge replayability for not only multi-players but also for solo skirmishers. 

If you‚Äôre the single player type this game has you covered. It offers the traditional campaign with difficulty and if that‚Äôs not enough you can grab additional mission packs. You can also skirmish vs the AI you can even team skirmish vs the AI so that you can enjoy larger battles all without ever having to play with another human.

If you‚Äôre the super competitive multi-player type? It has the usual 1v1 complete with rankings. There are still tournaments held to this day. It also has team vs team modes up to 4v4 so that you and your buddies (or random players) can play against opposing teams.

And the real beauty of this game is that it even offers something in between. 

Don‚Äôt like being super competitive but enjoy playing with others? Well this gem of a game offers an online co-op skirmish with other players against the AI with whatever difficulty setting suits you. When going through the list of games you can watch that are currently being played, this mode is one of if not the most played.

I felt it important to really give props to Relic Entertainment for remembering that there are different types of players and providing mulitple even for all players to fully enjoy the game. I felt it important because it‚Äôs something some other developers seem to have forgotten some time ago.

There are some balancing issues that have always existed in this game, with the amount of commanders and things that need it and specialty units someone is generally going to have a pretty good idea on how to find something really strong. Add in a mix of RNG with the pathing and damage system and you've got a recipe to find yourself quickly frustrated by how hard this game can punish you with extra bad luck for a lapse of micromanagement. 
My biggest gripe has to be the commanders and things, they are all fun with small buffs that practically do nothing but take forever to get. In my 450 hours of playing I haven't ever earned enough supply to buy a single commander only unlock them.

and yeah i know about upgrades to them, and adding tools like the flame throwers and MG42's, and the healing capabilities for the Russian conscripts... but those mean little to nothing if the player cant survive past the start of the game and face a force that is already 3 times their size...

A still solid World War 2 RTS.
  The game has aged well and it still looks great. Units are detailed and well animated, maps are interesting and well crafted. Visually, I liked the old fortified cities of Poland the most. Sound and music are good, the English voice-over with Russian accent is, well, a feature. Live with it, comrade. From technical standpoint, I had to search the forums and lock framerate via run options, otherwise it would not start.
  The gameplay is a solid CoH-style experience, missions are varied and fun. My only gripe is an occationally bad pathfinding, especially for larger (and slower) vehicles. This was a source of frustration in some of the urban maps towards the end of the campaign. The story is interesting, going over the Great Patriotic War and its brutal fighting.

The winning formula of Company of Heroes was tinkered with for its sequel, which results in a comparatively "cheap" feel of the title. Units now spawn from the edges of maps instead of from their respective source buildings, unit cost is now much higher than previously resulting in a smaller scale of warfare, and a heavy emphasis on "loot crates" is now front-and-center.

The "cold tech" that was introduced gave absolutely no gameplay benefit/improvement and most of the time you'll find yourself turning it off or choosing non-winter maps.

I grew up with COH 1, back in the day where you could buy games on a disk. 
It was a great game, a very great game. So complex and deep my simple mind couldn't comprehend it.

Now, grown up and many more years in. 10 years after release. I still come back to it from time to time. My taste in games changed, but my love for COH 2 didn't.
The game has such a depth, such complex plays - so many facets and mechanics that interlock, synergies and complete each other - to describe it in detail, you would take ages. 

But to sum it up in a little speech:

My friends, it has often been said that I like war.

My friends, I like war...

No, friends, I love war!

I love holocausts.

I love blitzkriegs.

I love defensive lines.

I love sieges, charges, I love mop-up operations, and retreats.

Wars across prairies, in streets, in trenches, in grasslands, in frozen tundras, through deserts, on the sea, in the air, I love every act of war that can occur upon this earth.

I love blasting the enemy to smithereens with artillery salvos that thunder across the lines of battle.

My heart leaps with joy whenever a soldier is tossed high into the air and cut to pieces by well placed sniper rounds. And there is nothing like a tank operator using a Tiger acht acht  to destroy enemy tanks. And the feeling that comes when a soldier runs screaming from his blazing tank, only to be mowed down by heavy machine gun fire, is such an exquisite feeling. 

I love it when my forces are ravaged by a Russian armored division. It's so sad to see towns and villages that were supposed to be defended at all costs, being laid to waste.

I love to be squashed under the heel of the British and American war machines. The humiliation as my men crawl around like vermin, ducking the jagdbombers flying overhead.

My friends, I love war.

A stunning RTS game with decent graphics for the year it was released in. 

Unique physics and unit movements. Combat is a very in-depth, especially for the dozens of tanks available with things like penetration of tanks, bouncing shells, damaged engines and a lot of other different modifiers that make tank and vehicle combat quite entertaining and are very important mechanics for the game and the way it's played. There are a variety of infantry units each with their own abilities and equipment, which specialise at different kinds of combat, so you can experiment with different tactics.

Multiple factions to choose from and a variety of in-game commanders each with their own exclusive abilities like bombing strikes, close air support, elite infantry, elite tanks and much much more to add flavour to the already heated engagements.

The campaign missions are quite interesting and provide an alternate experience to the PvP one. There are also Theater of War scenarios, where you can team up with a friend and co-op to win battles together. 

The game does include quite a lot of microtransactions, which is a bit annoying for me and too EA-style, but if you buy them on sale you can snatch a lot of good deals. One of the most realistic RTS games in my opinion, would definitely recommend it.

Good game, but it has a harsh learning curve. I don't know why but even when I'm just fighting against AI I find this game really challenging, even when I set them to be easy on me. Maybe it's just me though, maybe I'll learn what I'm doing wrong later on down the road. 

Still having a decent bit of fun though, picked the game up on sale. 15$ For everything CoH so I don't feel ripped off, but if you were going to pay full price for it I'd definitely recommend you watch some YouTube videos on it first before making that choice. Perhaps wait around for another sale to come through. 

One thing I really like about this game is the skirmish mode where I can at least create scenarios for me to learn the game more, I really enjoy that. Plus all of the maps with the loaded amount of Workshop content it's got a lot here to offer for a WW2 strategy game. 

I have my graphics on max and the game looks pretty good, has some solid gore moments too where people get hit by artillery or something and splatter into a red paste of body parts and guts. 

Sounds are on point too, no complaints there. 

There are mods that fix certain things about the game, some things I personally didn't like so if you find something that bugs you, you might try looking for a mod to fix that issue.

This is like a solid 8.5/10 for me as of now. Still learning the game a lot, we'll see how far it goes. If you find this game on sale and you've been thinking about it, I'd say go for it.

Pros: an excellent real-time tactical strategy game that reigns in some of the more annoying cliches of the genre (Starcraft zerging) in favor of utilizing a small but effective platoon against your enemies. Set in the Second World War, this is just the balm to soothe your itch.

Cons: like every game these days, it requires you to be online in order to track progress. Sounds simple, right? WRONG! Servers are more unstable than World of Warcraft, which means you don't get any profile progress or achievements.

(Review in 2014, when I was a whole 15 years old. being 23 now, here's a new review. some 800 hours later.) 

I used to enjoy Company of Heros 2, It used to be one of my main games. Yes, I've got under a thousand hours - but there's this thing called real life. Now, the learning curve of this game. Is a bit unique compared to other RTS games like starcraft, whereas with the latter units will mob up into one super formation - in this one, your punished for doing so. with such, it's more of a tug of war battle, where early game the allies need to wipe out the germans, before late game they push back and take it over. There is no in between. At a point, the game was a tug of war between only Whermacht, and the Russians. Similair to how War Thunder started out. Eventually, they added the americans and the OBK, than eventually the british. Throughout its time, many of the early allies were unbalanced, the devs have done an... okay job - at balancing the game, there are some bugs - which havn't been fixed, or mechanics that are downright stupid. with that being said, I have to go back to the learning curve of this game, no amount of campaign is going to prepare you for how incredibly toxic this game is, players are quick to abandon games as soon as they see it going in a different direction, although this game is a tug of war. I actually had to uninstall the game because it was making me so upset, not in the fact that I'm losing matches. but rather, people who have made this their sole game - somehow get matched up with the same players trying to start out. I'm not sure why they even show a leaderboard ranking - when theres no ranked servers. as a new player starting out, expect to get screamed at. have your entire team leave, and force you to play with a delapidated AI code that is more in the minds of feeding the enemy. You can solo against the computer if you want to learn, but nothing will prepare you from seeing the same broken builds. 200 russians charging early game with PTRS rifles, or british bum rushing you with assault corps. By this time, people have found ways to gank any emplacement, where - it almost becomes paramount to set up defenses in the backline for the absolute memery that is about to unfold. from my experience, playing the allies has a bit better players, in the sense of being understanding of new players. but the, "Wheraboos" as they are called. some actual, noozi flag havin individuals who give you less than 2 minutes to decide if they are going to up and leave the game after screaming you should have bum rushed the fuel spot.  

To the developers that are so detached from the community working on other games, having sponsered tournaments is not akin to making new maps - this game would never win a labor of love award. and it's quite badly optimized. The minimum and reccomended requirements are an absolute joke when it comes to what I said about the 200 russians, I find the game lagging with even 16gb and a RX560 4GB. 

~Unforgiving veteran community

~Badly optimized

Certain game mechanics, specifically vehicles getting stuck on wrecks or losing sight lines to "smoke" 
AT guns getting ganked in situations where they otherwise shouldn't - or getting sight lines disrupted by vehicle moshpits, as somebody would rather mob up 5 tanks. x2 anti tank guns for 700 manpower? likely to not be enough for 5 tanks. With how AT guns and such are, your better off running with a bunch of rocket launchers. 

ch1n4 players don't have their own servers, instead connect to american servers and lag the entire server.

No punishment for leaving games on your team and forcing you to have CSGO bots. 

No ranked system, besides a leaderboard based on win rate

Pump and dump game from relic, occasionally will come back to charge money for microtransactions and get take a majority of the cash from the artist.  

Company of heros 1, ironically more balanced than the second. this ones, get steamrolled by the allies. buy allies DLC, steamroll the angry german wheraboo players. 

No way to know what commanders your team chooses, without seeing units in the mid game, making cohesian quite low. 

They removed the blizzard mechanics from the snow maps, speeding up games and making certain units obsolete. at a point, it would get bitter cold. infantry would need to build fires, or be inside of armored transport. weather mechanics made the possibility for a game to 180 due to builds. removed for.... no reason?

Honestly, its hard to compare this game to its predecessor. I liked the first one for its simplicity, but this installment introduces so many more mechanics, not to mention the DLC is literally played partially on a map similar to Total War: Napoleon. I enjoyed it thoroughly, however be warned, this game for some unknown reason is SIGNIFICANTLY harder than the first installment. I had more trouble playing on easy than when I tried running the first game on Medium. Units will almost always lose in a 1v1 skirmish, so you have to overwhelm even the most simple of enemy squads. If you see a German Tank, unload EVERYTHING you have, because your T-34 will not survive... especially if it is a Panther. This is somewhat realistic since the Russian tactic was "throw bodies at the enemy until they die or retreat" due to their war-of-attrition doctrine, so dont expect much tactical gameplay, apart from one mission where you get 3 sniper units and thats it. The only real strategy is "Use the conscripts which require no resources to just keep throwing bodies at enemies until something new happens." Overall, i enjoyed it; Its definitely not the copy-and-paste of CoH1 that I was expecting.

This is one of my top favorite RTSes.  Buying the extra army DLCs is worth it.  I wouldn't bother buying the generals.  The graphics, sound, voice acting, and game play are amazing.  This game will also teach you history about the armies and what they were outfitted with.  The cover system  and range of weapons is fun and the game comes off as pretty realistic.  A dude with a rifle can't kill a tank.  A guy 5 ft way with a machine gun blasting a dude with a rifle will win the battle.  Mines kill everything.  Doing a rocket barrage or a Gustav cannon, or the weird bear tank.  These explosions are HUGE.  EVERYTHING CATCHES ON FIRE!  Holes in the ground, people screaming, smoke, and all the tracers flying through the air.  It's very immersive.   I blew up a bridge and watch 3 tanks fall into a river.  You can shoot a frozen lake and sink the enemy into the water too.  You can blow a house up and it kills your enemy instantly.  The detail is just crazy.  Every friend I show this game too is immediately wants to get it, even if they don't play RTSes.  GREAT JOB RELIC AND SEGA!

Imagine you had a great game idea, some great 3D artists, and a well established RTS pedigree and then realising the programming team you have to implement this is the most useless, incompetent bunch of hack programmers left over from the bargain bin. Particularly the AI guys. Yes you lot. I know, lets copy and paste the AI from the original Dawn of War, i.e. an AI from 2004, with all the problems that entails (yes the AI really has almost all the same problems), such as.. AI who's difficulty depends on their starting position for some completely unknown reason. AI who literally drive round in circles aimlessly. AI that, when on your side, goes MIA just as the computer AI's attack at the same time. AI that runs into tank guns repeatedly without registering why this is bad. AI that shells its allies, harasses your engineers to repair its vehicles in the middle of a firefight or deliberately drives through and destroys your defences that you built three seconds earlier. An AI that is so hopeless it needs ridiculous levels of ammo and fuel bonuses to put up a fight. AI that tries to rush you mid game with 48 tanks and if that fails goes home and takes its ball with it. AI that only wins attacks by being suspiciously successful in parts of the battlefield you have looked away from for a couple of seconds). An AI that knows where all your units are regardless of fog of war because the programmers are to lazy to implement... er.. any sort of AI. 
Each game against the AI (in Annihilate) follows the same boring pattern (on the higher difficulties). You initially deploy faster than the AI and take more points. Enemy AI spams troops from endless reserves who die by running into your machine guns. Friendly AI collapses, despite of you taking the brunt of the attacks, giving the enemy half the resource points on your side (although bizarrely it will fight tooth and nail for a distant point with no advantage... while negating to fight for one just in front of its base). An enemy mortar appears and is miraculously good at blasting your men even though you constantly move them about and it has no spotters... so shouldn't have any idea where your guys are (your mortars on the other hand seems to hit everything but the enemy). Just before you can get a anti tank, an enemy tank turns up (as if by magic) then tanks appear repeatedly, all miraculously aware of where your anti tank are set up - to the point of driving down one pixel wide lines not covered by their line of fires. When you do get your own tank out, at long last, there are several anti tank guns miraculously set up in a line to take it out if you dare to send it into enemy territory. You eventually manage to get enough tanks to out shoot your enemy and the game gives up, cue a charge into the enemies base and a win (which always seems to happen at the half an hour to 40 minutes point - if you don't exploit the AIs many other weaknesses to 'cheat'). During this building blasting exercise, the AI will deploy hopelessly ineffective forces such as machine guns to fight tanks, tank guns to fight commandos and so on. In short, the AI is a predictable, boring, idiotic cheat, whose play borders on hairpullingly frustrating (well borders is an understatement), and is still rubbish.
And the rest of the programming sucks as well. Single core CPU thrashing, stuttering game play on CPUs that at the time of release would have been mind-blowing - the game literally pauses for a few seconds to er.. floss its teeth or something, for no obvious reason at least once a game, and shocking loading times. Bizarre physics that has corpses spinning round in mid-air and weird non existent explosions that send trees flying about as if they have been hit by an atom bomb. Add that to a grubby cash grab with commanders and tactics store purchases pushing a 'complete' game into the hundreds of pounds arena. I would avoid this one, purely on this basis, even though the game has a lot of potential and is more likely to be fun against a human (which admittedly is probably what the programmers were mainly concentrating on). But hey, not everyone wants to play games 'online' opponents and I prefer single player.
If COH 3 has the same AI underpinnings again I will not be buying it. Seriously, Dawn of War's AI was acceptable in 2004, a few tweaks for the new mechanics do not, however, make it any good these days though... and I do realise good AI is hard but even a fairly terrible AI would be more fun (and better) than this to play against. And seriously, if you sort the AI out it will be one hell of a game.

No regrets about buying this game, except perhaps that I hadn't heard about summer sales xD ! In any case, totally worth its money. Has an excellent singleplayer campaign which features every type of battlefield you could think off (entrenchments, villages, river crossings, shelled cities etc.). Last but not least the Multiplayer! 2 game modes, a variety of maps depending on the number of players and the fact that you are playing against humans ensures that no two matches are the same, even if they are fought on the same map with the same tarting locations (which are also not set for every map). Bought it approximately 2 months ago and played very often since then, I must admit I am very satisfied with this game, had quite some fun, and the achievement/army customisation/commanders options  make sure that you have a personalised game experience and playing style.

The only negative aspect so far is that sometimes you are matched with players that seem to possess not much more that the basic skills, due to the matchmaker looking to build even teams, and not find players that are on the same level (meaning that it will try to get 2 teams with the same average level, no matter if one team has 2 players with levels 1 and 50 and the other one 2 players with levels 24 and 26).

Such a great game cant say enough good things. was the benchmark for all strategy games of the future.  but ever since expansions the balance is so off. i know the OKF was OP in the beginning but now its just ridiculous the amount of nerfing. the game is basically unplayable if you arent russian or american. most of my experience is AI as i play at the wee morning and evening hours.  enemy AI tanks hit infantry with 50% accuracy on the main guns but my 5 Star fully veteran tanks with MG42's hit infantry with 10% accuracy.  literally sitting there for several minutes of sustained fire, from the main gun and 2 MG's.....but if my infantry sprint past a tank, they are decimated. not even a chance of retreat.  theyll get blasted by some hail mary shot a mile away, which brings me to my next point.  the sight range is all wack, and enemy units somehow become reshrouded whilest my units are still clearly in sight and attack range.  and these arent stealth type units.  tanks will be there and then gone and reappear to fire on my units but then just reshroud and my units will lose target.  not to mention when told to attack for some reason tanks controlled by users will do a move to the enemy unit and only attack once theyve reached face touching distance. this goes for tanks and infantry.  whats the point of having a 70 something MM cannon if theyre going to shake hands distance before firing. i understand COH3 is coming etc etc. this is old stuff but the games basically broken. grats.

This game is one of the best WWII strategy games out there.
Campaign is Fun: Spam Conscripts
The DLC: Good Stuff but wait for sale
Multiplayer:
The game is more enjoyable when played in 3v3 and 4v4, pure chaos and destruction when in late game. 
1v1 mode is somewhat boring and it just shoves away the other commanders since their useless in that mode.
Strenghts:
- 3v3 and 4v4 modes are the fun mode in here. I wish the developers know this, since this isn't red alert or SC with fast paced combat. Also better invite your friends to play this game, so communicating in 3v3 or 4v4 modes aren't going to be difficult.
- when in 3v3 or 4v4 experimenting with specific commanders are fun.
- The slow to medium paced battles/ "Tactical Gameplay" are good for the average RTS enjoyer. As you would find it isn't task intensive (micro/macro). 
Cons:
- Sometimes and especially when you're new at this game. Factions seems to be unbalanced. But as you play more and encounter those line-up you would understand that you're just playing wrong. In short the game just feels a bit overwhelming, and it takes time to understand factions. 
- A niche game, RTS ain't sexy for the majority of gamers out there. There is a high chance you're going to play with the same person in your second game in Multiplayer.
- UI, matchmaking, and multiplayer system is kind of archaic in this time and age.
- Not the friendliest community. *salt and toxicity intensifies

If you're looking for a fun WW2 RTS game, COH2 is arguably the best choice. In terms of gameplay, it is fun and immersive. The factions are unique especially since there are two german factions but they still play differently. The soundtrack is great but when you have been playing for a long time, you'd notice that there isn't much OST used in-game. There are mods available but it's a downgrade of what modders are able to do in the previous installment. What most they can do is provide different stat values and in-game rules but no custom models and sound effects, although custom maps and custom icons are still available.

Unfortunately, one downside of this game is that most of the content are locked through a paywall. These locked content includes but are not limited to: other factions, maps, scenarios, and another campaign. Another issue of this game is that compared to the previous installment, the commanders are unlocked through either grinding or real money. I can forgive cosmetics since they don't mess up gameplay during multiplayer, but since it requires you to grind or buy the commanders it kinda becomes a pay to win issue. As of this review, I have 1347.5 hrs on record and I might be able to unlock all the commanders and cosmetics with the currency I saved up. It's kinda annoying if you have to sell almost 1000hrs of your life just to unlock everything. Don't get me wrong I didn't play 1000+ hrs because I grinded hard but 
 because I enjoyed the game.

If you enjoyed the previous game, you'll enjoy this although you'd want to get this during sales and get the full game since the full experience is there.

CoH2 is not for everyone. The learning curve is realy high and on multiplayer you'll find very good competition. Your army must be balanced and you have to pick wisely your next piece of vehicle or infantry group, time and territory are your most valuable resources... and for higher levels blobing is not an option; micromanagement and agressive play is the key for the win.
The campaign is utter garbage (the American one is quite decent), but the level of action within multiplayer games can't be compared. 
Love this game and probably I'll always will. 

And I'm still do. The game is pretty much still alive, though there are plans on making a third part that could be awsome too. And all the time they are updating generals, balancing the game and adding more maps from the community.
